In all regions and sectors, the COVID-19 pandemic shaped the story in 2021, and the recovery helps set priorities for 2022.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/navigating-the-labor-mismatch-in-us-logistics-and-supply-chains\"\u003eThe labor mismatch in the United States\u003c/a\u003e has pushed private-sector wages to increase at more than double the long-term pre-COVID-19 growth rates, yet positions remain unfilled. Some underlying factors are directly related to the impact of the pandemic and may be temporary. But deeper structural shifts could have a longer-lasting impact. Companies seeking labor resilience should learn to measure risk, design bold interventions, and ensure strong executive-level support.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/america-2022-in-charts-an-economic-opportunity-snapshot\"\u003eOur second American Opportunity Survey\u003c/a\u003e revealed that Americans are aware of the labor market changes: 49 percent of respondents said that most Americans have opportunities to find good jobs, up seven percentage points from March, when we first conducted our survey. Their biggest economic worry, by far, and a prime barrier to sustainable and inclusive growth? Access to healthcare and/or health insurance.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/education/our-insights/covid-19-and-education-an-emerging-k-shaped-recovery\"\u003eTaking a measure of US student achievement after pandemic-era school closures\u003c/a\u003e is a bleak business: students in majority-Black schools are five months behind where they would otherwise have been, both in math and reading. Students in majority-White schools are now just two months behind historical levels. If current trends persist, historically disadvantaged students could remain up to a grade level behind their peers. Educational systems can invest now to ensure all students have the chance to recover from the pandemic\u0026rsquo;s many setbacks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe impact of the COVID-19 crisis shows that \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/indias-postpandemic-logistics-sector-the-need-for-technological-change\"\u003eIndia\u0026rsquo;s logistics sector needs structural reforms more than ever\u003c/a\u003e. In the warehousing function, companies could consider shrinking their product mix, allocating more inventory to essential items, and introducing processes to reduce levels of human contact. In the transport function, key steps include using efficient multimodal transportation more extensively.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/disruption-and-uncertainty-the-state-of-grocery-2022-china\"\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s report on the state of China\u0026rsquo;s grocery industry\u003c/a\u003e reveals a paradox: this huge market leads in online commerce and is growing rapidly but is also highly unproductive, with the lowest sales per square meter in the world. The report covers topics including emerging trends that will shape the competitive landscape, the path to profitability for different retail models, and the sweeping impact of changing consumer preferences and technology.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn \u003ca href=\"/mgi/overview/2021-turning-point-reinvention-and-opportunity-in-the-economy-of-the-future\"\u003ea year-end look at how the pandemic has reset the ways we live, work, and do business\u003c/a\u003e, the \u003ca href=\"/mgi/overview\"\u003eMcKinsey Global Institute\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;showcases 12 of the most thought-provoking charts from our research over the past year. The rise of the Asian consumer, the changing workplace, and pandemic-era changes that could yield higher productivity are among the topics in focus.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNo discussion of 2021 would be complete without a debrief on the highlight of the year: the release of the COVID-19 vaccines. On the \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/inside-the-strategy-room-podcast\"\u003eInside the Strategy Room\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e podcast, \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-race-to-create-a-vaccine-a-conversation-with-frank-damelio\"\u003ePfizer\u0026rsquo;s CFO Frank D\u0026rsquo;Amelio\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;discusses the decision to put $2 billion of capital at risk and never look at the business case during development. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are some of this week\u0026rsquo;s other key findings from our research:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eOn \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-podcast\"\u003eThe McKinsey Podcast\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e, Knut Alicke and Dan Swan, partners in McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Operations Practice, describe \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/diagnosing-the-pain-in-your-supply-chain\"\u003ethe main cost, labor, and transportation issues facing CEOs and supply-chain managers\u003c/a\u003e. They suggest ways executives can build resilience into their supply-chain strategies for when the next major shake-up arrives.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eIn \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-global-surveys\"\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Global Survey\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;on \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/quantumblack/our-insights/global-survey-the-state-of-ai-in-2021\"\u003eAI adoption\u003c/a\u003e, 56 percent of respondents report AI adoption in at least one function, up from 50 percent in 2020, with the greatest increases coming from companies in emerging economies. Nearly two-thirds of respondents say their companies\u0026rsquo; investments in AI will continue to increase over the next three years.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eLatinos make up 18.4 percent of the US population and 17.3 percent of the US labor force, a share forecast to rise more than 30 percent by 2060. Latinos start more businesses and have higher rates of intergenerational mobility, yet \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/the-economic-state-of-latinos-in-america-the-american-dream-deferred\"\u003eremain far from equal with non-Latino White Americans\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eThis week, we feature three books in our \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks\"\u003eAuthor Talks\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;series. Simon Mundy, Moral Money editor at the \u003c/em\u003eFinancial Times\u003cem\u003e, discusses his new book, \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-the-human-side-of-climate-change\"\u003eRace for Tomorrow: Survival, Innovation and Profit on the Front Lines of the Climate Crisis\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e (William Collins, January 2022). The book relates the personal tales of people around the world dealing with the effects of climate change. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eDavid Schonthal, professor of strategy, innovation, and entrepreneurship at Northwestern University\u0026rsquo;s Kellogg School of Management, discusses his new book, \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-the-forces-working-against-innovation-and-how-to-overcome-them\"\u003eThe Human Element: Overcoming the Resistance That Awaits New Ideas\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e (Wiley, 2021). Innovators should consider factors including how much energy has to be expended to adopt a new idea and what emotions it brings up in those who interact with it. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eRob Cross, the Edward A. Madden Professor of Global Leadership at Babson College, discusses his new work, \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-beyond-collaboration-overload\"\u003eBeyond Collaboration Overload: How to Work Smarter, Get Ahead, and Restore Your Well-Being\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e (Harvard Business Review Press, 2021). Through roughly 800 interviews with high performers, Cross identifies what makes collaboration effective and what is just a big time-suck.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Katy McLaughlin, a senior editor in the Southern California office.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Ceros covid2]]\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #84, December 8, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eThe virus is not the only thing with a talent for transformation.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIf you could \u003c/strong\u003esay anything positive about the COVID-19 pandemic\u0026mdash;and its latest twist, the Omicron variant\u0026mdash;it might be that it forced a lot of people to get better at accepting and acting upon the need for change. This week, we looked at three ways in which business leaders are transforming their organizations, as well as changes reshaping mortgages, infrastructure, healthcare, and the workplace.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/the-ceo-architect-of-the-new-operations-agenda\"\u003eCEOs today face tough operational obstacles\u003c/a\u003e, including difficulty in finding workers and an upward price spiral for goods. The prices for basic commodities including steel, semiconductors, and natural gas have risen, as have container-shipping costs. The need for decarbonization adds a long-term challenge to the total picture. To get ahead of operational difficulties, leaders can set up resilient, risk-tolerant supply-chain structures, double down on digitization, and achieve real-time visibility and systematic responses to external developments.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBusiness building is one of the top strategic priorities for organizations\u0026mdash;double the share of recent years. That\u0026rsquo;s because business leaders expect half of their companies\u0026rsquo; revenues five years from now to come from products, services, or businesses that do not yet exist, according to the latest \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-global-surveys\"\u003eMcKinsey Global Survey\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;on \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/2021-global-report-the-state-of-new-business-building\"\u003enew-business building\u003c/a\u003e. This year\u0026rsquo;s survey provides insights to move organizations up the learning curve faster.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMcKinsey talked to more than 350 senior executives about their plans for \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/managing-change-what-lies-behind-g-and-a-spend-transformation\"\u003etransforming sales, general, and administrative activities\u003c/a\u003e. Of the executives surveyed, 91 percent are planning to maintain or increase investment in digital technology in the coming years. More than half of respondents (compared with just over a quarter last year) said remote working has increased productivity compared with pre-COVID-19 levels. This boost is leading organizations to aspire to an average of 20 percent savings through optimizing real-estate portfolios.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBefore we go any deeper into the topic of change, let\u0026rsquo;s admit that it\u0026rsquo;s not easy. On the \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/mckinsey-on-government/id1573645359\"\u003eMcKinsey on Government\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e podcast, \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/organizing-for-change\"\u003eMcKinsey senior partner Kirk Rieckhoff discusses why change is so hard\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;for systems and organizations, how to put teams together that can embrace a transformation, and the steps that lead to success.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe mortgage industry has been gradually adopting technology to streamline processes. But there is still an \u003ca href=\"/industries/private-capital/our-insights/five-trends-reshaping-the-us-home-mortgage-industry\"\u003eopportunity for investors to help make getting mortgages easier\u003c/a\u003e, faster, and cheaper, with increased digitization and automation, and through offerings from nonbank lenders, next-generation subservicers, nonqualified mortgage lenders, and companies bundling home-buying services. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe December edition of \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/how-we-help-clients/global-infrastructure-initiative/voices/voices-on-infrastructure-improving-project-development-and-delivery\"\u003eVoices on Infrastructure\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e explores the transformational power of the \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/how-we-help-clients/global-infrastructure-initiative/voices/creating-capacity-to-deliver-using-investment-to-spur-transformation\"\u003eInfrastructure and Investment Jobs Act and the EU Green Deal\u003c/a\u003e. The collection includes articles about \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/how-we-help-clients/global-infrastructure-initiative/voices/perspectives-on-optimizing-project-performance-in-rail\"\u003ehow rail-industry leaders optimize project development\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to meet changing environmental, social, and governance expectations, and the \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/how-we-help-clients/global-infrastructure-initiative/voices/investing-in-the-next-generation-of-transportation-infrastructure\"\u003eopportunities for infrastructure investors to modernize transportation\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/how-we-help-clients/global-infrastructure-initiative/voices/infrastructure-investing-to-build-a-net-zero-carbon-world\"\u003ehelp Europe meet its decarbonization goals\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/innovation-and-value-what-payer-led-managed-care-models-may-look-like\"\u003eHealthcare payers can take a more active role in the healthcare of members\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;with comprehensive care models that are expected to eventually lower total medical costs. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eParents are transforming the workplace in a way unlikely to please employers: by leaving it. \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/married-to-the-job-no-more-craving-flexibility-parents-are-quitting-to-get-it\"\u003eEmployers are wise to offer parents creative flexibility\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in how, when, and where they do their jobs. \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/income-alone-may-be-insufficient-how-employers-can-help-advance-health-equity-in-the-workplace\"\u003eEmployers can improve health equity\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;by ensuring benefits are easy to access and understand, destigmatizing receiving care, and exploring benefits that help with basic needs such as housing and transportation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are some of this week\u0026rsquo;s other key findings from our research:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/why-micromobility-is-here-to-stay\"\u003eConsumers are enthusiastic about micromobility\u003c/a\u003e, with almost 70 percent stating that they were willing to use micromobility vehicles for their commute\u0026mdash;though with lots of regional variability. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/integrated-evidence-generation-a-paradigm-shift-in-biopharma\"\u003eIntegrated evidence-generation plans (IEPs)\u003c/a\u003e are being developed by a handful of life-sciences companies. IEPs take into account the evidence needs of different functions and geographies across the life cycle of an asset, and then collaboratively determine how to meet them using a broad range of methods and data. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/the-uk-biotech-sector-the-path-to-global-leadership\"\u003eThe United Kingdom is Europe\u0026rsquo;s leading biotech hub\u003c/a\u003e in breakthrough life-sciences start-ups. UK biotechs can continue transforming their global impact by leveraging their uniquely data-rich environment and increasing collaboration and collective growth.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eOn \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-podcast\"\u003eThe McKinsey Podcast\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e, McKinsey partner Shelley Stewart III discusses \u003ca href=\"/bem/our-insights/serving-the-black-consumer-is-a-300-billion-dollar-opportunity\"\u003eopportunities to serve Black consumers\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;with housing, healthcare, grocery stores, and brands that fit their needs. \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOur \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks\"\u003eAuthor Talks\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e series features Pulitzer Prize winner and \u003c/em\u003eNew York Times\u003cem\u003e editorial-board member Farah Stockman. In her book, \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-what-happens-to-americans-when-they-lose-their-jobs\"\u003eAmerican Made: What Happens to People When Work Disappears\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e (Penguin Random House, October 2021), Stockman follows three workers laid off from manufacturing jobs that provided not only paychecks but also status, meaning, and the basis of connection to American life.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Katy McLaughlin, a senior editor in the Southern California office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #83, December 1, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003ePart of any recovery is fixing the things that broke. \u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIt\u0026rsquo;s exhilarating to think \u003c/strong\u003eabout creating new technology that will help build sustainable and inclusive growth. But this week, McKinsey delved into the less glamorous work of repairing what is hobbled, leaky, or damaged. Time and inertia have eroded the United States\u0026rsquo; water system, while the COVID-19 pandemic did a number on global travel in both tourism-dependent regions such as Thailand and emerging markets where tourism is less developed. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe \u003ca href=\"/industries/electric-power-and-natural-gas/our-insights/us-water-infrastructure-making-funding-count\"\u003eneed for investment in the US water system\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;is at an unprecedented level. Among other problems, on average, 14 to 18 percent of total daily treated potable water in the United States is lost through leaks. Fortunately, an exciting set of technologies is making it possible to achieve water objectives more efficiently, while the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act includes significantly higher investment in desalination, water conservation, and water recycling. If players across the system are strategic, there is a unique opportunity to prepare the system to be resilient, safe, and affordable for the generations to come.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCountries that are heavily dependent on international tourism, such as Thailand, need to mend a revenue crater created by the pandemic. Passenger occupancy on international flights to Thailand dropped by 95 percent in September 2021 compared with the previous year, while hotels only filled 9 percent of their rooms. \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/reimagining-travel-thailand-tourism-after-the-covid-19-pandemic\"\u003eThailand\u0026rsquo;s travel industry can seek growth\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;by bundling product offerings, promoting ecotourism and cultural tourism, and investing in infrastructure in destinations attractive to domestic tourists, among other options.  \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCountries where tourism is still being developed face a related, but different, set of repairs. In September 2020, \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/growth-in-a-crisis-lessons-from-hospitality-ceo-omar-el-hamamsy\"\u003eOmar El Hamamsy took on the role of CEO of Orascom Development\u003c/a\u003e, a real-estate and hospitality multinational, when there was plenty to fix. It was six months into the COVID-19 pandemic, seven months after the sudden passing of the company\u0026rsquo;s previous CEO, and amid an 84 percent drop in the number of global international tourist arrivals. In an interview with McKinsey, Hamamsy discusses the unique challenges of managing the company\u0026rsquo;s properties located in emerging markets.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere is some of this week\u0026rsquo;s other research:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/private-capital/our-insights/mckinsey-on-investing-issue-7\"\u003eThe latest issue of \u003cem\u003eMcKinsey on Investing\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e examines how a multitude of industries were reshaped by the COVID-19 pandemic. In a collection of nine feature articles, 16 elaborate charts, and two pages of facts and figures with the power to surprise, the publication explores themes of interest to private-markets investors. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/clinical-supply-chains-how-to-boost-excellence-and-innovation\"\u003eElevating clinical drug supply to best-in-class standards\u003c/a\u003e can deliver benefits including cost savings in clinical drug supply of 15 to 20 percent. Companies can explore new ways to achieve supply-chain flexibility in sourcing, employ advanced analytics for patient forecasting, and develop external partnerships with contract research organizations, among other strategies.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/food-security/how-healthcare-payers-can-expand-nutrition-support-for-the-food-insecure\"\u003eHealthcare payers have an opportunity to improve nutrition\u003c/a\u003e and have a positive impact on health. Early evidence suggests that medically tailored meal programs lead to fewer emergency-room visits and admissions to hospitals and skilled-nursing facilities, as well as lower monthly medical spending. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/oil-and-gas/our-insights/strategies-for-ofse-companies-confronting-the-energy-transition\"\u003eThe accelerating global energy transition has implications for the oil-field-services-and-equipment sector\u003c/a\u003e. Players must act swiftly and pursue an informed strategy because waiting for the upswing is not an option in the long run.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOur  \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks\"\u003eAuthor Talks\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e series features Wil Haygood, a journalist and Boadway Visiting Distinguished Scholar at Miami University. His new book \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-the-history-of-black-cinema-in-america\"\u003eColorization: One Hundred Years of Black Films in a White World\u003c/a\u003e (Alfred A. Knopf, October 2021)\u003cem\u003e examines a century of Black cinema history and the insights it offers into Black culture and civil rights in the United States. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Katy McLaughlin, a senior editor in the Southern California office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #82, November 24, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eThe COVID-19 pandemic locked us down, but in the future, we aim to fly.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAfter nearly two years\u003c/strong\u003e of lockdowns, travel bans, and at-home school and work, there\u0026rsquo;s some poetic justice in the robust development of advanced air mobility. The industry, which includes more than 250 companies developing electric vertical takeoff and landing (eVTOL) aircraft, attracted more than $5.4 billion in investment in just the first nine months of 2021. By 2030, thousands of eVTOLs could be flying above cities, delivering both cargo and passengers. \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/the-next-normal/air-taxis\"\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s video-rich package delves into advanced air mobility\u003c/a\u003e, where technology stands now, how it could play out, and what it means for the future of cities and society.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThree CEOs shared their companies\u0026rsquo; visions for air mobility. \u003ca href=\"/industries/aerospace-and-defense/our-insights/will-volocity-transform-urban-transportation\"\u003eFlorian Reuter, CEO of aircraft manufacturer Volocopter, spoke to McKinsey\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;about the multirotor eVTOL two-seater aircraft his company plans to offer for commercial use in 2024.  \u003ca href=\"/industries/aerospace-and-defense/our-insights/rideshares-in-the-sky-by-2024-joby-aviation-bets-big-on-air-taxis\"\u003eBonny Simi, Joby Aviation\u0026rsquo;s head of air operations and people, talked with us about how air taxis may change where people live\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and how they commute and travel. Joby\u0026rsquo;s eVTOL aircraft seats five people\u0026mdash;a pilot and four passengers\u0026mdash;and can travel at speeds of up to 200 miles per hour. And \u003ca href=\"/industries/aerospace-and-defense/our-insights/speeding-up-everyday-travel-lilium-prepares-for-takeoff\"\u003eDaniel Wiegand, CEO of Lilium, explained how his company\u0026rsquo;s aircraft are designed\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to minimize noise emissions\u0026mdash;something he believes will be crucial to community acceptance\u0026mdash;and with electric and battery power for sustainability.\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt can be hard to imagine a future of easy, cheap, and fast transportation when today the world\u0026rsquo;s containers are stuck in an expensive holding pattern. In a follow-up to their August video about why shipping costs skyrocketed during the COVID-19 pandemic, \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/when-are-shipping-rates-going-to-normalize\"\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s logistics experts forecast when shipping rates may normalize\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and at what level, identify challenges that may prolong the record costs, and explain how the Chinese New Year next February may affect shipping rates.\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/how-covid-19-is-reshaping-supply-chains\"\u003eMcKinsey surveyed a diverse group of supply-chain executives\u003c/a\u003e globally to learn what steps they had taken to shore up their supply chains over the past year. Among key findings: companies were more likely than expected to increase inventories, and less likely either to diversify supply bases or to implement nearshoring or regionalization strategies.\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/what-will-it-take-to-go-from-travel-shock-to-surge\"\u003eAxel Hefer, CEO of Trivago, a global accommodation search\u003c/a\u003e platform, has seen a big shift toward travel domestically and to neighboring countries. In an interview with McKinsey, he describes how it could take years for the industry to rebuild trust in the idea that intercontinental travel is a low-risk activity.\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are some of this week\u0026rsquo;s other key findings from our research:\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/net-zero-power-long-duration-energy-storage-for-a-renewable-grid\"\u003eDevelopment of a long-duration energy-storage market\u003c/a\u003e would enable the energy system to function smoothly with a large share of power coming from renewables and would make a substantial contribution to decarbonizing the power sector fully by 2040.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eIn this episode of \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-podcast\"\u003eThe McKinsey Podcast\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e, Mona Mourshed, global founder and CEO of Generation, discusses \u003ca href=\"/about-us/social-responsibility/the-economic-impact-of-ageism\"\u003ea consistent pattern of bias against workers aged 45 and older across geographies\u003c/a\u003e. Weirdly, managers tend to rate their older workers high, but are reluctant to hire them. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThey play an increasingly important role in global trade, but micro, small, and medium-size enterprises \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/reconceiving-the-global-trade-finance-ecosystem\"\u003e(MSMEs) are often excluded from the $5.2 trillion global trade finance ecosystem\u003c/a\u003e. Trade finance needs an architecture of common standards and best practices to become more inclusive, collaborative, and digitized. \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eHere\u0026rsquo;s something to discuss around the Thanksgiving table: our new edition of \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-for-kids\"\u003eMcKinsey for Kids\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e starts with the mess scattered around a typical kid\u0026rsquo;s bedroom and ends in Asia, where K-pop is influencing the world\u0026rsquo;s popular culture. What ties it all together? \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-for-kids/k-pop-culture-containers-and-why-asias-where-the-action-is\"\u003eA deep dive for young people into global trade\u003c/a\u003e. We go back to ancient Mesopotamia, through the Industrial Revolution, and onto container ships to explain why and how the socks on your floor, the songs on your playlist, and the food in your lunch box come from all over the world.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Katy McLaughlin, a senior editor in the Southern California office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #81, November 17, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eIt\u0026rsquo;s time to set priorities for the next era.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThis week,\u003c/strong\u003e McKinsey delved into priority setting, starting with ideas about how the wealth of ten top economies might be put to more productive use. We continued exploring what\u0026rsquo;s most important now with a breakdown of what the United States intends to tackle with its new $1.2 trillion infrastructure bill and in articles about COP26, M\u0026amp;A trends, and corporate responsibilities. We also reached outside our sphere, querying dozens of journalists about what they view as the top stories of our time.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMcKinsey took stock of the underlying health and resilience of the global economy as it begins to rebound from the COVID-19 pandemic and questioned \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/the-rise-and-rise-of-the-global-balance-sheet-how-productively-are-we-using-our-wealth\"\u003ehow productively global wealth is being used\u003c/a\u003e. Asset values in ten major economies are now nearly 50 percent higher than the long-run average relative to income. From 2000 to 2020, for every $1 of net new investment, twice as much debt and four times as many liabilities have been created. Historically, the growth of net worth has largely reflected investments that drive productivity and growth, in addition to inflation. Over the past two decades, however, increases in asset prices\u0026mdash;driven largely by soaring real-estate prices\u0026mdash;made up 77 percent of net-worth growth. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe first article in our new series, \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/reinvesting-in-america\"\u003eReinvesting in America\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e, breaks \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/the-us-bipartisan-infrastructure-law-breaking-it-down\"\u003edown the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act\u003c/a\u003e, signed into law this week. The act allocates an estimated $1.2 trillion in total funding over ten years, including $550 billion in new spending during the next five, divided between improving the surface-transportation network ($284 billion) and society\u0026rsquo;s core infrastructure ($266 billion).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/cop26-made-net-zero-a-core-principle-for-business-heres-how-leaders-can-act\"\u003eOur key takeaway from COP26\u003c/a\u003e was that the net-zero imperative is no longer in question\u0026mdash;it has become an organizing principle for business. McKinsey analysis indicates that a net-zero transition would require $150 trillion of capital spending, two-thirds of it in developing economies. Net-zero commitments are outpacing the formation of supply chains, market mechanisms, and financing models. We propose five considerations that can help executives define an effective net-zero program for the next few years. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eM\u0026amp;A deal value was up 175 percent from a year earlier for large transactions, according to \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/m-and-a/our-insights/record-breaking-global-m-and-a-activity-continues-in-first-half\"\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s review of global M\u0026amp;A trends\u003c/a\u003e. By the end of August, the value of large global M\u0026amp;A transactions had already surpassed $3.9 trillion, making the $4.5 trillion record set in 2007 appear within reach. The continued high premiums make extracting greater value from transactions more important than ever. Private-equity firms are increasingly prioritizing full-fledged business building, and corporate players are working harder\u0026mdash;and sometimes paying more\u0026mdash;to find hidden jewels.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn this episode of the\u003cem\u003e \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/inside-the-strategy-room-podcast\"\u003eInside the Strategy Room\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003epodcast, two authors of a new \u003ca href=\"/mgi/overview\"\u003eMcKinsey Global Institute\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;report examine how \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-corporation-in-the-21st-century\"\u003ethe value that companies bring to economies, societies, and households has changed\u003c/a\u003e. Between 1995 and 2018, the contribution of large corporations to their home countries\u0026rsquo; economies rose by ten percentage points in terms of share of GDP. But those corporations are relying less and less on assets and labor\u0026mdash;less physical capital and fewer employees per unit of revenue\u0026mdash;which raises a wide set of questions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe know what we think the big topics will be in the coming year, but we wanted to learn what members of the media consider most significant. \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/what-major-themes-will-we-see-in-global-media-in-2022-what-should-we-see-more-of\"\u003eMcKinsey asked dozens of journalists and media leaders around the world two big coverage questions\u003c/a\u003e. First, what business, economics, or policy theme do they predict will dominate media in 2022? And second, what topic do they think will be under covered, and why does it merit more attention? Our interactive presentation lets our audience choose which journalists or publications they want to hear from. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are some of this week\u0026rsquo;s other key findings from our research:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/electrifying-the-bottom-line-how-oems-can-boost-ev-profitability\"\u003eAutomotive leaders can improve their electric-vehicle (EV) business strategy\u003c/a\u003e with six key insights from our research on EV profitability. The full report is available upon request from \u003ca href=\"mailto:MCFM@mckinsey.com\"\u003eMCFM@mckinsey.com\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eAutomation, connectivity, and electrification will have profound effects on \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/the-future-of-interior-in-automotive\"\u003ethe design of automotive interiors\u003c/a\u003e. McKinsey examines considerations for OEMs and suppliers as vehicle interiors evolve.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eMost companies lack the tools to effectively manage \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/managing-the-risks-and-returns-of-intelligent-automation\"\u003ethe risks and returns of intelligent automation\u003c/a\u003e. Five steps can help create a better understanding of automation risk and how to handle it.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eA yearlong research collaboration between McKinsey and Exemplars in Global Health identifies factors that can drive widescale implementation of \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/unlocking-digital-healthcare-in-lower-and-middle-income-countries\"\u003edigital tools across healthcare systems in lower- and middle-income countries\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eAmid COVID-19-era supply-chain disruptions, \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/revamping-fashion-sourcing-speed-and-flexibility-to-the-fore\"\u003eapparel companies must shift toward a new sourcing model\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that is flexible, fast, sustainable, digitally enhanced, and consumer-centric. Four key strategies can accelerate success.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOur \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks\"\u003eAuthor Talks\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e features Giulio Boccaletti, honorary research associate at the Smith School of Enterprise and the Environment, University of Oxford, and a former McKinsey partner. He discusses his new book, \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-giulio-boccaletti-on-the-relationship-between-society-and-water\"\u003eWater: A Biography\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e (Pantheon, September 2021), which examines how societies throughout history have managed water resources and what the institutions that protect us from water events can learn from the past.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOur new edition of \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-for-kids/i-robot-what-technology-shifts-mean-for-tomorrows-jobs\"\u003eMcKinsey for Kids\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e starts with the mess scattered around a typical kid\u0026rsquo;s bedroom and ends in Asia, where K-pop is influencing the world\u0026rsquo;s popular culture. What ties it all together? \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-for-kids/k-pop-culture-containers-and-why-asias-where-the-action-is\"\u003eA deep dive for young people into global trade\u003c/a\u003e. We go back to ancient Mesopotamia, through the Industrial Revolution, and onto container ships to explain why and how the socks on your floor, the songs on your playlist, and the food in your lunch box come from all over the world.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Katy McLaughlin, a senior editor in the Southern California office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #80, November 10, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eBouncing back higher requires tackling underlying obstacles.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThis week, \u003c/strong\u003eMcKinsey continued its exploration into how to grow economies sustainably and inclusively by focusing on the United States, its regions, and specific programs. We also examined the global fight against climate change in interviews with the authors of two books on the topic and with an article on building resilience.  \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/a-sustainable-inclusive-and-growing-future-for-the-united-states\"\u003eThe United States can achieve sustainable and inclusive growth\u003c/a\u003e if it can address issues including the struggles of young people, who are building wealth at a much slower pace than their peers did half a century ago, and large gaps in workforce participation, wages, and higher-education attainment. Other challenges include climate change, which is affecting people in different geographies in the United States in various ways, and slower productivity growth. McKinsey proposes a series of no-regrets actions to create the conditions for economic growth that mitigates climate change and benefits a wide swath of the population.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThough the region enjoys a strong economy and lower unemployment than the national average, \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/americas/toward-an-equitable-economic-recovery-in-minneapolis-st-paul\"\u003eMinneapolis\u0026ndash;St. Paul has dramatic prosperity gaps between Black and White residents\u003c/a\u003e. Median Black household income is less than half the median White household income ($42,200 compared with $90,100, respectively), and workers of color were one and a half to two times likelier to report loss of income during the pandemic. To address root causes of inequities, leaders can increase access to capital for entrepreneurs, eliminate policies and practices that result in bias and exclusion, expand mentorship, and support the reskilling of workers. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/preparing-for-a-successful-homeowner-assistance-fund-program\"\u003eStates can leverage data to prepare for the US Treasury\u0026rsquo;s $10 billion Homeowner Assistance Fund program\u003c/a\u003e, intended to help homeowners avoid defaults and delinquencies through assistance with mortgage, insurance, and utility payments. A well-designed strategy to gather and analyze data will help states support homeowners most at risk. Going further to build dynamic models of the impact of different decisions and scenarios can also help states test various potential policies.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eThis week, we spoke with three authors for our \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks\"\u003eAuthor Talks\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e series, two of whom tackle climate change. Katharine Hayhoe, chief scientist for The Nature Conservancy, discusses her new book, \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-there-is-no-vaccine-for-climate-change\"\u003eSaving Us: A Climate Scientist\u0026rsquo;s Case for Hope and Healing in a Divided World\u003c/a\u003e \u003cem\u003e(Simon \u0026amp; Schuster, September 2021). Hayhoe examines the facts of climate change and suggests personal and policy changes that can improve the situation.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eIn his new book, \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-can-okrs-solve-our-planets-climate-crisis\"\u003eSpeed \u0026amp; Scale: An Action Plan for Solving Our Climate Crisis Now\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e (Penguin Random House, November 2021), John Doerr, investor and chairman of venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins, highlights ten big, global objectives by which we can cut carbon emissions. These include how we electrify transportation, decarbonize the grid, and manufacture concrete and steel.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEven in a scenario in which aggressive decarbonization results in just 1.5\u0026deg;C of warming above preindustrial levels by 2050, the number of people exposed to severe climate hazards could still increase to a quarter of the global population. \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/protecting-people-from-a-changing-climate-the-case-for-resilience\"\u003eLeaders need to build resilience against climate events\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;into their plans. Insurance, civil-engineering, agricultural, and financial-services companies all have roles to play in encouraging and enabling investment in sustainability and resilience.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are some of this week\u0026rsquo;s other key findings from our research:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThe global economy is exhibiting strong overall demand, according to \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/global-economics-intelligence-executive-summary-october-2021\"\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Global Economics Intelligence executive summary\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;for October. The public-health situation has improved in most surveyed economies, especially as COVID-19 vaccination programs make real progress. The main economic challenges are supply-chain bottlenecks and rising inflation. Fortunately, most economists and forecasting institutions expect that these difficulties will be relatively short lived. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eIn McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s new report, \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/iot-value-set-to-accelerate-through-2030-where-and-how-to-capture-it\"\u003eThe Internet of Things: Catching up to an accelerating opportunity\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e, we estimate that by 2030, the IoT could enable $5.5 trillion to $12.6 trillion in value globally. We found that the factory setting will account for the largest amount of potential economic value from the IoT, about 26 percent, in 2030. The human-health setting is second, representing about 10 to 14 percent of estimated value in 2030.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/our-insights/managing-growth-and-value-creation-in-saas\"\u003eSue Barsamian\u003c/a\u003e is a seasoned software executive who serves on the boards of companies including Five9, Box, and NortonLifeLock. In a wide-ranging interview, she discusses product\u0026ndash;market fit, why unit economics always matters, and what\u0026rsquo;s making her optimistic about board diversity. \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOur new edition of \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-for-kids\"\u003eMcKinsey for Kids\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e starts with the mess scattered around a typical kid\u0026rsquo;s bedroom and ends in Asia where K-pop is influencing the world\u0026rsquo;s popular culture. What ties it all together? \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-for-kids/k-pop-culture-containers-and-why-asias-where-the-action-is\"\u003eA deep dive for young people into global trade\u003c/a\u003e. We go back to ancient Mesopotamia, through the Industrial Revolution, and onto container ships to explain why and how the socks on your floor, the songs on your playlist, and the food in your lunch box come from all over the world.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOur third \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks\"\u003eAuthor Talks\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e features Azeem Azhar, creator of the \u003c/em\u003eExponential View\u003cem\u003e newsletter, on his new book, \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-azeem-azhar-on-closing-the-exponential-gap\"\u003eThe Exponential Age: How Accelerating Technology Is Transforming Business, Politics and Society\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e (Diversion Books, September 2021), which in the United Kingdom is titled \u003c/em\u003eExponential: How to Bridge the Gap Between Technology and Society\u003cem\u003e (Random House Business, September 2021). Azhar hopes the book will serve as a road map for how societies can deal with the effects of AI, automation, and big data.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Katy McLaughlin, a senior editor in the Southern California office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #79, November 3, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eEndemic COVID-19 is one more problem we\u0026rsquo;ll have to live with.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWe can still \u003c/strong\u003edream about putting the COVID-19 genie back in the bottle, but the more likely reality is that the virus will become an endemic problem we just have to get used to. Climate change is similar in some ways: a difficulty we have to plan for, deal with, and overcome every day. This week, McKinsey proposes multiple approaches to these and other ongoing struggles.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSoon, the daily risks we run with COVID-19 may seem as much a part of normal daily life as the risks we run when we drive or navigate flu season. \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/pandemic-to-endemic-how-the-world-can-learn-to-live-with-covid-19\"\u003eA complete approach to managing endemic COVID-19\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;first requires society to reach a consensus on what is an acceptable disease burden. We will then need a comprehensive approach to track progress against this standard, define new disease-management protocols to limit deaths, and establish practices to slow transmission.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUnderscoring how the virus is morphing into an endemic concern, our latest report on \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-coronavirus-effect-on-global-economic-sentiment\"\u003ethe coronavirus effect on global economic sentiment\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;revealed that uncertainty over COVID-19 is no longer executives\u0026rsquo; foremost economic worry. Instead, they perceive the mounting fallout on the supply chain and inflation as the biggest threats to growth in their companies and economies.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/aligning-portfolios-with-climate-goals-a-new-approach-for-financial-institutions\"\u003ePortfolio-alignment tools are computational models the financial sector can use to set climate targets\u003c/a\u003e and measure progress. These tools use forward-looking climate scenarios to estimate the division of the global carbon budget by sector and geography. This allows financial institutions the freedom to extend financing to heavy emitters, provided that the financing goes toward the responsible retirement or decarbonization of emitting assets and that decarbonization or retirement is successfully achieved. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/innovating-to-net-zero-an-executives-guide-to-climate-technology\"\u003eAdvanced technologies critical to stopping climate change\u003c/a\u003e that are already mature could deliver about 60 percent of the emissions abatement needed by 2050. But further abatement must come from climate technologies that aren\u0026rsquo;t quite ready. Our estimates suggest that next-generation technologies could attract $1.5 trillion to $2 trillion of capital investment per year by 2025. Established companies, start-ups, and investors will need a nuanced understanding of technical advances, customer demands, and policy environments.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCarbon markets have become increasingly fundamental to achieving net-zero greenhouse-gas emissions. A joint paper by McKinsey and research partners in Singapore discusses the rapid emergence of carbon markets as a viable asset class. \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/putting-carbon-markets-to-work-on-the-path-to-net-zero\"\u003eInstitutional investors could help corporations and nations use carbon markets\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to achieve global climate goals while also fulfilling their own mandates.  \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf Africa can use its large renewable-energy-generation capacity and rich natural capital endowments strategically, it could catalyze economic growth and make a substantial contribution to the global net-zero transition. \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/green-africa-a-growth-and-resilience-agenda-for-the-continent\"\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s \u003cem\u003eGreen Africa \u003c/em\u003ereport\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;highlights ten opportunities that could deliver growth, boost resilience, and abate emissions on the continent.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are some of this week\u0026rsquo;s other key findings from our research: \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eGlobal ambition, significant funding, the scale and pace of reforms, the talent supply, and the healthcare opportunity are galvanizing \u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/the-dawn-of-china-biopharma-innovation\"\u003ea new era of biopharmaceutical innovation in China\u003c/a\u003e. The country\u0026rsquo;s emergence as a new source of innovation is good news for a global biopharma industry facing intense pressure on R\u0026amp;D productivity. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/future-of-asia/asias-consumers-on-the-move-the-future-of-mobility\"\u003eMobility value pools across Asia are expected to grow\u003c/a\u003e while new patterns of consumption will transform opportunities in the region. Consumers may adopt new behaviors such as considering new forms of ownership, increasing eco-consciousness, and changing brand preferences. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eFeeling peckish? You\u0026rsquo;re in good company. This episode of the \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-consumer-and-retail-podcast\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eMcKinsey on Consumer and Retail\u003c/em\u003e podcast\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e features \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/everyone-snacks-how-mars-wrigley-is-pursuing-growth-in-emerging-markets\"\u003eBlas Maquivar, president of global emerging markets at Mars Wrigley\u003c/a\u003e. The executive describes the snacking habits of various nations and digital strategies that let consumers print their own pictures on M\u0026amp;M candies.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOur \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks\"\u003eAuthor Talks\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;series features former McKinsey consultant David McCloskey on his debut novel, \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-david-mccloskey-explores-the-world-of-espionage\"\u003eDamascus Station\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e (W. W. Norton \u0026amp; Company, October 2021). The novel was inspired by the author\u0026rsquo;s pre-McKinsey career as an analyst with the CIA, when he worked in field stations across the Middle East and focused on Iraq, Lebanon, and Syria, and counterterrorism issues.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eAlso in\u003c/em\u003e Author Talks\u003cem\u003e,  Paul Polman, the cofounder and chair of IMAGINE and former CEO of Unilever, discusses his book \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-paul-polman-on-business-as-a-force-for-good\"\u003eNet Positive: How Courageous Companies Thrive by Giving More Than They Take\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e (Harvard Business Review Press, October 2021). Leadership and systems changes are needed so that businesses can focus on being successful by solving the world\u0026rsquo;s problems.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Katy McLaughlin, a senior editor in the Southern California office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #78, October 27, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eHow can the world deliver growth \u003cem\u003eand \u003c/em\u003esustainability \u003cem\u003eand \u003c/em\u003einclusion?\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMcKinsey routinely highlights\u003c/strong\u003e near-term obstacles that affect the organizations we serve, as in this week\u0026rsquo;s collection of articles about a distressing aftershock of the COVID-19 pandemic: inflation. But this week, we also offer an expansive reflection by McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s leadership on a vision for the future.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHow do we go about building \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/our-future-lives-and-livelihoods-sustainable-and-inclusive-and-growing\"\u003ea future that delivers growth, sustainability, and inclusion\u003c/a\u003e? McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s global managing partner Bob Sternfels and colleagues Tracy Francis, Anu Madgavkar, and Sven Smit deliver a proposal for how changemakers in business, government, and society can forge such a path. First and foremost, the three goals cannot be viewed as trade-offs but rather as fundamentals that strengthen and reinforce one another.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMcKinsey recently examined inflation from several angles. The COVID-19 pandemic has driven radical shifts in demand, buying patterns, and perceived value across value chains, which in turn have led to sharp spikes in commodity prices. While procurement teams should continue efforts to fight material-cost increases and creatively reduce sourcing costs, \u003ca href=\"/industries/industrials-and-electronics/our-insights/winning-the-race-with-inflation-the-pricing-opportunity-for-industrial-companies\"\u003eadjusting prices is essential in today\u0026rsquo;s inflationary environment\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to improve margin position and align the prices of a wide range of industrial goods with their value to customers. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePandemic price spikes and commodity cost increases are concerns for many business leaders, but \u003ca href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/pandemic-price-spikes-what-cfos-next-move-thomas-kolaja-he-him-/\"\u003efor CFOs, inflation and its repercussions are calls to action\u003c/a\u003e. To get clarity on how price increases have affected their profit-and-loss statements, CFOs first have to ask the right questions about market dynamics, financial performance, and leadership incentives. Swift action to mitigate the effects of price spikes is often essential because it takes time for benefits to materialize.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAfter a decade of defense-spending growth, \u003ca href=\"/industries/aerospace-and-defense/our-insights/defense-affordability-its-time-for-a-new-approach\"\u003ethe budget for the US Department of Defense could flatten and not keep pace with inflation\u003c/a\u003e. The budget isn\u0026rsquo;t the only thing that is changing. Defense leaders have renewed interest in adopting innovative technologies, such as quantum computing, artificial intelligence, and hypersonic weapons. Balancing the budget will require a new cost-reduction approach that sets market-backed targets across all areas. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBathroom tissue may not be a glamorous topic, but it\u0026rsquo;s an effective bellwether of consumer sentiment, as panic buying during the outset of the pandemic illustrated. Today, \u003ca href=\"/industries/packaging-and-paper/our-insights/beyond-covid-19-the-new-consumer-behavior-is-sticking-in-the-tissue-industry\"\u003ethe five trends shaping the global tissue industry\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;point to larger consumer themes, including the need to be e-commerce ready and sustainable. Rising inflation is expected to fuel demand for private-label and lower-cost products. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are some of this week\u0026rsquo;s other key findings from our research:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThe number of public-company listings in the United States peaked in the mid-1990s, at nearly 6,000, but has fallen by about half over the past 20 years. While pundits worry, our analysis shows that \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/reports-of-corporates-demise-have-been-greatly-exaggerated\"\u003ereports of corporates\u0026rsquo; demise have been greatly exaggerated\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eAs businesses emerge from the pandemic, more than 80 percent face critical skills gaps. In these new circumstances, we believe \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/reviving-the-art-of-apprenticeship-to-unlock-continuous-skill-development\"\u003ethe age-old art of apprenticeship\u003c/a\u003e can be central to an organization\u0026rsquo;s strategy for improving capabilities.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eDwindling supplies of fresh water pose a material business risk: one estimate shows that the lack of clean fresh water threatens some $425 billion of value across more than 500 companies. \u003ca href=\"/industries/electric-power-and-natural-gas/our-insights/managing-water-and-climate-risk-with-renewable-energy\"\u003eNew analysis shows how companies can reduce water risk\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;by targeting renewable-energy purchases and investments.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eIt\u0026rsquo;s not for goofing off; it\u0026rsquo;s for sharpening your problem-solving skills. What nine-letter word are we searching for? \u0026ldquo;Crossword,\u0026rdquo; of course\u0026mdash;as in \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/the-mckinsey-crossword/october-26-2021\"\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s weekly crossword\u003c/a\u003e. Each puzzle is created with the McKinsey reader in mind and includes a business theme (of varying degrees of subtlety) for you to noodle over.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Katy McLaughlin, a senior editor in the Southern California office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #77, October 20, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eWithin regional stories lie universal postpandemic themes.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThis week, \u003c/strong\u003eMcKinsey experts examined the Asian postpandemic economy and looked into other regional issues including trends reshaping Europe\u0026rsquo;s power markets, how the United States can decarbonize its power system by 2035, and Germany\u0026rsquo;s journey toward net zero. Within these deep dives in specific regions are global lessons, including the need to massively accelerate renewable energy generation and to truly understand the digital-native consumer.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTwo years since McKinsey labeled this \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/future-of-asia/topics/the-asian-century\"\u003ethe Asian century\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and in the wake of the extraordinary shock of COVID-19, the region is exhibiting remarkable resilience. The Asian economy contracted by 1.5 percent in 2020, while the world economy shrank by 3.2 percent; Asia is expected to rebound faster both this year and next. \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/asia-pacific/five-windows-of-opportunity-for-postpandemic-asia\"\u003eWindows of opportunity for Asia\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;include leveraging regional trade networks, boosting growth through innovation and productivity, putting climate change at the top of the corporate and policy agenda, and serving a changing consumer sector.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/electric-power-and-natural-gas/our-insights/five-trends-reshaping-european-power-markets\"\u003eEuropean power markets\u003c/a\u003e have entered a period of unprecedented change. Power prices have risen to about four times the historical average in a number of European countries. More uncertainty lies ahead: electricity demand is expected to increase steadily in Europe, due in part to electrification of transport. A future energy system dominated by intermittent renewable power raises questions about total-capacity rollout. When utilities and large power buyers face such question marks, strategic risk management becomes a matter of survival.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn April 2021, the United States set a target to create a \u0026ldquo;carbon pollution-free power sector by 2035.\u0026rdquo; \u003ca href=\"/industries/electric-power-and-natural-gas/our-insights/net-zero-by-2035-a-pathway-to-rapidly-decarbonize-the-us-power-system\"\u003eMcKinsey experts present a potential \u0026ldquo;zero-by-35\u0026rdquo; decarbonization scenario for the United States\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in which each regional power market would reach net-zero greenhouse-gas emissions without offsets from other sectors.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/net-zero-germany-chances-and-challenges-on-the-path-to-climate-neutrality-by-2045\"\u003eAchieving climate neutrality by 2045 is feasible for Germany\u003c/a\u003e, though daunting. Our research shows that the transformation to net-zero emissions can be achieved at net-zero cost for society as a whole, delivering a favorable business case for Germany and a leap to a new technological age. Germany has to tackle key challenges in the five most emissions-intensive sectors: energy, industry, transportation, buildings, and agriculture.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are some of this week\u0026rsquo;s other key findings from our research:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eTraditionally, earnings per share is viewed as a major driver of returns to shareholders. But our historical and updated analyses point to \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/which-metrics-really-drive-total-returns-to-shareholders\"\u003eeconomic profit as a better indicator\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of corporate performance. McKinsey experts explain why investors should examine a company\u0026rsquo;s total profit after the cost of capital is subtracted.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eCOVID-19 forced colleges and universities worldwide into online education. \u003ca href=\"/industries/education/our-insights/setting-a-new-bar-for-online-higher-education\"\u003eMcKinsey identified the best online higher-education practices\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;by surveying academic research as well as the reported practices of more than 30 institutions, and by conducting ethnographic market research. Vital building blocks include creating a seamless journey for students (single sign-on is key), adopting an engaging approach to teaching, and facilitating interpersonal connections.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/semiconductors/our-insights/value-creation-how-can-the-semiconductor-industry-keep-outperforming\"\u003eShareholders in semiconductor companies\u003c/a\u003e have seen high double-digit returns throughout the pandemic, despite supply-chain issues and growing divergence in global trade. To keep the momentum going, semiconductor players might want to consider focusing on gaining leadership in profitable segments by leveraging M\u0026amp;A and partnerships, building agility, and pursuing new technologies and innovations. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eCOVID-19 has been hard on fashion: apparel companies lost more than 90 percent of their profits in 2020, according to the \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/state-of-fashion-archive\"\u003eMcKinsey Global Fashion Index\u003c/a\u003e. \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/jumpstarting-value-creation-with-data-and-analytics-in-fashion-and-luxury\"\u003eData will be the key for the fashion industry\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to unlock the insights needed to reengage customers in the coming months and years.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOur \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks\"\u003eAuthor Talks\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e series features Emory University law professor Dorothy A. Brown, a nationally recognized scholar on race, class, and tax policy, about her latest book, \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-dorothy-a-brown-on-the-whiteness-of-wealth\"\u003eThe Whiteness of Wealth: How the Tax System Impoverishes Black Americans\u0026mdash;and How We Can Fix It\u003c/a\u003e \u003cem\u003e(Crown, March 2021). US tax policy often favors behaviors and activities more common among White households, putting Black taxpayers at a disadvantage.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Katy McLaughlin, a senior editor in the Southern California office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #76, October 13, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eThe drama of COVID-19 has cast leaders in new roles.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAll the world\u0026rsquo;s a stage,\u003c/strong\u003e but the COVID-19 pandemic has rewritten the script. Executives are now asked to play different parts. This week, McKinsey looked at the morphing demands on CFOs and asset managers, and at how C-suite leaders across industries must understand and embrace digitally enabled strategies and business models.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/mastering-change-the-new-cfo-mandate\"\u003eThe job of CFO\u003c/a\u003e has been transformed by the pandemic, according to the latest \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-global-surveys\"\u003eMcKinsey Global Survey\u003c/a\u003e. Crisis management, social and environmental issues, and the accelerated adoption of technology are occupying time previously devoted to strategic leadership and finance capabilities. Between 2016 and 2021, the share of finance leaders who say that they are responsible for their companies\u0026rsquo; digital activities has more than tripled. Procurement, board engagement, and investor relations are also newly important focuses for CFOs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe\u0026rsquo;re all tech executives now, to some extent. Across industries, \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/strategy-for-a-digital-world\"\u003ecompetitive differentiation today emerges from superior digital capabilities\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and technology endowment, more agile delivery, and a progressively more tech-savvy C-suite. To better understand \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/unlocking-the-banking-technology-workforce\"\u003ehow leading banks achieve more with their technology budget\u003c/a\u003e, we looked at how their workforce is configured, on three dimensions: spending, roles, and talent. Banks that have reconfigured all three have achieved a significant uptick in output from their technology budgets. \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/the-digital-future-of-manufacturing-consumer-packaged-goods\"\u003eConsumer-packaged-goods (CPG) manufacturers must leverage digital\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and analytical capability to accelerate productivity. CPG companies must also unravel the conundrum of e-commerce, which offers a growth channel but not necessarily a profitable one. On the \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-consumer-and-retail-podcast\"\u003eMcKinsey on Consumer and Retail\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e podcast, McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Lidiya Chapple and Tatiana Sivaeva explain \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/how-cpg-companies-can-sell-online-profitably\"\u003ehow CPG companies can profitably meet online consumers\u0026rsquo; needs\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/crossing-the-horizon-north-american-asset-management-in-the-2020s\"\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s annual report on North American asset managers\u003c/a\u003e, whose industry profits reached close to $73 billion in 2020, highlights ways in which the industry\u0026rsquo;s role is changing. Investors increasingly want their asset managers to expose them to opportunities outside of traditional asset classes and industry sectors. Asset managers are getting more help from technology-enabled mass customization, which can broaden access to value propositions that have typically been the preserve of institutional and high-net-worth investors.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are some of this week\u0026rsquo;s other key findings from our research:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eCultivated meat is a cutting-edge food that is just beginning to be produced at commercial levels. In a \u003ca href=\"/industries/agriculture/our-insights/exploring-cultivated-meat\"\u003eseries of videos and articles about cultivated meat\u003c/a\u003e, McKinsey and industry experts offer insights into what it is, how it is made, and how it can scale to become a global industry. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/global-economics-intelligence-executive-summary-september-2021\"\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Global Economics Intelligence executive summary for September\u003c/a\u003e revealed that rapid growth and strong demand are bumping against pandemic-related disruptions. Energy prices have surged, but long-term inflation expectations remain moderate.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/how-affordable-is-mental-healthcare-the-long-term-impact-on-financial-health\"\u003ePeople with mental illness report higher levels of financial distress\u003c/a\u003e. Their lower sense of financial security underscores the importance of holistic care for behavioral health\u0026mdash;not just treating mental illness symptoms but considering the broader needs an individual with mental illness may have.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eA corporate spin-off can liberate a parent company and a divested business unit from capital and bureaucratic constraints, so they can pursue strategies they couldn\u0026rsquo;t otherwise. Our \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/achieving-win-win-spin-offs\"\u003eanalysis of more than 200 US spin-offs\u003c/a\u003e, as well as our experience in the field, point to four critical factors.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOur \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks\"\u003eAuthor Talks\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e  series features Indra Nooyi, former chairman and CEO of PepsiCo, about her new book \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-indra-nooyi-on-leadership-life-and-crafting-a-better-future\"\u003e\u0026ldquo;My Life in Full: Work, Family, and Our Future\u0026rdquo;\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e (Penguin Random House, September 2021). Reflecting on her own experience, the first woman of color and immigrant to run a Fortune 50 company argues that winning the war for talent requires creating a new system in which women can both manage their families and climb to the top at work.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Katy McLaughlin, a senior editor in the Southern California office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #75, October 6, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eSome problems are relentless and call for an unrelenting response. \u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAs the COVID-19 crisis \u003c/strong\u003edrags on, executives, particularly in developed economies, are feeling worse about the state of the economy and their own companies\u0026rsquo; prospects. It\u0026rsquo;s natural that a challenge as unremitting as the pandemic should produce alternating hope and despair. This week, McKinsey examined the backslide in executives\u0026rsquo; views, and a variety of similar issues that require problem-solving as dogged as the problems themselves, including vaccine development, transport decarbonization, employee needs, and the extraterrestrial junkyard.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eJust as the rise of the Delta variant ushered in a fresh wave of COVID-19 cases, so it appears to have resuscitated \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/economic-conditions-outlook-2021\"\u003eexecutives\u0026rsquo; worries about the economy\u003c/a\u003e. In our latest \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-global-surveys\"\u003eMcKinsey Global Survey\u003c/a\u003e, 65 percent of respondents say that they expect improvements in their home economies, down from a range of 73 to 79 percent who have said so since March 2021. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBy region, the pandemic is the top risk to growth in every region except Latin America and cited most often by those in developing markets and Asia\u0026ndash;Pacific. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn \u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/accelerating-pandemic-response-efforts-an-interview-with-cepis-richard-hatchett\"\u003ea wide-ranging interview with McKinsey, Richard Hatchett, CEO of the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations\u003c/a\u003e, or CEPI, discusses the work of the largest vaccine-development initiative focused on viruses that are potential epidemic threats. Among other big challenges, there is still work to be done to optimize existing COVID-19 vaccines. CEPI is evaluating mix-and-match dose strategies, where first and second doses could be from different manufacturers, to improve the performance, as well as fractionated, or dose-sparing strategies, to boost coverage.   \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe organization is also examining the optimal intervals between doses and whether two or three doses are required.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/built-to-last-making-sustainability-a-priority-in-transport-infrastructure\"\u003eWhat will it take to move the transport infrastructure industry toward carbon zero\u003c/a\u003e? Globally, more than $2 trillion of transport infrastructure investments will be needed each year until 2040 to fuel economic development. The transport sector is the largest contributor of greenhouse-gas emissions within the European Union, and emissions are still growing. McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s road map lays out changes needed in planning, design, tender, procurement, and operations that can help the industry forge a more sustainable path forward.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhat do workers want?
