Our research is clear: workers are hungry for purpose, to feel their work is valued, and their opportunities are growing, all in a comfortable physical and digital environment with the right work\u0026ndash;life balance. \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/this-time-its-personal-shaping-the-new-possible-through-employee-experience\"\u003eIt is possible to deliver an excellent employee experience\u003c/a\u003e, but organizations may need to profoundly reorient themselves away from a traditional top-down model to one based on the fundamentals of design thinking. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/aerospace-and-defense/our-insights/look-out-below-what-will-happen-to-the-space-debris-in-orbit\"\u003eEven in space, we need to clean up after ourselves\u003c/a\u003e. About 11,000 satellites have been launched since Sputnik 1 in 1957. In the next few years, roughly 70,000 satellites could enter orbit if proposed plans come to fruition\u0026mdash;an explosion of interest based on potential new markets and more sophisticated technologies. Unless actively deorbited, they will remain there for months to hundreds of years. \u003ca href=\"/industries/aerospace-and-defense/how-we-help-clients\"\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Aerospace \u0026amp; Defense Practice\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;examines how to handle the four main types of extraterrestrial trash.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are some of this week\u0026rsquo;s other key findings from our sector research:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eIt\u0026rsquo;s not science fiction; it\u0026rsquo;s the tech-enabled insurance industry of the future. In auto insurance, risk will shift from drivers to the artificial intelligence and software behind self-driving cars. Satellites, drones, and real-time data sets will give insurers unprecedented visibility into risk. As part of our research into the \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/the-top-trends-in-tech-2023\"\u003eten tech trends reshaping industries\u003c/a\u003e, McKinsey explored their impact on insurance and which five are poised to \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/how-top-tech-trends-will-transform-insurance\"\u003ereshape the insurance landscape\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eMcKinsey analyzed \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/lessons-from-the-rapidly-evolving-regulation-of-digital-banking\"\u003eregulatory frameworks around the world for the burgeoning digital banking sector\u003c/a\u003e, examining how various approaches have shaped the development of digital banking.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eOn the \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/inside-the-strategy-room-podcast\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eInside the Strategy Room\u003c/em\u003e podcast\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e, Obi Ezekoye, a leader in the Strategy \u0026amp; Corporate Finance Practice, Anthony Luu, an expert in M\u0026amp;A and strategy transformations, and Andy West, the global coleader of McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s M\u0026amp;A Practice, discuss why \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/agile-business-portfolio-management\"\u003ecompanies struggle to make portfolio decisions, especially on the divestment side\u003c/a\u003e, and often make them too late.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOur \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks\"\u003eAuthor Talks\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e series features Parag Khanna, founder and managing partner of FutureMap, speaking about his book \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-parag-khanna-on-the-forces-creating-a-new-geography-of-opportunity\"\u003eMove: The Forces Uprooting Us\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e (Simon \u0026amp; Schuster, October 2021). The globalization scholar discusses the migration patterns he expects will occur over the next ten to 30 years and how societies should prepare.\n\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Katy McLaughlin, a senior editor in the Southern California office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #74, September 29, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eTo address vaccine hesitancy, first comprehend it.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe first step\u003c/strong\u003e to solving a problem is to understand it. That\u0026rsquo;s one of the keys to getting at least some unvaccinated Americans to take action. This week, McKinsey examined vaccine hesitancy and identified some of the reasons for resistance, which, once removed, could help build a bridge to herd immunity. McKinsey experts used this same problem-defining approach to examine how to improve women\u0026rsquo;s work lives, reduce methane emissions, make organizational transformations more effective, and drive revenue in meal delivery.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMore than 63 percent of the US population have received at least one dose of a COVID-19 vaccine, and more than 54 percent have been fully vaccinated, as of September 16, 2021. \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/whos-left-engaging-the-remaining-hesitant-consumers-on-covid-19-vaccine-adoption\"\u003eA minimum of roughly 80 million additional individuals would still need to be vaccinated in the next few months\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;for the country to have a chance at reaching herd immunity. Among the unvaccinated, 14 percent are \u0026ldquo;Unlikely adopters,\u0026rdquo; who may never take the shot, while 7 percent are \u0026ldquo;Interested,\u0026rdquo; meaning that they plan on getting the vaccine. The most dynamic unvaccinated group is the \u0026ldquo;Cautious\u0026rdquo; category, people who may get vaccinated if their concerns can be addressed. Aiding in scheduling appointments, as well as addressing worries about long-term side effects, could help move this group into the vaccinated category.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/women-in-the-workplace-archive\"\u003eMcKinsey and LeanIn.Org\u0026rsquo;s Women in the Workplace study\u003c/a\u003e reflects experiences from 423 participating organizations and more than 65,000 survey respondents. In spite of the challenges of the COVID-19 pandemic and its effect on the workplace, women\u0026rsquo;s representation has improved across the corporate pipeline since 2016, but there are also persistent gaps. Women of color continue to lose ground at every step: between the entry level and the C-suite, their representation drops off by more than 75 percent. In the past year, one in three women has considered leaving the workforce or downshifting their career\u0026mdash;a significant increase from one in four in the first few months of the pandemic. Companies need to take bold steps to address burnout and to recognize and reward the women leaders who are driving progress. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/curbing-methane-emissions-how-five-industries-can-counter-a-major-climate-threat\"\u003eCurbing emissions of methane\u003c/a\u003e from agriculture, oil and gas, coal mining, solid-waste management, and wastewater management will be critical to solving the net-zero equation. New McKinsey research shows that these five industries could achieve a 20 percent reduction in global annual methane emissions by 2030 and a 46 percent reduction by 2050\u0026mdash;enough for a significant shift toward a 1.5\u0026deg;C warming pathway. McKinsey proposes three \u0026ldquo;no regrets\u0026rdquo; actions to begin reducing methane emissions now.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs leaders steer organizations out of the COVID-19 pandemic, many are recognizing the need for transformation. The question is, \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/transformation/our-insights/how-many-people-are-really-needed-in-a-transformation\"\u003ehow many people must be involved in a transformation for it to be effective\u003c/a\u003e? McKinsey analyzed data from 60 organizations that are at least two years into their transformations and discovered the bare minimum: at least 7 percent of employees should own some part of the change project. That may seem low, but the average company involves only 2 percent of its employees.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/our-insights/ordering-in-the-rapid-evolution-of-food-delivery\"\u003eFood delivery has become a global market worth more than $150 billion\u003c/a\u003e, having more than tripled since 2017. McKinsey identifies the most promising revenue models, which include \u0026ldquo;dark kitchens,\u0026rdquo; customer-specific menu engineering, and brand spin-offs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are some of this week\u0026rsquo;s other key findings from our sector research:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eIncreasingly, private-equity (PE) firms are closely managing the companies they own. To run these portfolio companies, they are choosing CEOs who understand the higher metabolic rate that PE requires. McKinsey, along with top PE executives, created a \u003ca href=\"/industries/private-capital/our-insights/a-playbook-for-newly-minted-private-equity-portfolio-company-ceos\"\u003eplaybook for newcomers to the role of portfolio-company CEO\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that provides insight, guidance, and a series of steps to take control of this demanding leadership challenge.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/a-turning-point-for-us-auto-dealers-the-unstoppable-electric-car\"\u003eIt\u0026rsquo;s time for US auto dealerships to prepare for an electric-vehicle (EV) future\u003c/a\u003e. Everyone from sales staff to maintenance workers will need training to work with this technology. McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s confidence in the segment comes from impressive sales numbers, despite the COVID-19 pandemic: Europe and China achieved fourth-quarter 2020 sales increases of 60 percent and 80 percent, respectively, over the previous quarter. In the United States, EV sales increased nearly 200 percent between the second quarter 2020 and the second quarter 2021.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eEven the most seasoned professional was a neophyte at some point, a fact celebrated in our \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/my-rookie-moment\"\u003eMy Rookie Moment\u003c/a\u003e \u003cem\u003evideo series, in which McKinsey colleagues discuss the first time they had to deal with a particular challenge. This edition features stories about the nerve-racking process of giving a colleague tough feedback for the first time, and the humbling experience of receiving it. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Katy McLaughlin, a senior editor in the Southern California office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #73, September 22, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eCOVID-19 vaccines demonstrate how to achieve the impossible. \u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eVaccination rates,\u003c/strong\u003e vaccine hesitancy, herd immunity\u0026mdash;these have become topics that occupy our everyday thoughts. It can be jarring to remember that less than a year ago, nobody, outside of clinical-trial volunteers, could get a shot at all. How the world got from there to here in record time is the story of achieving an impossible goal. This week, McKinsey explored how Pfizer\u0026rsquo;s leadership team took on a challenge that they initially believed was undoable. We also examined other difficult feats, including delivering sustainable infrastructure, making electric vehicles (EVs) profitable, and adapting to climate change, and contemplated steps to achieving them.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you want to leave the meeting room, first make a decision. That was one of the systems Pfizer developed to advance its apparently impossible agenda of distributing a vaccine in eight months, said \u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/pfizers-mix-of-science-and-grit-alters-the-course-of-its-covid-19-response\"\u003eAngela Hwang, Pfizer\u0026rsquo;s head of biopharmaceuticals, in an interview with McKinsey senior partner David Quigley\u003c/a\u003e. This interview is part of \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-vaccines-progress\"\u003eCOVID-19 vaccines: The road to recovery and beyond\u003c/a\u003e, a series that includes a broad array of voices leading the historic global effort to develop, distribute, and provide equitable access to COVID-19 vaccines, including the Africa CDC; CEPI; Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance; and Moderna.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs illustrated by our \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts/covid-19-hospitalizations-where-we-are-now\"\u003e\u0026ldquo;chart of the day,\u0026rdquo;\u003c/a\u003e vaccination has helped countries dramatically reduce the rate of hospitalization due to COVID-19, among other benefits. Now Pfizer is focusing on the next big vaccine challenges, including shots for younger kids, heartier formulations, and doses that can manage new variants.  \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe September edition of \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.globalinfrastructureinitiative.com/voices/september-2021\"\u003eVoices on Infrastructure\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e features four articles that explore how leaders are tackling the seemingly insurmountable task of building sustainable infrastructure and retrofitting existing assets. \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/accelerating-sustainable-infrastructure-an-investors-perspective\"\u003eIn an interview, Sadek Wahba, chairman and managing partner of I Squared Capital\u003c/a\u003e, discusses some of the most exciting investment cases for sustainable infrastructure, including floating solar and floating wind turbines, as well as offshore wind. \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/delivering-sustainable-infrastructure-insights-from-industry-leaders\"\u003eLara Poloni, president of AECOM, and Nick Smallwood, CEO of IPA\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and head of the UK government\u0026rsquo;s Project Delivery Function, identify top concerns for the construction industry. These include prioritizing whole-life carbon measurement and scaling up the capacity to retrofit existing social infrastructure and housing to improve energy efficiency. Densely packed urban residents are particularly vulnerable to the effects of climate change. McKinsey Sustainability and C40 Cities\u0026mdash;a network of 97 global cities dedicated to addressing climate change\u0026mdash;offer \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/ensuring-adaptation-and-resilience-to-climate-change\"\u003ea starting set of 15 high-potential actions for cities to consider\u003c/a\u003e. Finally, solving problems requires first understanding them completely. Help us develop a consistent set of sustainability metrics by answering \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/action-needed-help-us-measure-project-sustainability\"\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s full asset-life-cycle survey\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDespite growing sales, EV profitability is only slightly above breakeven for many auto makers. McKinsey research is clear that the \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/why-the-automotive-future-is-electric\"\u003eautomotive future is electric\u003c/a\u003e, so figuring out how to make it profitable is essential to both OEMs\u0026rsquo; business models and the decarbonization of the transportation system. \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/electrifying-the-bottom-line-how-oems-can-boost-ev-profitability\"\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s in-depth report explores how OEMs can boost EV profitability\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are some of this week\u0026rsquo;s other key findings from our sector research:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/fast-forward-how-cloud-computing-could-transform-risk-management\"\u003eCloud-based computing will provide tangible benefits for banking risk management\u003c/a\u003e, but leaders face significant challenges migrating their systems and activities from on-premises to the cloud. McKinsey proposes three key actions to help guide the cloud adoption journey. Our \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/cloud-cost-optimization-simulator\"\u003ecloud cost-optimization simulator\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;illustrates the potential financial impact of a migration.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eData, properly protected and used, can simplify delivery of public services, reduce fraud and human error, and catalyze massive operational efficiencies. McKinsey suggests \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/government-data-management-for-the-digital-age\"\u003efive actions governments can take to transition to an efficient and effective data landscape\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eAs a share of GDP, industrial manufacturing in the United States has been falling for decades. But \u003ca href=\"/industries/industrials-and-electronics/our-insights/manufacturing-process-innovation-for-industrials\"\u003esmaller industrial businesses have the opportunity to improve manufacturing processes and grow\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;amid a shift toward end-to-end market demand.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOur \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks\"\u003eAuthor Talks\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e series features Ella Bell Smith, a professor of management at the Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth College. She discusses her re-released book, \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-ella-bell-smith-on-why-race-and-class-are-wedges-between-women\"\u003eOur Separate Ways, With a New Preface and Epilogue: Black and White Women and the Struggle for Professional Identity\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e (Harvard Business Review Press, August 2021). She makes a case for why companies need to spend more on developing Black women to take on senior roles and why women in general should seek out revenue-generating positions. Even the most seasoned professional was a neophyte at some point, a fact celebrated in our \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/my-rookie-moment\"\u003eMy Rookie Moment\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003evideo series, in which McKinsey colleagues discuss the first time they had deal with a particular challenge. The latest edition features stories about the nerve-wracking process of giving a colleague tough feedback for the first time, and the humbling experience of receiving it.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Katy McLaughlin, a senior editor in the Southern California office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #72, September 15, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eTo reach the post-COVID-19 era, vaccine supply chains must improve.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eNine months since\u003c/strong\u003e the first COVID-19 mass vaccination program began, only 1.4 percent of people in low-income countries have received at least one dose. The problem is not just of procurement, but also of distribution and the lack of strong cold-chain infrastructure in some parts of the world. Solving these problems is the only way to get from where we are now to the post-COVID-19 era. Once the vaccination challenge\u0026mdash;and the pandemic itself\u0026mdash;has been overcome, CEOs will face a new set of priorities, which our experts defined this week. We also explored mindsets and skills, including automating, partnering, and developing and supporting diverse talent, that will be crucial for future leaders.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEach of the COVID-19 vaccines has a different profile, but they all have one thing in common: \u003ca href=\"/industries/social-sector/our-insights/port-to-patient-improving-country-cold-chains-for-covid-19-vaccines\"\u003ethe need for cold-chain vaccine storage\u003c/a\u003e. Broadly speaking, developing countries have less mature cold-chain systems than do high-income economies, with various degrees of maturity within them. Procuring vaccines will not be enough to vaccinate the world: cold-chain systems need investment and improvement to get doses into arms effectively. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs promised last week, McKinsey senior partner Homayoun Hatami and global leader Liz Hilton Segel offer an\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/what-matters-most-five-priorities-for-ceos-in-the-next-normal\"\u003e information-packed interactive examining the five priorities of CEOs in the new normal\u003c/a\u003e. To prepare for the post-COVID-19 era, leaders need to do more than fine-tune their day-to-day tasks; they need to be ready and willing to rethink how they operate, and even why they exist. In the future, CEOs must be proactive on sustainability, know how to derive value from cloud computing, focus on cultivating talent, design organizations for speed, and communicate purpose across their organizations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEnergy companies face societal pressure and increased regulation to significantly reduce fossil-fuel dependency. Leaders in the sector should consider a promising solution: \u003ca href=\"/industries/oil-and-gas/our-insights/the-autonomous-plant-entering-a-new-digital-era\"\u003eautonomous plants\u003c/a\u003e. Such future plants link technology, data, and advanced visualizations with operations to ensure that assets learn from each action taken, as well as from historical data and derived insights. These plants progressively improve their operations over time to run with a lower carbon footprint as well as more safely and profitably.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo improve the track record of \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/a-smarter-way-to-think-about-public-private-partnerships\"\u003epublic\u0026ndash;private partnerships\u003c/a\u003e, government policy makers can align with the private sector to better manage the risks of undertaking a large project. Transferring specific project risks and responsibilities\u0026mdash;including development, construction, and operation\u0026mdash;to private-sector investors and lenders leverages the risk-management capabilities of the private sector, while the public sector often remains the project\u0026rsquo;s legal owner.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUS business leaders face a moral and economic imperative at the societal level: to \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/innovating-employee-health-time-to-break-the-mold\"\u003emake employer-sponsored healthcare work better for America\u0026rsquo;s workers\u003c/a\u003e. Poor health costs the US economy about $3.2 trillion annually from premature deaths and lost productivity. Compared with high-income peer countries, the United States has a 46 to 50 percent higher disease burden rate for 20- to 40-year-old workers, and a 17 to 33 percent higher disease burden rate for those over 40 years old. Employers can consider a suite of changes to improve employee health and productivity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/metals-and-mining/our-insights/why-women-are-leaving-the-mining-industry-and-what-mining-companies-can-do-about-it\"\u003eHow can mining companies attract and retain more women\u003c/a\u003e workers? A global survey with more than 1,000 respondents examined the diversity problem within mining, where only 8 to 17 percent of the workforce is female, the gender pay gap is large, and the rate of women who ascend from entry level to executive ranks is low. Leaders who want to fix the problem should set parity goals, cultivate potential employees from colleges and even high schools, and create \u0026ldquo;buddy\u0026rdquo; and \u0026ldquo;sponsor\u0026rdquo; programs that provide support.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are some of this week\u0026rsquo;s other key findings from our sector research:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eLike streaming music or driving electric cars, eating cultivated meat\u0026mdash;grown in a bioreactor rather than in an animal\u0026rsquo;s body\u0026mdash;may eventually seem totally normal, says \u003ca href=\"/industries/agriculture/our-insights/rethinking-meat-a-leader-in-the-cultivated-meat-industry-envisions-the-future\"\u003eCEO Josh Tetrick in an interview about his cultivated-meat company, Eat Just, Inc\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eOn the \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.mckinsey.com/business-functions/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/inside-the-strategy-room-podcast\"\u003eInside the Strategy Room\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.mckinsey.com/business-functions/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/inside-the-strategy-room-podcast\"\u003e podcast\u003c/a\u003e, Howard Ungerleider, president and CFO of Dow, describes his role in executing \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-making-of-a-megadeal-howard-ungerleider-on-the-merger-of-dow-and-dupont\"\u003ethe Dow Chemical and DuPont merger\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in 2017 and their subsequent split into three separate companies. The highly complex transaction, which took four years, transformed the chemical industry landscape.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eWhen \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/asia-pacific/steady-state-prioritising-stability-in-a-volatile-market\"\u003eKevin Gallagher, CEO of Santos\u003c/a\u003e, Australia\u0026rsquo;s largest domestic gas supplier, first took the top job in 2016, he realized that the company needed to break its boom-and-bust cycle with a new business model. He divested noncore assets and set a break-even oil price as a consistent metric to generate free cash flow through the cycle. This article explores lessons companies can derive from Santos\u0026rsquo;s successful turnaround.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eEven the most seasoned professional was a neophyte at some point, a fact celebrated in our \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/my-rookie-moment\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/my-rookie-moment\"\u003eMy Rookie Moment\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/my-rookie-moment\"\u003e video series\u003c/a\u003e, in which McKinsey colleagues discuss the first time they had to deal with a particular challenge. This edition features stories about the nerve-racking process of giving a colleague tough feedback for the first time, and the humbling experience of receiving it.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Katy McLaughlin, a senior editor in the Southern California office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #71, September 8, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eWhat will be the top priorities in the next normal?\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs companies and industries plan for life after the COVID-19 pandemic, one of the trickiest tasks will be to identify a new set of priorities. Throughout this crisis, coping and keeping up with the ever-shifting situation have taken precedence. But a contagious virus will not always be the top concern for organizations, and other urgent issues, including sustainability, cloud computing, and competition for talent, will require top-of-mind focus. This week, McKinsey examined how leaders can identify and address what matters most in the postpandemic world.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the wake of COVID-19, a top priority for many companies has been to address talent questions, including how to optimize hybrid teams, attract and retain workers with needed capabilities, and make the most of scarce skills. Forward-looking organizations are choosing \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/the-key-role-of-dynamic-talent-allocation-in-shaping-the-future-of-work\"\u003eflow-to-work operating models\u003c/a\u003e, which create pools of resources that can be deployed flexibly and on demand. These pools are formed based on similarity of skills, rather than similarity of business functions, making it easier for organizations to access the right skills when they need them. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/how-we-help-clients/panorama/our-insights/chart-of-the-month-september-2021\"\u003eWhat is the key to outstanding performance in banking?\u003c/a\u003e According to a recent McKinsey analysis, location is today\u0026rsquo;s biggest factor, accounting for about 65 percent of the standard deviation in price to book. Banks that choose to prioritize location should consider looking for investments and acquisitions that expose them to flourishing markets. In expanding markets, they should consider prioritizing high-demand products and services and profitable customer segments.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo operate efficiently and support their organizations\u0026rsquo; missions, \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/four-imperatives-for-the-next-generation-legal-department\"\u003ecorporate legal departments should focus on four key priorities\u003c/a\u003e: defining their functional purpose clearly, preparing for both a changing legal ecosystem and a new wave of corporate litigation, and competing for talent with law firms and the public sector.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNext week, watch for McKinsey senior partner Homayoun Hatami and global leader Liz Hilton Segel offering a deep dive into the five immediate priorities for CEOs now. Imperatives include centering strategy around sustainability and making the most of the cloud-computing revolution.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are some of this week\u0026rsquo;s other key findings from our sector research:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/private-capital/our-insights/global-it-services-an-often-overlooked-opportunity-for-private-equity\"\u003eIT services companies are often overlooked by private-equity investors but deserve more serious attention\u003c/a\u003e. The $1 trillion per-year global market for IT service providers is projected to grow by more than 6 percent per year in 2021 and 2022, more quickly than global GDP.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/five-traps-to-avoid-the-long-game-of-dtc-and-e-commerce\"\u003eDirect-to-consumer and e-commerce companies need to avoid five common pitfalls\u003c/a\u003e that hamper growth and long-term success. These include deferring focus and investment in operations and channel management and designing technology platforms for short-term goals, such as launches, instead of the long game.   \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/why-the-automotive-future-is-electric\"\u003eThe automotive future is electric\u003c/a\u003e. New regulatory targets in the European Union and the United States now aim for an electric-vehicle (EV) share of at least 50 percent by 2030, and several countries have announced accelerated timelines for sales bans on internal-combustion-engine vehicles in 2030 or 2035. Increasing consumer appetite and improved technology are making EVs ever more popular and viable.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eIn a new edition of our\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks\"\u003eAuthor Talks\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e series, Vanessa Bohns, a professor of organizational behavior at Cornell University, discusses her book, \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-vanessa-bohns-on-our-hidden-potential-to-persuade\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-vanessa-bohns-on-our-hidden-potential-to-persuade\"\u003eYou Have More Influence Than You Think: How We Underestimate Our Power of Persuasion, and Why It Matters\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-vanessa-bohns-on-our-hidden-potential-to-persuade\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;(W. W. Norton, September 2021). People often have more impact on others than they realize, so learning how to use that power can be more important than focusing on acquiring more influence. Our latest edition of \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-for-kids/i-robot-what-technology-shifts-mean-for-tomorrows-jobs\"\u003eMcKinsey for Kids\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e is designed to help 18-year-olds (or so) explore automation and the future of work (heads-up: there could be robots involved). Our \u0026ldquo;find your fit\u0026rdquo; mini quiz suggests a few occupations that a kid might consider.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Katy McLaughlin, a senior editor in the Southern California office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #70, September 1, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eHow high can industries bounce back?\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhile the COVID-19 pandemic\u003c/strong\u003e was unspooling, many in various industries asked themselves, \u0026ldquo;How bad can it get?\u0026rdquo; Now that some recoveries are under way, leaders are increasingly wondering how good, how high, and how long the postcrisis bounce will be. This week, McKinsey examined the global recovery in car sales and discussed with Moderna\u0026rsquo;s chief executive why developing the COVID-19 vaccine may lead to a robust era of drug discovery. Consumer-sector and bank executives, as well as corporate boards, are rethinking approaches to set the stage for successful comebacks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFew industries were hit as hard by the pandemic\u0026rsquo;s arrival as automotive and mobility. Now, our survey of consumers in China, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom, and the United States shows that \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/how-consumers-behavior-in-car-buying-and-mobility-changes-amid-covid-19\"\u003econsumers\u0026rsquo; intent to purchase cars is close to pre-COVID-19 levels\u003c/a\u003e, fueled by positive outlooks in the United States and China. Car dealerships are getting busier, and many are eagerly seeking more inventory to sell. Overall, mobility is picking up steadily.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eModerna was able to develop a COVID-19 vaccine in only 11 months in part because it already had nine vaccines in clinical trials using messenger RNA (mRNA) technology, says CEO St\u0026eacute;phane Bancel. We are now in a world where mRNA as a platform has been derisked for use in vaccines and can be authorized for emergency use. \u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/modernas-path-to-vaccine-innovation-a-talk-with-ceo-stephane-bancel\"\u003eModerna is studying the use of its mRNA platform to help transform the treatment of infectious diseases\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in the next five years.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/understanding-the-ever-evolving-always-surprising-consumer\"\u003eConsumer behavior throughout various phases of the pandemic\u003c/a\u003e surprised even consumer-behavior experts. On the \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-consumer-and-retail-podcast\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eMcKinsey on Consumer and Retail\u003c/em\u003e podcast\u003c/a\u003e, McKinsey partner Kari Alldredge; Anne Grimmelt, a senior knowledge expert in McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Consumer Packaged Goods Practice; and Anjali Lai, a senior analyst at Forrester, discuss being shocked by how much bread baking and pet buying went on during lockdowns and how heartily consumers embraced a return to big brands. Because consumers can\u0026rsquo;t accurately predict their own behavior shifts, companies should get better at mining online data and using advanced analytics to spot trends.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eChanges in technology, markets, and the labor force provoked by the pandemic have \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/boards-talent-and-culture\"\u003ealtered the mandate for many corporate boards\u003c/a\u003e. On the \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/inside-the-strategy-room-podcast\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eInside the Strategy Room\u003c/em\u003e podcast\u003c/a\u003e, McKinsey experts discuss corporate boards that are engaging more deeply on broader questions of talent\u0026mdash;far beyond just who is CEO and how much compensation they get\u0026mdash;and company culture.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/managing-change-on-many-fronts-how-northwestern-mutual-beat-the-odds\"\u003eNorthwestern Mutual\u003c/a\u003e executives were all set to roll out a proprietary financial-planning tool the company wanted its network of independent financial advisers to embrace. Then the pandemic hit. The crisis required pivoting to virtual engagement, which resulted in creating more opportunities for outreach and better uptake and understanding of the tool.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are some of this week\u0026rsquo;s other key findings from our sector research:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eCultivated meat is meat, but it is produced from animal cells that grow in a controlled environment. \u003ca href=\"/industries/agriculture/our-insights/high-stakes-innovation-an-interview-with-a-cultivated-meat-pioneer\"\u003eAn interview with start-up Aleph Farms CEO Didier Toubia\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;examines the potential of this revolutionary technology.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    The materials traditionally used to make consumer and commercial goods account for close to half of global greenhouse-gas emissions. \u003ca href=\"/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/our-insights/common-goods-fighting-materials-impact-on-climate-change\"\u003eJohn Bissell and Rich Riley are co-CEOs of Origin Materials\u003c/a\u003e, which offers a proprietary technology platform to help companies produce their goods with less negative impact. In a wide-ranging interview on the \u003ca href=\"/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/our-insights/mckinsey-on-startups\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eMcKinsey on Start-ups\u003c/em\u003e podcast\u003c/a\u003e, the executives discuss growth plans at a time when more companies are looking for sustainability solutions.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOur new edition of \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-for-kids/i-robot-what-technology-shifts-mean-for-tomorrows-jobs\"\u003eMcKinsey for Kids\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;is designed to help 18-year-olds (or so) explore automation and the future of work (heads-up: there could be robots involved). Our \u0026ldquo;find your fit\u0026rdquo; mini quiz suggests a few occupations that a kid might consider. Our \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks\"\u003eAuthor Talks\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e series features Tiziana Casciaro, professor of organizational behavior at Toronto\u0026rsquo;s Rotman School of Management on the new book she coauthored, \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-power-for-all\"\u003ePower, for All: How It Really Works and Why It\u0026rsquo;s Everyone\u0026rsquo;s Business\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e (Simon \u0026amp; Schuster, August 2021). The book explains why power comes not from rank but from knowing what is valued and how to deliver it. Also on \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks\"\u003eAuthor Talks\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e, global development executive April Rinne talks about her new book, \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-april-rinne-on-finding-calm-and-meaning-in-a-world-of-flux\"\u003eFlux: 8 Superpowers for Thriving in Constant Change\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e (Berrett-Koehler Publishers, August 2021), which explores how individuals and organizations can develop adaptable mindsets. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Katy McLaughlin, a senior editor in the Southern California office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #69, August 25, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eThe Delta variant has moved the goalposts.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSome parts of the world\u003c/strong\u003e felt a surge of optimism in the spring, as vaccination rates were climbing and COVID-19 cases dropping. Those regions now face the disappointment of a reversal, thanks to the spread of the Delta variant. Such whiplash is starting to feel like a way of life for people everywhere, as well as for industries including shipping, retail, and healthcare. This week, McKinsey published updated research examining when the pandemic might end and attempted to estimate when some pandemic-related disruptions could return to what we used to call normal.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAmong high-income countries, cases caused by the Delta variant reversed the transition toward normalcy first in the United Kingdom, during June and July of 2021, and subsequently in the United States and elsewhere. McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s analysis supports the view of others that \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/when-will-the-covid-19-pandemic-end\"\u003ethe Delta variant has effectively moved overall herd immunity out of reach\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in most countries for the time being. The United Kingdom\u0026rsquo;s experience nevertheless suggests that once a country has weathered a wave of Delta-driven cases, it may be able to resume the transition toward normalcy. Beyond that, a more realistic epidemiological endpoint might arrive not when herd immunity is achieved but when COVID-19 can be managed as an endemic disease. The biggest overall risk would likely then be the emergence of a significant new variant.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOne of the most economically pervasive pandemic effects is a boom in shipping costs. \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/whats-going-on-with-shipping-rates\"\u003eIn a video explaining why container shipping prices have surged\u003c/a\u003e, McKinsey partners say that sending a container from Asia to Europe or North America cost roughly $2,000 before the pandemic and $12,000 or more today. Though demand should remain high in the coming months as retailers prepare for the holiday season, prices should begin to come down by the end of the year.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile many of consumers\u0026rsquo; pandemic-inspired digital habits are sticking, the acceleration into digital channels now seems to be leveling off in both Europe and the United States. \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/can-companies-build-on-their-digital-surge\"\u003eCompanies can build on their digital surge\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;by creating strategies based on long-term value, investing aggressively in tech talent, and being smarter about how they work with data.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/increased-workforce-turnover-and-pressures-straining-provider-operations\"\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s July survey of 100 large private-sector US hospitals\u003c/a\u003e revealed that amid returning patient volumes and continuing COVID-19 hospitalizations, challenges in clinical-support staffing remain high. Eighty-four percent of survey respondents report trouble with turnover and vacancies in their nursing staffs. This may only be the start of greater challenges, as \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/nursing-in-2021-retaining-the-healthcare-workforce-when-we-need-it-most\"\u003e22 percent of the nursing workforce reported in our Spring 2021 Future of Work in Nursing Survey\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that they may leave their roles providing direct patient care in the next year.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/survey-us-consumer-sentiment-during-the-coronavirus-crisis\"\u003eUS consumer spending recovered in the second quarter of 2021\u003c/a\u003e, driven by increasing vaccination rates, stimulus payments in March 2021, and the general reopening of the economy. Consumers\u0026rsquo; pent-up demand and willingness to spend in some discretionary categories caused spending to grow at 20 to 30 percent year over year, reaching 4 to 7 percent above pre-COVID-19 levels. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are some of this week\u0026rsquo;s other key findings from our sector research:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/the-future-of-payments-in-the-middle-east\"\u003eThe COVID-19 pandemic has triggered an acceleration of digital-payment adoption in the Middle East\u003c/a\u003e, as it has in other regions. Payments players with the right strategies can capitalize on this revolution in a region that is traditionally heavily dependent on cash.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eAmid increased consolidation, digitization, and specialization in the insurance industry, \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/creating-value-in-us-insurance-investing\"\u003eprivate equity is investing in specialty-insurance carriers and brokers and benefiting from the long-term capital\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;insurance companies provide. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eBetween September and November of 2020 alone, 178,000 women in the United Kingdom lost their jobs. \u003ca href=\"/industries/social-sector/our-insights/helping-unemployed-women-find-work-in-uncertain-times\"\u003eIn an interview with McKinsey, Smart Works CEO Kate Stephens said that the UK charity, which provides support to women who are job hunting\u003c/a\u003e, saw a corresponding 21 percent rise in the number of women seeking its services, many of which are now offered remotely.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOur new edition of \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-for-kids/i-robot-what-technology-shifts-mean-for-tomorrows-jobs\"\u003eMcKinsey for Kids\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e is designed to help 18-year-olds (or so) explore automation and the future of work (heads-up: there could be robots involved). Our \u0026ldquo;find your fit\u0026rdquo; mini quiz suggests a few occupations that a kid might consider. \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/we-still-know-what-you-are-reading-this-summer\"\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s annual reading list is back\u003c/a\u003e, with 100-plus book recommendations shared by more than 40 leaders and personalities. Nonetheless, some of the pandemic\u0026rsquo;s side effects still have the power to surprise. This week, McKinsey looked at a few of these unexpected consequences, including an explosion in the number of online ratings consumers give to products and services, the acceleration of trends reshaping the bank workforce, dramatic changes in Chinese car-buying behavior, and the possible decline of cash as a part of everyday life.\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen lockdowns forced consumers to remain at home, US e-commerce experienced ten years\u0026rsquo; growth during the first quarter of 2020. One less discussed outcome is \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/five-star-growth-using-online-ratings-to-design-better-products\"\u003ethe surge in the volume of online ratings and reviews\u003c/a\u003e\u0026mdash;40 to 80 percent higher during the core pandemic months in 2020 than they had been a year earlier. The old levers of brand equity, greater ad spending, and big promotions are simply less relevant in an age when consumers have access to so much word-of-mouth feedback. Companies, McKinsey suggests, can respond in six ways, such as adopting technological tools to analyze reviews and using consumer feedback to redesign products.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe global banking industry had already been undergoing major changes when the pandemic struck. In the previous decade, branch footprints shrunk by about 20 percent in the United States and by 60 percent in Nordic countries. McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s pre-COVID-19 research suggests that the number of people in almost all bank-branch roles will decline over the next decade. \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/how-banks-can-build-their-future-workforce-today\"\u003eThe global pandemic accelerated these banking-workforce trends\u003c/a\u003e, making it more important for banks to focus now on upskilling and reskilling at scale. Successful players are currently building a scalable learning infrastructure and investing in a learning culture. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOf the huge health challenges created by COVID-19, perhaps the least understood is its impact on global mental health. \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/improving-mental-health-an-interview-with-one-minds-garen-staglin\"\u003eMcKinsey interviewed Garen Staglin, the chair and cofounder of One Mind\u003c/a\u003e, a nonprofit whose mission is to accelerate brain-health research and mental-health advocacy. CEOs and other senior executives need to make a personal commitment to corporate behavioral-health programs if they are to succeed, he says. These leaders should focus on reducing the stigma of mental illness and on cultivating a corporate culture conducive to mental wellness.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/the-race-to-win-how-automakers-can-succeed-in-a-post-pandemic-china\"\u003eChinese consumers have changed their vehicle preferences and car-buying habits\u003c/a\u003e in the wake of COVID-19. McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s most recent survey of approximately 2,400 auto consumers in 19 major Chinese cities shows declining brand loyalty, a marked preference for trading up among consumers with less-expensive vehicles, and a significant increase in the use of digital channels during the vehicle-purchase process. While overall vehicle sales fell in China in 2020, sales of new-energy vehicles (NEVs) grew by an impressive 22 percent. Our survey reveals that 63 percent of Chinese consumers are willing to purchase NEVs, up from 20 percent in 2017.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are some of this week\u0026rsquo;s other key findings from our sector research:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eIn an interview with McKinsey, \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/africas-plan-for-a-continent-wide-pandemic-recovery\"\u003eDr. John Nkengasong, the first director of the Africa CDC\u003c/a\u003e, discusses what it will take to roll out COVID-19 vaccines on a continent-wide scale, to increase vaccine manufacturing within Africa, and to enhance coordination across its borders.\n    These outcomes could help Africa better\n    control its response to COVID-19 and any\n    future infectious diseases. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/chinas-digital-r-and-d-imperative\"\u003eChina\u0026rsquo;s top manufacturers aspire to make innovative products without needing to import core technologies\u003c/a\u003e. To achieve these R\u0026amp;D goals, Chinese companies should allocate more resources to higher-risk, longer-term R\u0026amp;D projects and nurture creative talent by designing career pathways that reward innovation with status and incentives. Companies should also consider splitting R\u0026amp;D into two parts: one focused on innovation, the other on excellence in project execution.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eMcKinsey takes summer reading seriously. Here are some resources to help you find business books that captivate and enlighten: \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eIn \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-gottfried-leibbrandt-on-why-cash-may-be-a-thing-of-the-past\"\u003eThe Pay Off: How Changing the Way We Pay Changes Everything\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e (Elliott \u0026amp; Thompson, July 2021), a new book coauthored with Natasha de Ter\u0026aacute;n, former SWIFT CEO and McKinsey alumnus Gottfried Leibbrandt discusses how the pandemic accelerated the move away from cash. The book analyzes the implications of electronic payments\u0026mdash;already huge in China\u0026mdash;for banks, cryptocurrencies, and society\u0026rsquo;s relationship with money.  \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/we-still-know-what-you-are-reading-this-summer\"\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s annual reading list is back\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e, with 100-plus book recommendations shared by more than 40 leaders and personalities. Death rates may fall to new lows while case counts begin a precipitous climb; hospitalizations may drop dramatically in one region while reaching a breaking point in another. This month, McKinsey had good news to report on many aspects of the world economy, but also offered a sobering look at how variants\u0026mdash;in particular, the Delta variant\u0026mdash;are bringing a fresh tide of bad news.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/global-economics-intelligence-executive-summary-july-2021\"\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Global Economics Intelligence executive summary for July\u003c/a\u003e notes strengthening global industrial activity, the return of consumer demand, and growing trade momentum amid the backdrop of a worsening pandemic wave. The Delta variant of the coronavirus spread to more countries in recent weeks, and the total number of cases officially logged soared past half a million per day. The global number of deaths is now about two-thirds as high as it was at the peak of the previous wave, in April of this year. As the virus spreads, the potential rises for a vaccine-resistant strain to emerge. Meanwhile, in poorer countries, vaccines are scarce, and most populations are little protected.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are some other key findings from our sector research this week:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eMcKinsey estimates that \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/a-300-billion-dollar-opportunity-serving-the-emerging-black-american-consumer\"\u003ecompanies that are focused on underserved Black American consumers could tap into $300 billion of value annually\u003c/a\u003e. In 2019, consumer expenditures by Black households totaled approximately $835 billion; combined spending by all Black households has increased 5 percent annually over the past two decades. Serving the Black consumer well is entirely possible for companies that take the time to figure out the needs of what others may dismiss as a \u0026ldquo;niche\u0026rdquo; audience.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eHistorically, few companies have organizational structures that are designed to treat \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/organizing-for-sustainability-success-where-and-how-leaders-can-start\"\u003esustainability as a material business issue\u003c/a\u003e. Companies that lead in this area often have sustainability teams embedded into business units, funds with tailored criteria allocated to sustainability investments, and sustainability-specific performance metrics.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eOn the \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-consumer-and-retail-podcast\"\u003eMcKinsey on Consumer and Retail\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e podcast, McKinsey partners Sebastian Gatzer and Clarisse Magnin discuss how they assumed the pandemic would distract consumers from sustainability issues. Instead, \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/prioritizing-sustainability-in-the-consumer-sector\"\u003emore consumers globally are saying, \u0026ldquo;I am willing to pay more\u0026rdquo; for sustainable products\u003c/a\u003e. Companies have to make investments and take risks in order to achieve a sustainability-based model, but overall it can pay off economically.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eMcKinsey takes summer reading seriously. Here are resources to help find books that captivate and enlighten:\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eIn their newly released \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/much-anew-about-nudging\"\u003eNudge: The Final Edition\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e, Harvard professor Cass Sunstein and University of Chicago professor Richard Thaler update their 2008 book on interventions aimed at getting people to act in their own best interests. Brexit, trade disputes, and decarbonization were already having a profound impact on many industries and regions. Then the pandemic ushered in an era of shutdowns, hybrid work, and reversals, like the one some regions are experiencing now as variants bring renewed surges in case counts. This week, McKinsey examined the one constant throughout this turbulent era: the need to learn, adapt, and change. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe COVID-19 crisis and subsequent move to hybrid working models accelerated \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/three-keys-to-building-a-more-skilled-postpandemic-workforce\"\u003ethe need for new workforce skills\u003c/a\u003e, particularly social, emotional, and advanced cognitive abilities. Fifty-eight percent of respondents to \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/building-workforce-skills-at-scale-to-thrive-during-and-after-the-covid-19-crisis\"\u003eour recent global survey\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;said that closing skills gaps became a higher priority since the pandemic began. That statistic only hints at the need for retraining: \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/future-of-work/the-future-of-work-after-covid-19\"\u003eresearch\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;from the \u003ca href=\"/mgi/overview\"\u003eMcKinsey Global Institute\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;finds that more than 100 million workers in eight large economies may need to switch occupations by 2030. Companies should make a comprehensive inventory of skills across their organizations, create \u0026ldquo;skills hubs\u0026rdquo; for ongoing learning, and build learning ecosystems through partnerships with communities and educators.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/education/our-insights/how-hbcus-can-accelerate-black-economic-mobility\"\u003eStrengthening more than 100 historically Black colleges and universities\u003c/a\u003e (HBCUs) in the United States could increase Black worker incomes by about $10 billion and boost the economy with $1.2 billion in incremental business profits, $300 million in decreased student-loan debt, and $1 billion in additional consumer expenditures. For some HBCUs, 2020 was their strongest-ever year of fundraising; if this level can be sustained over time, these institutions can continue the critical work they have been doing since 1837.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/future-proof-solving-the-adaptability-paradox-for-the-long-term\"\u003eIn this era of accelerated change, adaptability not only can but must be nurtured\u003c/a\u003e. Developing the adaptability muscle requires self-care, a focus on purpose, the ability to recognize the default mindset, deeper connections with colleagues, and an environment where it is safe to learn. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/government-transformations-in-times-of-extraordinary-change-key-considerations-for-public-sector-leaders\"\u003eLarge-scale government overhauls\u003c/a\u003e are always challenging, but are particularly difficult in times of crisis, when leaders are under pressure to deliver fast results. McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s experience is that dual focus on performance and organizational health leads to the most successful transformations. Two case studies of large US government agencies demonstrate how practices such as setting aspirational goals, creating a transformation office, and accurately assessing progress can lead to meaningful change.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are some other key findings from our sector research this week:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eAccording to the popular \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/our-insights/saas-and-the-rule-of-40-keys-to-the-critical-value-creation-metric\"\u003eRule of 40\u003c/a\u003e\u0026rdquo; metric, a software-as-a-service company\u0026rsquo;s growth rate when added to its free cash flow rate should equal 40 percent or higher. McKinsey research finds that barely one-third of software companies achieve this. Our experts analyze the four main approaches of companies that do and suggest ways to emulate them.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eIn private equity, making an \u0026ldquo;add-on\u0026rdquo; strategy work depends on the successful integration of companies. The pitfalls are many, however, and deals can wither as a result. \u003ca href=\"/industries/private-capital/our-insights/winning-at-private-equity-integrations\"\u003eMcKinsey experts suggest best practices for optimal integrations\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003ePoint-of-sale financing in the United States has grown significantly over the past 24 months. McKinsey provides an overview of the \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/buy-now-pay-later-five-business-models-to-compete\"\u003ebuy now, pay later\u003c/a\u003e\u0026rdquo; market, details key factors influencing growth, and offers ideas for market entry for banks and partnerships for merchants. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThe rise of autonomous vehicles is shifting demand for automotive chips. \u003ca href=\"/industries/industrials-and-electronics/our-insights/automotive-semiconductors-for-the-autonomous-age\"\u003eMcKinsey analyzes the current semiconductor market\u003c/a\u003e, which includes some OEMs considering in-house design. \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOur \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books\"\u003eAuthor Talks\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e series features Michael Useem, a professor at the University of Pennsylvania\u0026rsquo;s Wharton School, where he is also the director of the Center for Leadership and Change Management. He discusses his new book \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-michael-useem-on-leading-with-an-edge\"\u003eThe Edge: How 10 CEOs Learned to Lead\u0026mdash;and the Lessons for Us All\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e, which explores the thought processes behind leaders\u0026rsquo; pivotal choices. Also on \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books\"\u003eAuthor Talks\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, Jeffrey E. Garten discusses his book, \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-jeffrey-e-garten-on-the-meeting-that-transformed-the-global-economy\"\u003eThree Days at Camp David: How a Secret Meeting in 1971 Transformed the Global Economy\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e. The former dean of the Yale School of Management and undersecretary of commerce in the Clinton administration examines the end of the gold standard and its ramifications for world markets. Our most recent edition of \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-for-kids/a-tigers-tale-about-what-nature-is-really-worth\"\u003eMcKinsey for Kids\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e introduces younger audiences to mangrove forests and explains why building a \u0026ldquo;business case\u0026rdquo; for mangroves can help protect Bengal tigers and king cobras. For more perspectives, please see the full \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;of our coronavirus-related content, visual insights from our \u003cem\u003e\u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo;\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003ea curated collection of our \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 articles\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;relating to the coronavirus, our \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7b1fc4c0cc-f07a-40fd-b12a-3081fb62de78%7d%40en\"\u003esuite of tools\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic, and how our editors choose \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/covid-19-visualizing-the-impact-of-an-invisible-threat\"\u003eimages\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003ethat help readers visualize the impact of an invisible threat.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Katy McLaughlin, a senior editor in the Southern California office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #65, July 28, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eIt\u0026rsquo;s time to focus on healing.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe $1.5 trillion global wellness market\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026mdash;encompassing health, fitness, nutrition, appearance, sleep, and mindfulness\u0026mdash;is growing at 5 to 10 percent a year. It makes sense that consumers, after everything they have endured throughout the COVID-19 crisis, are seeking ways to take control of their well-being. Sectors including travel and education are also focusing on recovering from their pandemic wounds. This week, McKinsey took a deep dive into how a range of companies are trying to help consumers heal, and how companies and sectors can heal themselves.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs part of our series on \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/the-next-normal\"\u003eThe Next Normal\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e, \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/the-next-normal/wellness\"\u003eMcKinsey experts forecast what the wellness industry will look like by the end of the decade\u003c/a\u003e. By 2030, consumers may get tattoos where they buy mascara; seek advice from the fridge, which talked to the mattress, about what to eat in order to sleep better; and triage their medical conditions at home before reaching out to a doctor. As consumers increasingly consider wellness when they make purchases, the opportunity to serve their needs is growing.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOver the past year, McKinsey has interviewed a number of wellness-industry leaders. \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/the-business-of-fitness-building-the-tone-house-brand\"\u003eShaun Robert Jenkins, head coach of fitness studio Tone House\u003c/a\u003e, in New York City, discusses overcoming pandemic-related obstacles with a brand focused on omnichannel delivery, community, and authentic extensions and partnerships. \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/connectivity-with-the-consumer-the-honest-companys-formula-for-growth\"\u003eNick Vlahos, CEO of The Honest Company\u003c/a\u003e, talks about building a relationship with a consumer at the pivotal moment when she is pregnant with her first child. Brian McNamara, CEO of \u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/gsks-brian-mcnamara-on-the-business-impact-of-covid-19\"\u003eGlaxoSmithKline Consumer Healthcare\u003c/a\u003e, and \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/looking-ahead-in-us-consumer-health-an-interview-with-scott-melville\"\u003eScott Melville, CEO of the Consumer Healthcare Products Association, both predict a future in which consumers will proactively manage their own health.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAppearances seemed to matter less to many people under lockdowns during the pandemic, which likely helped contribute to the 33 percent drop in global sales that the beauty industry suffered in 2020. On the \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-consumer-and-retail-podcast\"\u003eMcKinsey on Consumer and Retail\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-consumer-and-retail-podcast\"\u003e podcast\u003c/a\u003e, McKinsey experts discuss the incipient rebound that is occurring in the fragrance category. \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/taking-a-good-look-at-the-beauty-industry\"\u003eBeauty brands are bouncing back\u003c/a\u003e, with quiz-type diagnostics that help consumers discover new products in a fun way; personalized packaging; and a wider adoption of \u0026ldquo;social selling,\u0026rdquo; which is already gaining traction in China.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMental healthcare is a key component of wellness, but the stigma that surrounds mental-health conditions often prevents sufferers from seeking treatment. \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/overcoming-stigma-three-strategies-toward-better-mental-health-in-the-workplace\"\u003eCompanies can combat mental-health stigma\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;by providing all employees with education on the topic, training managers to recognize the signs of mental illness and substance abuse, and adopting nonstigmatizing language.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/education/our-insights/covid-19-and-education-the-lingering-effects-of-unfinished-learning\"\u003eHealing is vitally needed in K\u0026ndash;12 education\u003c/a\u003e, where the average student is now five months behind in math and four months behind in reading. The economic ripple effects may cause a $128 billion to $188 billion loss to the US economy once these students enter the workforce. Educators should work to safely reopen schools, use outreach programs to reengage students who have disconnected from learning, and help make up for learning loss with tutoring and after-school programs. Moreover, the education system should consider exploring ways to benefit from technology, hybrid models, remote learning, homeschooling, and learning hubs over the long term.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTravel is another sector that has emerged bruised from pandemic lockdowns. \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/a-travel-boom-is-looming-but-is-the-industry-ready\"\u003eTo prepare for a rebound, the travel industry must\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;build capacity, invest aggressively in digital innovation, and look for collaboration opportunities to help make flying easier for consumers. An app that would allow travelers to manage verified certifications for COVID-19 vaccines and test results, for example, would be handy. In a recent interview, Airbnb CEO \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-21st-century-corporation-a-conversation-with-brian-chesky-of-airbnb\"\u003eBrian Chesky explains how the company experienced wild highs and lows throughout the pandemic\u003c/a\u003e: early on, the business dropped 80 percent in eight weeks and the company had to lay off 25 percent of its workforce. But by the end of the year, the company had launched a successful IPO.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOur most recent edition of \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-for-kids/a-tigers-tale-about-what-nature-is-really-worth\"\u003eMcKinsey for Kids\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e introduces younger audiences to mangrove forests and explains why building a \u0026ldquo;business case\u0026rdquo; for mangroves can help protect Bengal tigers and king cobras. For more perspectives, please see the full \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;of our coronavirus-related content, visual insights from our \u003cem\u003e\u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo;\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003ea curated collection of our \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 articles\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;relating to the coronavirus, our \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7b1fc4c0cc-f07a-40fd-b12a-3081fb62de78%7d%40en\"\u003esuite of tools\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic, and how our editors choose \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/covid-19-visualizing-the-impact-of-an-invisible-threat\"\u003eimages\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003ethat help readers visualize the impact of an invisible threat.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Katy McLaughlin, a senior editor in the Southern California office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #64, July 21, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eHow does it end\u0026mdash;and where does it leave us?\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCase numbers are resurging\u003c/strong\u003e in parts of the world where the COVID-19 pandemic was waning, falling in places that saw huge surges recently, and just beginning to rise in previously little-impacted parts of the globe. Trying to determine the end of a story while the plot is still twisting is difficult. But this week, McKinsey sought answers to the burning questions of how the pandemic can finally be vanquished and how vaccines can reach the world, as well as what companies can do to mitigate new geopolitical risks and cope with inflation and volatility.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe world is unlikely to ever reach global herd immunity, but it can contain the virus with a combination of vaccines, improved testing, and smarter quarantining, based on known outbreaks, rather than large, blunt lockdowns. This was one conclusion of an interdisciplinary panel of global-health, national-security, and technology experts that McKinsey assembled to envision \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/how-might-the-covid-19-pandemic-end\"\u003ehow the pandemic might end\u003c/a\u003e. By 2025, COVID-19 will have cost the world between $16 trillion and $35 trillion. A multifaceted approach to solving this pandemic and averting others should include scaling nanobiophysics technology in order to create precision molecular testing and improving data-sharing systems.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDr. Seth Berkley, CEO of Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance (a public\u0026ndash;private global-health partnership that works to increase access to immunization in poor countries), spoke with McKinsey \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/finding-solidarity-in-an-effort-to-vaccinate-the-world\"\u003eabout the effort to get COVID-19 vaccines into arms across the world\u003c/a\u003e. Through a partnership with 193 countries and territories, Gavi has been involved in securing two billion doses of COVID-19 vaccines for the second half of 2021, with the goal of immunizing every healthcare worker in the world. Obstacles to worldwide vaccination remain huge: while 49.6 percent of inhabitants of high-income countries had received at least one dose of the vaccine as of July 14, only 1 percent of those in low-income countries had.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe velocity of change coming out of the pandemic is generating new forms of financial and operational risk as companies grapple with inflation, capacity constraints, and supply-chain disruptions. Higher inflation has returned to the United States and the European Union, with volatility in prices for commodities including lumber and steel. To strategize for both the near and long term, companies are wise to establish \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/responding-to-inflation-and-volatility-time-for-procurement-to-lead\"\u003eprocurement nerve centers\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that bring together specialists in supply chain, planning, finance, operations, and engineering.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the next two decades, competition for global influence is likely to reach its highest level since the Cold War. Current tensions are most apparent in the unfolding competition between China and the United States, the homes of 76 of the world\u0026rsquo;s 100 most valuable companies. To \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/how-global-companies-can-manage-geopolitical-risk\"\u003emanage geopolitical risk\u003c/a\u003e, boards should devote time to big-picture questions. Companies also need to think critically about their corporate narratives and decide whether they are global entities or whether ties to a specific country or region are more important.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOther key findings from our sector research this week:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/how-the-automotive-industry-is-accelerating-out-of-the-turn\"\u003eCar sales and production have come roaring back\u003c/a\u003e, but today\u0026rsquo;s consumers, suppliers, and dealers demand more digital, connected, and electric vehicles. Automakers will have to hire more software engineers and reskill up to one-quarter of their current workforces.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eClimate change poses specific risks for urban areas, 90 percent of which are coastal. By 2050, more than 800 million urban residents could be affected by sea-level rise and coastal flooding.
