A report cowritten by McKinsey and C40 Cities Climate Leadership, a network of large cities committed to addressing climate change, identifies \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/how-cities-can-adapt-to-climate-change\"\u003e15 high-potential actions that can work for many types of cities\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/dont-overthink-your-approach-to-valuation-in-emerging-markets\"\u003eInvestors apply risk premiums too aggressively when assessing emerging markets\u003c/a\u003e, McKinsey research finds. Business leaders can rely on the same valuation principles and approaches they would use to assess investments in developed markets.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOur \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books\"\u003eAuthor Talks\u003c/a\u003e \u003cem\u003eseries features Melody Wilding, an executive coach, licensed social worker, and professor of human behavior about her book \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-melody-wilding-on-turning-sensitivity-into-a-superpower\"\u003eTrust Yourself: Stop Overthinking and Channel Your Emotions for Success at Work\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e. She addresses the complexity of being both highly sensitive and high achieving, a combination she says can be a competitive advantage in those who know how to overcome self-doubt. Our most recent edition of \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-for-kids/a-tigers-tale-about-what-nature-is-really-worth\"\u003eMcKinsey for Kids\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e introduces younger audiences to mangrove forests and explains why building a \u0026ldquo;business case\u0026rdquo; for mangroves can help protect Bengal tigers and king cobras. For more perspectives, please see the full \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;of our coronavirus-related content, visual insights from our \u003cem\u003e\u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo;\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003ea curated collection of our \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 articles\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;relating to the coronavirus, our \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7b1fc4c0cc-f07a-40fd-b12a-3081fb62de78%7d%40en\"\u003esuite of tools\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic, and how our editors choose \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/covid-19-visualizing-the-impact-of-an-invisible-threat\"\u003eimages\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003ethat help readers visualize the impact of an invisible threat.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Katy McLaughlin, a senior editor in the Southern California office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #63, July 14, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eThe future of work is far from settled.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe COVID-19 pandemic\u003c/strong\u003e ushered in the opportunity to rethink how we work. It\u0026rsquo;s a sea change that occurs less than once in a generation and has the potential to reshape society in countless ways. This week, McKinsey examined the need for humility as leaders, organizations, and employees grapple with learning best practices, testing solutions, and admitting that nobody has all the answers in hand.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCompanies risk alienating their employees\u0026mdash;and even losing them\u0026mdash;if they refuse to acknowledge \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/its-time-for-leaders-to-get-real-about-hybrid\"\u003ethe disconnect between how employers and their workers see the future\u003c/a\u003e. Employers want to reestablish normality by bringing workers back to the office; employees want far more work-from-home. For employers, the risks are high: recent surveys found that 40 percent of workers globally are considering leaving their current employers by the end of the year. Companies must acknowledge that figuring out a hybrid working model will be a long-term project and require a significant period of testing and learning.  \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eResearch with more than 500 senior executives across eight industries helped McKinsey identify \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/return-as-a-muscle-how-lessons-from-covid-19-can-shape-a-robust-operating-model-for-hybrid-and-beyond\"\u003ekey things companies should do to create a robust and productive operating model for hybrid work\u003c/a\u003e. Companies that increased performance throughout the pandemic invested more time crafting clear goals and clarifying strategy; empowered small, cross-silo teams to make decisions; spent more time on coaching and recognition; and adopted new collaboration technologies. Going back to the office isn\u0026rsquo;t a silver bullet, especially in light of weary and stressed workforces. Instead, companies need to build muscle in these key areas in order to make a return to the workplace successful.  \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSince the start of the pandemic, 42 percent of employees globally have reported a decline in mental health. Mental-health conditions cause absenteeism, presenteeism, and approximately\n$1 trillion worth of lost productivity a year, according to the World Health Organization. The good news is that a meta-analysis shows that for every dollar companies spent on wellness programs, their healthcare costs fell by approximately $3.27 and their absenteeism costs by about $2.73. \u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/using-digital-tech-to-support-employees-mental-health-and-resilience\"\u003eMcKinsey identified six main types of digital offerings that could be helpful for companies implementing an employee well-being strategy\u003c/a\u003e. These include mindfulness tools, data-collection wearables, meditation and hypnosis apps, and virtual mental-health services. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/shaping-the-workforce-of-the-future-in-retail-and-consumer-goods\"\u003eForward-thinking retail companies are creating thoughtful guidelines for hybrid work\u003c/a\u003e, training employees to bounce back from burnout, and proactively reskilling their workforces. On the \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-consumer-and-retail-podcast\"\u003eMcKinsey on Consumer and Retail\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e podcast, partners Bryan Hancock and Ashish Kothari discuss retail companies that need to add new skills because of the sectors\u0026rsquo; mass pivot to omnichannel during the pandemic. They share examples of companies that have replaced some work with automation and then redirected employees\u0026rsquo; time and energy to new tasks that can grow the business.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/ron-ohanley-of-state-street-on-corporate-resilience-and-esg\"\u003eChairman and CEO of State Street Corporation Ron O\u0026rsquo;Hanley\u003c/a\u003e oversees one of the oldest American financial institutions, with $38.0 trillion in assets under custody and administration, and $3.5 trillion in assets under management. On the \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/inside-the-strategy-room-podcast\"\u003eInside the Strategy Room\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e podcast, he talks about his view of taking a stand on environmental, social, and corporate governance issues as part of mitigating investment risk. Remote work has made it harder to give employees opportunities for apprenticeship, slowed innovation, and created mental-health risks. Communicating to employees how values play into the big picture helps reestablish bonds.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOther key findings from our sector research this week:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eSeth Moore, former chief strategy and analytics officer of online retailer Overstock.com, who is now a senior adviser to McKinsey, clears up several misconceptions about \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/the-power-and-pitfalls-of-dynamic-pricing-for-omnichannel-retailers\"\u003edynamic pricing in a retail context\u003c/a\u003e. It\u0026rsquo;s not about changing prices frequently, nor is it a blend of art and science. It\u0026rsquo;s plain old science, whereby an algorithm can increase the rate at which a retailer makes good pricing decisions. Personalizing prices for customers is a delicate matter; the best strategy is to offer \u0026ldquo;just for you\u0026rdquo; discounts that make a shopper feel like they won something.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s analysis of 54 markets around the world found that over half of all \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/making-banks-from-branch-networks-why-financial-services-are-still-a-good-idea-for-postal-carriers-and-retailers\"\u003epostal carriers are well positioned to enter the financial-services market\u003c/a\u003e. If postal executives can leverage their existing distribution networks to provide financial services, their companies could become a more integral part of their customers\u0026rsquo; everyday lives and create enduring business models.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOur \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books\"\u003eAuthor Talks\u003c/a\u003e \u003cem\u003eseries features Shankar Vedantam, host of NPR\u0026rsquo;s \u003c/em\u003eHidden Brain \u003cem\u003epodcast, about his book \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-shankar-vedantam-on-the-power-and-paradox-of-self-deception\"\u003eUseful Delusions: The Power and Paradox of the Self-Deceiving Brain\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003e(W. W. Norton, March 2021), coauthored with Bill Mesler. No one likes the idea of being duped, but our ability to persuade ourselves enables bonds and passions that logic would rule out. Our most recent edition of \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-for-kids/a-tigers-tale-about-what-nature-is-really-worth\"\u003eMcKinsey for Kids\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e introduces younger audiences to mangrove forests and explains why building a \u0026ldquo;business case\u0026rdquo; for mangroves can help protect Bengal tigers and king cobras. For more perspectives, please see the full \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;of our coronavirus-related content, visual insights from our \u003cem\u003e\u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo;\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003ea curated collection of our \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 articles\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;relating to the coronavirus, our \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7b1fc4c0cc-f07a-40fd-b12a-3081fb62de78%7d%40en\"\u003esuite of tools\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic, and how our editors choose \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/covid-19-visualizing-the-impact-of-an-invisible-threat\"\u003eimages\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003ethat help readers visualize the impact of an invisible threat.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Katy McLaughlin, a senior editor in the Southern California office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #62, July 7, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eWhen two distinct goals are imperative, the only choice is to solve for both.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThroughout the COVID-19\u003c/strong\u003e pandemic, businesses and governments faced the need to solve multiple, competing priorities simultaneously. One of the toughest: how to keep an economy going while at the same time shutting it down to protect citizens from infection. As some regions emerge from the worst of the health crisis, it\u0026rsquo;s tempting to think that there could be a return to focusing on just one main concern. But this week, McKinsey experts examined sectors, particularly defense and national infrastructure, where solving for dual imperatives is more important than ever.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/aerospace-and-defense/our-insights/decarbonizing-defense-imperative-and-opportunity\"\u003eDefense forces, which typically account for at least 50 percent of governments\u0026rsquo; carbon emissions, could help prevent climate change\u003c/a\u003e\u0026mdash;and the many risks it implies\u0026mdash;by taking dramatic action to decarbonize. Obstacles to change include the primacy of having mission-critical capability and long equipment life cycles (which means fossil-fuel-powered equipment in use now, or coming into service shortly, will still be fielded in 2050). But defense forces can begin setting priorities for decarbonization by categorizing their emissions as those for which they are directly responsible and those resulting from the supply chain, and by how much emissions reductions would impact mission-critical initiatives. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe May 2021 ransomware attack on Colonial Pipeline, the United States\u0026rsquo; largest pipeline network for delivery of refined petroleum products, made one thing clear: \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/building-cyber-resilience-in-national-critical-infrastructure\"\u003enational critical infrastructure just inherited a new imperative, which is to build cyber resilience\u003c/a\u003e. In light of the new level of threat, companies will have to improve their knowledge of their own operations and vulnerabilities and establish high-fidelity baselines for the devices on their networks so they can detect subtle anomalies. Owners and operators must move to a zero-trust mindset and need to improve their systems\u0026rsquo; ability to respond and establish control. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the not-so-distant future, waste products such as \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/from-farm-to-sky-feedstocks-fuel-indias-path-to-cleaner-skies\"\u003eused cooking oils and agricultural residues will fuel airplanes in the sky\u003c/a\u003e. One country championing the use of such sustainable aviation fuels (SAFs) is India. \u003ca href=\"/~/media/mckinsey/industries/travel logistics and infrastructure/our insights/from farm to sky feedstocks fuel indias path to cleaner skies/clean-skies-for-tomorrow.pdf\"\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s recent report with the World Economic Forum\u0026rsquo;s Clean Skies for Tomorrow Coalition\u003c/a\u003e\u0026mdash;which is working toward making carbon-zero flying a reality by the middle of the century\u0026mdash;is a blueprint for India\u0026rsquo;s ongoing transition to SAFs. The coalition\u0026rsquo;s community in India has set the goal of flying 100 million passengers on SAFs at a 10 percent blend by 2030.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are some other key findings from our sector research this week:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eOn the \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/inside-the-strategy-room-podcast\"\u003eInside the Strategy Room\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e podcast, Tanya Baker, global leader of Goldman Sach\u0026rsquo;s internal incubator GS Accelerate, talks about \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-committed-innovator-a-conversation-with-tanya-baker-of-goldman-sachs-accelerate\"\u003ewhat it takes to foster entrepreneurship\u003c/a\u003e. Two big lessons: if you have to choose between a great idea and a great team of people, pick the people, because ultimately talent rules outcomes. Her second takeaway: people who have been successful in other roles at Goldman Sachs are not always the same people who will succeed at building a new business. Entrepreneurship often requires a separate set of skills.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eOn \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-podcast\"\u003eThe McKinsey Podcast\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e, senior partners Kim Baroudy and Massimo Mazza discuss \u003ca href=\"/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/our-insights/entrepreneurship-beyond-silicon-valley\"\u003ethe state of entrepreneurship outside the confines of Silicon Valley\u003c/a\u003e. Europe\u0026rsquo;s fragmentation\u0026mdash;its 24 languages and multiple regulatory environments\u0026mdash;is a hidden strength, as it forces founders to think internationally. Capital growth and the kinds of companies achieving scale in Latin America is changing fast. Silicon Valley can feel flattered by imitation, as tech hubs grow in Tel Aviv, S\u0026atilde;o Paulo, Frankfurt, London, Shanghai, Paris, Berlin, and Stockholm. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eHow did \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/nordic-payments-where-collaboration-and-competition-lead-to-innovation\"\u003eNordic companies come to form the vanguard of innovation in digital, mobile, and instant payments\u003c/a\u003e? Claus Bunkenborg, CEO of MobilePay; Peter Klein, executive vice president, strategy and solutions, for new payment platforms at Mastercard; and Lars Sj\u0026ouml;gren, CEO of P27 Nordic Payments, discuss the influence of Nordic history and business culture on the sector. One theory: a history of wars has forced these small countries to learn to compromise and collaborate. \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOur most recent edition of \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-for-kids/a-tigers-tale-about-what-nature-is-really-worth\"\u003eMcKinsey for Kids\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e introduces younger audiences to mangrove forests and explains why building a business case for mangroves can help protect Bengal tigers and king cobras. For more perspectives, please see the full \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;of our coronavirus-related content, visual insights from our \u003cem\u003e\u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo;\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003ea curated collection of our \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 articles\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;relating to the coronavirus, our \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7b1fc4c0cc-f07a-40fd-b12a-3081fb62de78%7d%40en\"\u003esuite of tools\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic, and how our editors choose \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/covid-19-visualizing-the-impact-of-an-invisible-threat\"\u003eimages\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003ethat help readers visualize the impact of an invisible threat.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Katy McLaughlin, a senior editor in the Southern California office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #61, June 30, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eHow do we make technology rise to our aspirations?\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003ePart of the great reset,\u003c/strong\u003e as companies and countries envision a post-COVID-19 future, is rethinking how technology can serve our needs. Science-fiction scenarios may depict computers developing minds of their own, but the work of updating algorithms, adjusting risk models, and deciding how data will be leveraged is still very much a human job. This week, McKinsey made the case for why open-data ecosystems for finance is the next frontier and examined the technology rethink required in retail, insurance, banking, automotive, photonics, and biotech.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRobust digital financial infrastructure proved its worth during the COVID-19-crisis, helping governments cushion people and businesses from the economic shock. The \u003ca href=\"/mgi/overview\"\u003eMcKinsey Global Institute\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;discusses the next step: \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/financial-data-unbound-the-value-of-open-data-for-individuals-and-institutions\"\u003eeconomies that embrace data sharing for finance\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;could see GDP gains of between 1 and 5 percent by 2030, with benefits flowing to both consumers and financial institutions. The research examines 24 use cases in banking and payments, focusing on the European Union, United States, United Kingdom, and India. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/how-tech-will-revolutionize-retail\"\u003eretailer of the future\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;will harness the power of data, quantum computing, artificial intelligence, and augmented reality, says serial entrepreneur and senior adviser to McKinsey John Straw on the \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-consumer-and-retail-podcast\"\u003eMcKinsey on Consumer and Retail\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e podcast. The biggest mistake retail companies make? Unwillingness to invest in something that doesn\u0026rsquo;t automatically feed the bottom line. The biggest win: using cutting-edge technology to give consumers a way of envisioning their lives if they go ahead and buy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn a \u003ca href=\"/quarterly/overview\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eMcKinsey Quarterly\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;interview, Bart Schlatmann, the CEO of Allianz Direct, discusses \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/a-digital-business-builder-an-interview-with-the-ceo-of-allianz-direct\"\u003ehow to build a scalable, new, digital business inside of an older, more established company\u003c/a\u003e. The direct-to-consumer insurance business inside financial-services giant Allianz serves multiple European markets on a single platform. The CEO\u0026rsquo;s first move was to put himself under pressure: with approximately 70 engineers, he promised to launch a business in two markets within 18 months.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe COVID-19 pandemic created significant challenges for financial institutions in both modeling and model-risk management. \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/model-life-cycle-transformation-in-the-next-decade\"\u003eInstitutions should use six strategies to update their models\u003c/a\u003e, including using agile modeling, upgrading data architecture, and embracing automation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBatteries and fuel cells get the attention, but \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/how-hydrogen-combustion-engines-can-contribute-to-zero-emissions\"\u003ehydrogen combustion\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;is a nascent zero-emissions technology that some automotive OEMs, component suppliers, and start-ups are reconsidering. Low capital-expenditure requirements for combustion engines, decreasing hydrogen prices, and the relative efficiency of some types of vehicles are making this technology, once considered too expensive, increasingly relevant.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnother technology ripe for reinvention is \u003ca href=\"/industries/industrials-and-electronics/our-insights/the-next-wave-of-innovation-in-photonics\"\u003ephotonics\u003c/a\u003e. Although the laser market has steadily increased since the 1970s, innovation and revenue growth have slowed over the past decade. The creation of integrated devices combining lasers, sensors, and optics could usher in a new age of opportunity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/can-european-biotechs-achieve-greater-scale-in-a-fragmented-landscape\"\u003eEurope\u0026rsquo;s biotech industry\u003c/a\u003e has remained resilient through one of the worst economic crises in decades. Despite a brief downturn in 2020, share-price evolution has been positive overall since the beginning of the pandemic, and funding continues to grow at a record rate. Future success will depend on improving the translation of research into new companies, raising more capital, cultivating entrepreneurial talent, and building global networks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are some other key findings from our sector research this week:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eA \u003ca href=\"/mgi/overview\"\u003eMcKinsey Global Institute\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;survey of 18,000 people in 15 counties identified \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/defining-the-skills-citizens-will-need-in-the-future-world-of-work\"\u003e56 foundational skills that can help future-proof workforces\u003c/a\u003e. One revelation: though numerous skills are associated with having a university degree, for \u0026ldquo;self-confidence,\u0026rdquo; \u0026ldquo;courage and risk-taking,\u0026rdquo; and \u0026ldquo;empathy,\u0026rdquo; there is no such association. Scholars can puzzle over this: more education was associated with lower proficiency of some valuable traits, such as \u0026ldquo;humility.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThe combination of increased burnout among women and the hold placed on diversity and inclusion initiatives has put \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/reprioritizing-the-employee-experience-in-consumer-goods-and-retail-companies\"\u003econsumer-goods and retail companies at a greater risk of losing diverse talent\u003c/a\u003e. Companies should ensure flexible work and employee well-being and create programs to promote diverse hiring and promotion.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOur most recent edition of \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-for-kids/a-tigers-tale-about-what-nature-is-really-worth\"\u003eMcKinsey for Kids\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e introduces younger audiences to mangrove forests and explains why building a \u0026ldquo;business case\u0026rdquo; for mangroves can help protect Bengal tigers and king cobras. For more perspectives, please see the full \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;of our coronavirus-related content, visual insights from our \u003cem\u003e\u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo;\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003ea curated collection of our \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 articles\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;relating to the coronavirus, our \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7b1fc4c0cc-f07a-40fd-b12a-3081fb62de78%7d%40en\"\u003esuite of tools\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic, and how our editors choose \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/covid-19-visualizing-the-impact-of-an-invisible-threat\"\u003eimages\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003ethat help readers visualize the impact of an invisible threat.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Katy McLaughlin, a senior editor in the Southern California office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #60, June 23, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eWith enough data and insight, can we get a peek at the future?\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u0026ldquo;Business forecasting exists to make astrology look good,\u0026rdquo; \u003c/strong\u003esays McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s global managing partner Kevin Sneader, paraphrasing John Kenneth Galbraith\u0026rsquo;s famous quip before outlining eight trends that he predicts will define 2021 and beyond. Despite the complexity of trying to peer into the future, this week McKinsey experts propose what\u0026rsquo;s ahead for capital markets, corporate organization, and medical research. In a deep analysis of the state of Black America, our experts envision what the future could be for nearly 13 percent of the US labor force.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo get a handle on what\u0026rsquo;s to come, McKinsey finance and risk experts, with input from the \u003ca href=\"/mgi/overview\"\u003eMcKinsey Global Institute\u003c/a\u003e, offer \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/beyond-the-pandemic-eight-charts-on-covid-19-and-the-next-phase-of-global-economic-growth\"\u003eeight charts depicting the retreat of the virus in some regions, increasing economic stability, and near-term growth\u003c/a\u003e. Further charts examine how economies have recovered from crises in the past and model possible outcomes.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOn the \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/inside-the-strategy-room-podcast\"\u003eInside the Strategy Room\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e podcast, \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-eight-trends-that-will-define-2021-and-beyond\"\u003eSneader discusses the eight trends that will shape the post-COVID-19 economy\u003c/a\u003e. He predicts that e-grocery and telemedicine will stick and that \u0026ldquo;revenge travel,\u0026rdquo; where people vacation after being cooped up, will kick in. Companies will likely focus on developing more resilient supply chains and attempting to recover in ways that meet their sustainability targets. More than anything, pandemic-era innovations will reshape life for a long time to come.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/the-economic-state-of-black-america-what-is-and-what-could-be\"\u003eWhat will the future look like for Black Americans\u003c/a\u003e, who make up 12.9 percent of the US labor force but earn only 9.6 percent of total wages? Achieving better standards of living, jobs, education, healthcare, food, and consumer goods will depend on changes to the world Black people currently face. The \u003ca href=\"/mgi/overview\"\u003eMcKinsey Global Institute\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;concluded that hiring with a diversity focus, strengthening schools, upgrading the quality of jobs that many Black workers currently have, and supporting Black entrepreneurs are key to closing the prosperity gap.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOn \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-podcast\"\u003eThe McKinsey Podcast\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e, organizational experts Chris Gagnon and Elizabeth Mygatt discuss \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/how-to-future-proof-your-organization\"\u003ehow companies can future-proof\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;themselves, making them more able to handle disruptions like the one they just went through. Leaders should examine their company\u0026rsquo;s value agenda as though they were a private-equity firm scrutinizing a potential deal. Being clear about what everyone is trying to accomplish helps leaders choose the right talent, create a project-oriented organization, and build up speed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSome companies are using their plans for a COVID-19 as the basis for complete strategy overhauls. But not every company wants or needs to do that. Instead, they can use \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/why-your-covid-19-exit-needs-strategy-inserts\"\u003estrategy inserts\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;or short interventions. In particular, companies should examine opportunities to allocate resources to growth pockets, get ahead of climate risks, and adopt new technologies.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\"Rollercoaster\" is one term that\u0026rsquo;s been used to describe \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/in-conversation-the-impact-of-covid-19-on-capital-markets\"\u003ethe performance of capital markets during the pandemic\u003c/a\u003e. McKinsey finance experts Tim Koller and Peter Stumpner provide more nuance and reflection on the \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/inside-the-strategy-room-podcast\"\u003eInside the Strategy Room\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e podcast. After the big market drop last year, a handful of companies\u0026mdash;mostly in the tech, electric vehicle, and semiconductor industries\u0026mdash;began diverging from the market. The result is the Mega 25, companies that accounted for 40 percent of the total market cap added in one year. The experts discuss how sustainable these valuations are and whether the word \u0026ldquo;bubble\u0026rdquo; applies.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are some other key findings from our sector research this week:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/pharmas-digital-rx-quantum-computing-in-drug-research-and-development\"\u003eQuantum computing has the potential to accelerate drug development exponentially\u003c/a\u003e. The biggest impact will be in the hypothesis-formation phase, because of how much faster and more accurately molecular properties can be predicted.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/making-supply-chain-decarbonization-happen\"\u003eSupply chains, even in heavy industry and other energy- and resource-intensive sectors, can decarbonize\u003c/a\u003e. Companies should focus on improving carbon accounting, filling in data gaps, and forming alliances to create new supply ecosystems. Once they have reduced energy and materials waste, they need to examine the \u0026ldquo;Scope 3\u0026rdquo; emissions that occur up and down their value stream.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eA \u003ca href=\"/~/media/mckinsey/business functions/marketing and sales/our insights/getting tangible about intangibles the future of growth and productivity/getting-tangible-about-intangibles-the-future-of-growth-and-productivity.pdf\"\u003eMcKinsey Global Institute\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;survey of 860 executives found that \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/getting-tangible-about-intangibles-the-future-of-growth-and-productivity\"\u003ecompanies in the top quartile for growth invested 2.6 times as much in intangibles\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;as those in the bottom two quartiles. Intangibles include research, technology, software, advertising and branding, and human capital.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOur \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books\"\u003eAuthor Talks\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e series features Mia Bay, a professor of American history at the University of Pennsylvania, discussing her new book \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-mia-bay-on-traveling-black\"\u003eTraveling Black: A Story of Race and Resistance\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e (Harvard University Press, 2021). Bay examines the history of exclusion and harassment Black Americans have faced as they attempted to drive, fly, park, lodge, or even eat on the road. Our most recent edition of \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-for-kids/a-tigers-tale-about-what-nature-is-really-worth\"\u003eMcKinsey for Kids\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e introduces younger audiences to mangrove forests and explains why building a \u0026ldquo;business case\u0026rdquo; for mangroves can help protect Bengal tigers and king cobras. For more perspectives, please see the full \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;of our coronavirus-related content, visual insights from our \u003cem\u003e\u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo;\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003ea curated collection of our \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 articles\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;relating to the coronavirus, our \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7b1fc4c0cc-f07a-40fd-b12a-3081fb62de78%7d%40en\"\u003esuite of tools\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic, and how our editors choose \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/covid-19-visualizing-the-impact-of-an-invisible-threat\"\u003eimages\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003ethat help readers visualize the impact of an invisible threat.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Katy McLaughlin, a senior editor in the Southern California office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #59, June 16, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eLife beyond the COVID-19 pandemic holds much promise.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThere\u0026rsquo;s a lot to look forward to\u003c/strong\u003e once the COVID-19 pandemic eventually fades into history. As viral-spread and economic-fallout curves both flatten in some parts of the world, signs of change and growth indicate a bright future. Our central pandemic-related analysis this week explores a possible new age of global prosperity, with high rates of economic growth and surging healthcare innovation. Individual groups and industries\u0026mdash;including Black US entrepreneurs, medical researchers, and the hospitality sector\u0026mdash;have the opportunity to benefit from a reset in context and attitudes.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the postpandemic era, much is possible. Just with the technology that is currently available\u0026mdash;no unheard-of breakthrough required\u0026mdash;it\u0026rsquo;s possible to achieve 3 to 4 percent global economic growth each year for a decade. Leaders won\u0026rsquo;t need to make a hard choice between sustained and inclusive growth. Instead, growth can be better overall if it\u0026rsquo;s more equitable. The pandemic experience provoked what could become a renaissance in public-health innovation and delivery. \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/looking-beyond-the-pandemic-could-the-world-economy-gain-more-than-it-lost-to-covid-19\"\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s analysis goes deep and broad to discover what could happen next\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/future-of-america/black-owned-businesses-face-an-unequal-path-to-recovery\"\u003eBlack US entrepreneurs face unequal access to capital\u003c/a\u003e, which makes recovery harder for their businesses. But the recent \u003ca href=\"/bem/our-insights/its-time-for-a-new-approach-to-racial-equity\"\u003eracial-equity\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;reckoning in the United States has focused multiple industries on finding solutions to that and other obstacles for Black business owners. Banks can increase access to capital, and corporations can offer emergency grants. Financial institutions can both increase financial education and design systems that are more user friendly and communicative.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eHow can corporations maintain their cultures in a world of hybrid work? On the \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/mckinsey-talks-talent-podcast\"\u003eMcKinsey Talks Talent\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e podcast, talent experts Bryan Hancock, Bill Schaninger, and Brooke Weddle discuss \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/culture-in-the-hybrid-workplace\"\u003ethe opportunity that companies have to reinvent their cultures\u003c/a\u003e. Leaders can focus on helping employees find purpose and make the office the new off site, a place where intentional togetherness occurs. There is a risk, however, that a divide will grow between remote workers and those who come into the office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf the office is the new off site, the home is the new clinical-trial site. To the growing list of unintended pandemic consequences, add \u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/no-place-like-home-stepping-up-the-decentralization-of-clinical-trials\"\u003ethe decentralization of clinical trials\u003c/a\u003e. In the face of severe disruption to clinical-trial research during lockdowns, trial sponsors mobilized rapidly to preserve continuity of care and data integrity\u0026mdash;for example, by adopting remote consent and patient monitoring, videoconference assessments, and at-home phlebotomy. The medical industry can now build on the unplanned migration to off-site trial settings.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLeisure travel, particularly to outdoor and beach settings, is likely to be a bright spot in the US hospitality industry\u0026rsquo;s recovery. In a video conversation, \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/the-path-to-recovery-for-us-hospitality\"\u003eVik Krishnan, leader of McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s work in the US travel industry, discusses the hospitality sector\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and suggests pockets of emerging demand in which industry leaders should focus resources.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/inside-the-strategy-room-podcast\"\u003eInside the Strategy Room\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e podcast steps back and examines \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/in-conversation-managing-in-extreme-uncertainty\"\u003elessons from the pandemic experience of managing through extreme uncertainty\u003c/a\u003e. McKinsey experts Patrick Finn, Mihir Mysore, and Ophelia Usher discuss how leaders must be willing to revisit assumptions, change direction, and admit mistakes when the firmament is shaking. Also key: an integrated nerve center of decision makers who can think and act quickly. Above all, leaders who have lived through hardships are essential in such circumstances.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOur \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books\"\u003eAuthor Talks\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e series features Kirsten Neff, an associate professor of educational psychology at the University of Texas at Austin, discussing her new book \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-kristin-neff-on-harnessing-fierce-self-compassion\"\u003eFierce Self-Compassion: How Women Can Harness Kindness to Speak Up, Claim their Power and Thrive\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e. Neff examines why women shame themselves for failure and how they can learn to be kind to themselves while fighting for their professional wants and needs. Our most recent edition of \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-for-kids/a-tigers-tale-about-what-nature-is-really-worth\"\u003eMcKinsey for Kids\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e introduces younger audiences to mangrove forests and explains why building a \u0026ldquo;business case\u0026rdquo; for mangroves can help protect Bengal tigers and king cobras. For more perspectives, please see the full \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;of our coronavirus-related content, visual insights from our \u003cem\u003e\u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo;\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003ea curated collection of our \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 articles\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;relating to the coronavirus, our \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7b1fc4c0cc-f07a-40fd-b12a-3081fb62de78%7d%40en\"\u003esuite of tools\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic, and how our editors choose \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/covid-19-visualizing-the-impact-of-an-invisible-threat\"\u003eimages\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003ethat help readers visualize the impact of an invisible threat.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Katy McLaughlin, a senior editor in the Southern California office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #58, June 9, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eUnderstanding who we have become.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eChange accelerates under pressure,\u003c/strong\u003e as illustrated by the last year and a quarter. This week, McKinsey drilled into numerous changes that have reset the context for companies, employees, and societies. McKinsey experts analyzed changes to consumer profiles in Asia, the consequences of women\u0026rsquo;s exodus from the workforce, and why more than 70 HR leaders believe this is a new era for their profession. Our \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-gillian-tett-on-looking-at-the-world-like-an-anthropologist\"\u003eauthor interview this week\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;suggests a way of getting a handle on the ever-morphing human landscape: we all need to become anthropologists, skilled in recognizing the cultural patterns around us (see more on our latest \u003cem\u003eAuthor Talks\u003c/em\u003e below).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHalf of global consumption growth over the next decade will come from Asia, according to research from the \u003ca href=\"/mgi/overview\"\u003eMcKinsey Global Institute\u003c/a\u003e. Falling poverty rates, rising incomes, shrinking household size, aging populations, and more women earning more money are all \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/asia-pacific/the-trailblazing-consumers-in-asia-propelling-growth\"\u003efactors reshaping Asian consumer trends\u003c/a\u003e. Those who wish to sell to these consumers need to understand factors including their growing interest in sustainability, Asian brands, and new forms of ownership. Another trend to keep in mind: inequality is growing and was likely exacerbated by the pandemic.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/back-to-human-why-hr-leaders-want-to-focus-on-people-again\"\u003eHR leaders believe their profession has transformed\u003c/a\u003e in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic. After years of pressure to digitize their roles and move employees into \u0026ldquo;self serve\u0026rdquo; solutions, McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s interviews with more than 70 chief HR officers in Europe revealed an impulse to revive human interaction. These leaders believe they must engage personally to bring in and retain strategic talent and improve morale. One reason for the pivot: they learned during the pandemic, when decisions had to be made at lightning speed, that leadership talent is everywhere and just needs the right support to flourish.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePressure can accelerate change, but sometimes reverses it. That\u0026rsquo;s the sad story behind the \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/future-of-america/what-we-lose-when-we-lose-women-in-the-workforce\"\u003e2.3 million US women who left the workforce in the first year of the pandemic\u003c/a\u003e. The latest US Bureau of Labor statistics show that recent employment gains dramatically favor men. A political scientist who studies this \u0026ldquo;shecession\u0026rdquo; and an HR executive who left her job to oversee her children\u0026rsquo;s online schooling discuss the lost paychecks, stalled careers, and lower lifetime earning that could reverberate for decades to come.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnother thing women lose by leaving the workforce? Purpose. McKinsey organizational experts found that 70 percent of people say they derive their purpose in life through their work. On \u003cem\u003eThe McKinsey Podcast\u003c/em\u003e, partner Naina Dhingra and senior partner Bill Schaninger discuss why \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/the-search-for-purpose-at-work\"\u003ecompanies should serve as conduits for the unique purpose of each of their employees\u003c/a\u003e, rather than imposers of a collective purpose. The pandemic has made employees contemplate these questions more than ever, with millennials the most concerned that work provides a sense of meaning.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUS healthcare consumers say they gained weight, exercised less, and delayed care throughout the pandemic. Their view of healthcare providers and what they want in the future changed too, according to McKinsey surveys. \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/how-covid-19-has-changed-the-way-us-consumers-think-about-healthcare\"\u003eHealthcare providers should adapt to the post-COVID-19 environment\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;by focusing on the \u0026ldquo;whole person\u0026rdquo; and offering incentives to both consumers and providers to research costs and options.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are some other key findings from our sector research this week:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eNordic companies, with their legacies of long-term focus on environmental issues, seem well-positioned to outperform while companies around the world catch up on sustainability. But a McKinsey analysis showed that many Nordic firms trail their global peers. \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/europe/bold-moves-to-forge-nordic-champions\"\u003eSolutions for Nordic companies to return to growth and scale\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;include making a deal a year, spending more, and setting ambitious productivity-improvement goals. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eSales of battery-electric vehicles are expected to grow 25 percent annually through 2030. With costs and competition increasing \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/ev-fast-charging-how-to-build-and-sustain-competitive-differentiation\"\u003efor charge-point operators, growth will come from differentiation\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of location, charging speed, and partnerships.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/tech-forward/get-the-most-out-of-your-platform-transformation\"\u003eCompanies can get the most out of their platform transformations\u003c/a\u003e if they decide whether to be orchestrators or providers, design incentives that attract the right participants, and improve technology with cloud infrastructure and a software-as-a-service approach. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/solving-the-kyc-puzzle-with-straight-through-processing\"\u003eBanks can more efficiently combat money laundering by adopting end-to-end straight-through processing\u003c/a\u003e. Automating the \u0026ldquo;know your customer\u0026rdquo; process also makes things smoother for customers and less tedious for employees. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThe market for biosimilars is expected to double in size to more than $30 billion by 2025 and\n    more than $60 billion by 2030. \u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/an-inflection-point-for-biosimilars\"\u003eBiosimilars companies who accelerate development and tailor approaches to each country\u0026rsquo;s market will be best positioned\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to take advantage of this growth.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOur \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books\"\u003eAuthor Talks\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e series features Gillian Tett, the \u003c/em\u003eFinancial Times\u003cem\u003e markets and finance columnist and US managing editor, on her book \u003c/em\u003eAnthro-Vision: A New Way to See in Business and Life\u003cem\u003e. Tett explores how anthropologists get inside the minds of people in order to understand other cultures and how leaders can do the same to appraise their own environments. Our most recent edition of \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-for-kids/a-tigers-tale-about-what-nature-is-really-worth\"\u003eMcKinsey for Kids\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e introduces younger audiences to mangrove forests and explains why building a \u0026ldquo;business case\u0026rdquo; for mangroves can help protect Bengal tigers and king cobras. For more perspectives, please see the full \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;of our coronavirus-related content, visual insights from our \u003cem\u003e\u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo;\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003ea curated collection of our \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 articles\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;relating to the coronavirus, our \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7b1fc4c0cc-f07a-40fd-b12a-3081fb62de78%7d%40en\"\u003esuite of tools\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic, and how our editors choose \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/covid-19-visualizing-the-impact-of-an-invisible-threat\"\u003eimages\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003ethat help readers visualize the impact of an invisible threat.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Katy McLaughlin, a senior editor in the Southern California office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #57, June 2, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eProblems were to be expected, but not these problems.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe pandemic\u003c/strong\u003e has left businesses and governments to grapple with a perplexing collection of supply-chain and logistical disruptions. Over a year ago, we knew we were facing upheavals in health, education, and workplace systems. Ramifications such as the semiconductor shortage, however, were harder to predict. This week, McKinsey examined a variety of unexpected pandemic consequences and looked for ways to address them.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/coping-with-the-auto-semiconductor-shortage-strategies-for-success\"\u003eThe global semiconductor shortage\u003c/a\u003e threatens economic recoveries and poses an urgent problem for carmakers, which have already announced production rollbacks\u0026mdash;and billions of dollars in expected revenue losses\u0026mdash;as a result. McKinsey experts examined the causes of the shortage, including a drop in consumer demand for vehicles at the onset of the pandemic, which prompted semiconductor suppliers to shift production to other products. Automakers and suppliers should consider significant strategic changes to head off a repeat.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGrocery is \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/whats-next-for-digital-consumers\"\u003eanother industry that has been turned upside down by the pandemic\u003c/a\u003e, not once but multiple times as consumers respond to the evolving situation. \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/doubling-online-grocery-capacity-during-the-pandemic-an-interview-with-matthew-simister\"\u003eAt Tesco, online sales doubled\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in the United Kingdom, where the company has a strong online business, and in Central Europe, where growth is coming off a low base, said Matthew Simister, Tesco\u0026rsquo;s Central Europe CEO, in an interview. Growing e-grocery leads to \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/will-brick-and-mortar-supermarkets-survive-in-europe\"\u003ethe question of whether brick-and-mortar grocers will survive\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in Europe, and if so, which formats are best positioned for success? McKinsey identified amply stocked \u0026ldquo;soft discounters\u0026rdquo; and moderately sized, centrally located \u0026ldquo;hypermarkets light\u0026rdquo; as winning models. Leading players are participating in the \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/automation-in-european-grocers-supply-chains-has-reached-its-tipping-point\"\u003eautomated warehouse revolution\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that is lowering labor costs and supporting e-grocery. Another crucial tactic: \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/value-for-money-perception-must-go-beyond-price-for-european-grocers\"\u003econvincing shoppers that a grocer offers the best value\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;by strategically discounting, improving private-label lines, and offering a large variety of cheap products.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/indias-tragedy-reverberates-around-the-world\"\u003eThe devastation in India\u003c/a\u003e is among the saddest unanticipated turns in the pandemic. After the first wave of the disease faded quickly in 2020, the current disaster took the lives of nearly 28,000 people in one week last month, amid 2.3 million new reported cases. The world should take action, write partner Pooja Kumar and senior partner Navjot Singh, with support for oxygen and vaccine production and distribution. Such help not only serves a humanitarian purpose but also lowers the risk that variants will threaten recoveries elsewhere.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSome of the health repercussions of the pandemic are indirect, such as the side effect of fewer people seeking treatment for mental and behavioral health problems. \u003ca href=\"https://covid-tracker.mckinsey.com/behavioral-health\"\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s behavioral-health-services interactive\u003c/a\u003e tracks how many people are accessing care for problems including substance abuse and serious mental illness.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOther key findings from our sector research this week:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/a-new-look-at-how-corporations-impact-the-economy-and-households\"\u003eLarge companies create flows to households in OECD economies differently today\u003c/a\u003e compared with 25 years ago. The \u003ca href=\"/mgi/overview\"\u003eMcKinsey Global Institute\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;mapped the pathways through which a dollar of company revenue reaches households. Comparing two periods, 1994\u0026ndash;96 and 2016\u0026ndash;18, productivity gains amounted to 25 percent in real terms, though wages grew only 11 percent. Where did the gains from labor productivity go? Predominantly to capital income.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/industrials-and-electronics/our-insights/implementing-a-digital-transformation-at-industrial-companies\"\u003eIndustrial companies can digitally transform\u003c/a\u003e with six building blocks, including upskilling and focusing on data management. There\u0026rsquo;s good reason to try: a McKinsey analysis of 350 industrial companies found that those that made investments in automation, e-commerce, and other areas achieved higher revenues and total returns to shareholders than digital laggards.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-committed-innovator-a-conversation-with-dometics-peter-kjellberg\"\u003eRefrigeration pioneer Dometic Group has spent the past 100 years innovating\u003c/a\u003e into areas including mobile homes, sports and outdoor tools, and home food and beverage equipment. On the \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/inside-the-strategy-room-podcast\"\u003eInside the Strategy Room\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e podcast, Peter Kjellberg, chief marketing officer and head of global verticals at Dometic, explains his system to test whether a company will support a brand reinvention: look into the CEO\u0026rsquo;s eyes, and if he or she does not display genuine enthusiasm, forget it.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOur \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books\"\u003eAuthor Talks\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e series features Shankar Vedantam, host of NPR\u0026rsquo;s Hidden Brain podcast, about his \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-shankar-vedantam-on-the-power-and-paradox-of-self-deception\"\u003eUseful Delusions: The Power and Paradox of the Self-Deceiving Brain\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e, coauthored with Bill Mesler. No one likes the idea of being duped, but our ability to persuade ourselves enables bonds and passions that logic would rule out. Our most recent edition of \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-for-kids/a-tigers-tale-about-what-nature-is-really-worth\"\u003eMcKinsey for Kids\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e introduces younger audiences to mangrove forests and explains why building a \u0026ldquo;business case\u0026rdquo; for mangroves can help protect Bengal tigers and king cobras. For more perspectives, please see the full \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;of our coronavirus-related content, visual insights from our \u003cem\u003e\u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo;\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003ea curated collection of our \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 articles\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;relating to the coronavirus, our \u003cem\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7b1fc4c0cc-f07a-40fd-b12a-3081fb62de78%7d%40en\"\u003esuite of tools\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic, and how our editors choose \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/covid-19-visualizing-the-impact-of-an-invisible-threat\"\u003eimages\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003ethat help readers visualize the impact of an invisible threat.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Katy McLaughlin, a senior editor in the Southern California office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #56, May 26, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eHow can we prepare better for next time?\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhen a crisis turns into a recovery,\u003c/strong\u003e or vice versa, leaders must toggle between managing for the present and the future. This week, McKinsey examined how sectors including health, air travel, consumer retail, and wealth management can plan for the long term even as they cope with the immediate disruptions of the pandemic. The bottom line: modeling, predicting, and planning are all important, but investing with courage is essential.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFive dollars a person. That\u0026rsquo;s how much \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/not-the-last-pandemic-investing-now-to-reimagine-public-health-systems\"\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s experts project it will cost to prevent another pandemic like COVID-19\u003c/a\u003e, which has caused what may become a $16 trillion global economic disruption. By spending a total of\n$357 billion over the next decade on preparations including pathogen surveillance, global immunization, and medical supply stockpiles, countries can reduce the likelihood of a repeat. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOther health concerns need preventative action too. \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/how-keeping-health-a-priority-is-a-prescription-for-european-prosperity\"\u003eEurope can improve the medical conditions that erode roughly 15 percent of its GDP\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;by investing in solutions for mental health, obesity, back pain, diabetes, and smoking, among other problems. The pandemic\u0026rsquo;s devastating consequences\u0026mdash;a half-million lives and 7.5 percent of GDP lost in 2020 alone\u0026mdash;have created a unique moment for Europe to rethink health-resource allocation, funding, and delivery models.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOn \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-podcast\"\u003eThe McKinsey Podcast\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e, the firm\u0026rsquo;s air-travel experts Alex Dichter and Robin Riedel discuss \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/how-air-travel-is-evolving-postpandemic\"\u003ethe near- and long-term concerns of the air-travel industry\u003c/a\u003e, which suffered roughly half a trillion dollars in revenue loss in 2020. Airlines are thinking about safety, recovering business, and how to bring back employees and equipment. In the future, sustainability, cargo by drone, and customer experience will be among the top priorities.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLet there be no doubt: top executives confirm that their \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/five-fifty-hybridized\"\u003eorganizations are switching to hybrid for work\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that isn\u0026rsquo;t essential to perform on site. \u003ca href=\"/quarterly/the-five-fifty\"\u003eThe \u003cem\u003eFive Fifty\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, a quick look accompanied by a deep dive, illustrates that while leaders know hybrid is the future, they and their employees are mired in doubt and anxiety about what it all means.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/a-year-like-no-other-for-european-grocery-retailers-the-state-of-the-industry-post-2020\"\u003eIt was a year of big percentages for European grocers\u003c/a\u003e: in 2020, the online grocery channel grew by 55 percent, 60 percent of customers changed their shopping behaviors, and the industry sold 8 percent more groceries by volume. Looking ahead, European grocers should expect grocery spending to decrease slightly, some of the behavioral changes to stick, and healthy and sustainable food preferences to grow.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAn April McKinsey survey of 29,000 respondents in 24 countries found that while the pandemic drove rapid adoption of digital channels, growth has plateaued in the past six months and may begin to slip back as the virus retreats. \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/whats-next-for-digital-consumers\"\u003eCompanies can hold onto new digital customers\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;by gaining their trust, investing in \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/omnichannel-shopping-in-2030\"\u003ephygital\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; and innovating to provide excellent experiences, particularly in education, grocery, and healthcare. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCOVID-19 underscored how important it is to have tools that improve decision making in a crisis. One such tool is \u0026ldquo;nowcasting,\u0026rdquo; a prediction model that uses complex econometric techniques and contemporaneous data to provide a timely view of economic indicators. \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/next-generation-nowcasting-to-improve-decision-making-in-a-crisis\"\u003eMcKinsey experts suggest a new approach to nowcasting\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that involves improving the quality and reducing the number of variables.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/the-value-of-personal-advice-wealth-management-through-the-pandemic\"\u003eLast year was a wild ride for financial advisors\u003c/a\u003e, who steered clients through turmoil and saw 9 percent growth\u0026mdash;a record\u0026mdash;in median assets per advisor compared with the year prior. McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s annual report on \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/the-state-of-north-american-retail-wealth-management\"\u003eThe state of North American retail wealth management\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e collected data from roughly 70,000 North American financial advisors. Among findings: fee-based revenues grew but were offset by a decline in fee pricing.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOur most recent edition of \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-for-kids/a-tigers-tale-about-what-nature-is-really-worth\"\u003eMcKinsey for Kids\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e introduces younger audiences to mangrove forests and explains why building a \u0026ldquo;business case\u0026rdquo; for mangroves can help protect Bengal tigers and king cobras.  For more perspectives, please see the full\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of our coronavirus-related content, visual insights from our \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; a curated collection of our\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 articles\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;related to the coronavirus, our\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7b1fc4c0cc-f07a-40fd-b12a-3081fb62de78%7d%40en\"\u003esuite of tools\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic, and how our editors choose\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/covid-19-visualizing-the-impact-of-an-invisible-threat\"\u003eimages\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that help readers visualize the impact of an invisible threat.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Katy McLaughlin, a senior editor in the Southern California office.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #55, May 19, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eMaking the most of the great reset.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAfter a long pandemic pause, some parts of the world are finally contemplating a restart.\u003c/strong\u003e Where the virus is subsiding, people can begin assembling an approach to life and business that combines what they miss about the time before COVID-19 and what they discovered during the pandemic. That future must include a plan for those, such as the unemployed, who are still stuck on pause.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis week, McKinsey took a deep dive into employment and workplace issues, with multiple studies, articles, and podcasts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/what-executives-are-saying-about-the-future-of-hybrid-work\"\u003eMcKinsey survey of 100 executives\u003c/a\u003e found that 90 percent envision a future with some combination of remote and on-site work, but most (68 percent) have no detailed plan for how it will work. The surveyed executives, from a wide range of industries, have good reason to desire a future with remote options: large numbers say it has led to increases in productivity and customer satisfaction.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo help companies design their strategies, \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/virtually-possible-getting-remote-work-right-for-g-and-a-functions\"\u003eMcKinsey experts suggest hybrid approaches for general and administrative functions\u003c/a\u003e, categorizing them into four types with varying needs for interaction. Office versus home is not the only paradigm; options include teams that work mostly remotely but come together for periods of intense collaboration, or hub-and-spoke systems where remote workers can come into satellite or coworking spaces as desired. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOn the \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/mckinsey-talks-talent/id1491112396\"\u003eMcKinsey Talks Talent Podcast\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e, partners Susan Lund and Bryan Hancock and senior partner Bill Schaninger discuss \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/future-of-work/the-future-of-work-after-covid-19\"\u003enew McKinsey Global Institute research\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;on the \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/grabbing-hold-of-the-new-future-of-work\"\u003elasting impact of the pandemic on labor demand\u003c/a\u003e. In the United States, 17 million people are in jobs that may see less demand, while globally 100 million people may need new skills. The daunting panorama, particularly for workers in retail and travel, underscores the need to reskill and move jobs to people and people to jobs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eVaccine development need never be the same after the pandemic. McKinsey researchers examined \u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/fast-forward-will-the-speed-of-covid-19-vaccine-development-reset-industry-norms\"\u003ehow it was possible to gain approval for three COVID-19 vaccines in a mere 11 months\u003c/a\u003e. The unprecedented speed was due to regulators moving faster, companies and governments accepting high investment risk for billions of dollars, around-the-clock lab work, and\u0026mdash;because the virus spread with tragic speed\u0026mdash;accelerated clinical trials. Some of the victories, such as fast decision making within pharma companies and high tolerance for investment risk, could be applied to future drug development.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eViral-vector gene therapy is emerging as a scientific superstar, its power demonstrated by one of the early-approved COVID-19 vaccines. \u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/gene-therapy-innovation-unlocking-the-promise-of-viral-vectors\"\u003eThis technology poses abundant promise\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;but also several challenges, including the expense and side effects of high doses.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEven amid so much change, television advertising is still relevant. Advertisers often simply hand off their broadcast strategies to media agencies, but evaluating data faster, adjusting ad placement, and increasing the frequency of media tenders can \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/good-to-great-boosting-the-efficiency-of-your-tv-spend\"\u003ehelp companies get the most out of their TV spending\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOur\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books\"\u003eAuthor Talks\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003eseries features Dambisa Moyo, an economist who currently sits on the boards of Chevron, 3M, and Cond\u0026eacute; Nast, on her new book, \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-dambisa-moyo-on-how-boards-can-work-better\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-dambisa-moyo-on-how-boards-can-work-better\"\u003eHow Boards Work: And How They Can Work Better in a Chaotic World\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-dambisa-moyo-on-how-boards-can-work-better\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;(Basic Books, 2021). The book outlines traditional board tasks and describes new \u0026ldquo;cultural frontier\u0026rdquo; responsibilities. In their new book, \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/sounding-the-alarm-on-system-noise\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/sounding-the-alarm-on-system-noise\"\u003eNoise: A Flaw in Human Judgment\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/sounding-the-alarm-on-system-noise\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;(Hachette Book Group, May 2021), strategy experts Daniel Kahneman and Olivier Sibony examine the unwanted variability in professional judgments and explain how to practice \u0026ldquo;decision hygiene.\u0026rdquo; Our most recent edition of \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-for-kids/a-tigers-tale-about-what-nature-is-really-worth\"\u003eMcKinsey for Kids\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e introduces younger audiences to mangrove forests and explains why building a \u0026ldquo;business case\u0026rdquo; for mangroves can help protect Bengal tigers and king cobras.
