For more perspectives, please see the full\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of our coronavirus-related content, visual insights from our \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; a curated collection of our\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 articles\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;related to the coronavirus, our\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7b1fc4c0cc-f07a-40fd-b12a-3081fb62de78%7d%40en\"\u003esuite of tools\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic, and how our editors choose\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/covid-19-visualizing-the-impact-of-an-invisible-threat\"\u003eimages\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that help readers visualize the impact of an invisible threat.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Katy McLaughlin, a senior editor in the Southern California office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #54, May 12, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eDon\u0026rsquo;t let the pandemic whittle away at the workforce.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe pandemic has hit everyone hard,\u003c/strong\u003e but some groups have suffered in unique ways. Working mothers, Asian Americans, and nurses are among those whose difficulties at work and at home\u0026mdash;which for many is now the same stressful place\u0026mdash;could result in a retreat from their careers. As employers prepare to emerge from the crisis, they must find creative ways to support the hardest-hit communities, which can require rethinking long-held beliefs. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/for-mothers-in-the-workplace-a-year-and-counting-like-no-other\"\u003eThe pandemic has been brutal for working mothers\u003c/a\u003e, a third of whom say they are considering leaving the workforce or downshifting their careers. One of the culprits is the double shift, the eternal burden of working mothers that has gotten worse during the COVID-19 crisis and is even more troubling for women of color. Companies can help by providing emergency childcare and tutoring services, offering to continue remote work for those who want it, and revising hiring standards to eliminate the bias against gaps in employment. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/nursing-in-2021-retaining-the-healthcare-workforce-when-we-need-it-most\"\u003eA McKinsey survey of 400 frontline nurses\u003c/a\u003e revealed that 22 percent may leave their jobs providing direct patient care in the next year, a reflection of the physical and mental strain the pandemic has placed upon the profession. Employers should counteract this by improving in four key areas: providing more recognition, incentives, and breaks; offering flexible scheduling; finding opportunities for nurses to provide telemedicine services and other innovative patient-care delivery methods; and reskilling, so that nurses can keep up with technological advances.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAsian Americans have long struggled for equality in the workplace, a fact reflected by their low representation in senior-level jobs relative to their representation in entry-level jobs. In a series of charts based on survey data from McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s latest \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/women-in-the-workplace-archive\"\u003eWomen in the Workplace\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;report, created in partnership with LeanIn.org, we explore the \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/covid-19s-impact-on-asian-american-workers-six-key-insights\"\u003enegative effects the pandemic has had on Asian Americans\u003c/a\u003e, concerning stress levels, engagement in work, and sense of opportunity. Solutions include promoting the practice of sponsorship and expanding workplace flexibility.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMcKinsey also looked at the US dairy industry\u0026rsquo;s tumultuous first pandemic year, which included milk dumping in April 2020 even as some store dairy cases sat empty. \u003ca href=\"/industries/agriculture/our-insights/what-us-dairy-executives-learned-from-the-pandemic\"\u003eOur survey of 50 US dairy CEOs in the fourth quarter of 2020, followed by interviews\u003c/a\u003e, revealed a sense of optimism combined with concern over changing consumer tastes. Best practices this year include being proactive about health and sustainability messaging, expanding the talent pool to include remote workers, and making supply chains more resilient.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOn \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-podcast\"\u003eThe McKinsey Podcast\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e, former Unilever CEO Paul Polman and McKinsey senior partner Dame Vivian Hunt discuss why, increasingly, the way for companies to deliver resilience, longevity, and growth is to build \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/stakeholder-capitalism-a-conversation-with-vivian-hunt-and-paul-polman\"\u003estakeholder capitalism\u003c/a\u003e. The pandemic illustrated how expensive it is to let a health problem fester; companies should learn this lesson and apply it to broad social issues including the environment and diversity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOur\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books\"\u003eAuthor Talks\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003eseries features former Best Buy CEO and chairman Hubert Joly on his new book, \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-hubert-joly-on-unleashing-human-magic\"\u003eThe Heart of Business: Leadership Principles for the Next Era of Capitalism\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e (Harvard Business Review Press, May 2021). Mr. Joly, who currently lectures at Harvard Business School, writes about what it means to lead with purpose and humanity. Our most recent edition of \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-for-kids/a-tigers-tale-about-what-nature-is-really-worth\"\u003eMcKinsey for Kids\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e introduces younger audiences to mangrove forests and explains why building a \u0026ldquo;business case\u0026rdquo; for mangroves can help protect Bengal tigers and king cobras.  For more perspectives, please see the full\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of our coronavirus-related content, visual insights from our \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; a curated collection of our\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 articles\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;related to the coronavirus, our\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7b1fc4c0cc-f07a-40fd-b12a-3081fb62de78%7d%40en\"\u003esuite of tools\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic, and how our editors choose\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/covid-19-visualizing-the-impact-of-an-invisible-threat\"\u003eimages\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that help readers visualize the impact of an invisible threat.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Katy McLaughlin, a senior editor in the Southern California office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #53, May 5, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eHow can we prepare the workforce for the postpandemic world?\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDuring the pandemic,\u003c/strong\u003e we learned to cope; in the postpandemic world, we need to learn to thrive. Companies emerging from the crisis are realizing that workforces require new capabilities to face the digital and environmental future. This week, McKinsey examined what industries should do to develop the talent and knowledge they need.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo flourish during and after the pandemic, \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/building-workforce-skills-at-scale-to-thrive-during-and-after-the-covid-19-crisis\"\u003ecompanies need a new set of skills\u003c/a\u003e, including social and emotional, advanced cognitive, and digital capabilities. In a recent \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-global-surveys\"\u003eMcKinsey Global Survey\u003c/a\u003e, 69 percent of respondents said that building the skills of existing staff is more important than any other method of talent building, including hiring. It\u0026rsquo;s time for companies to strategize talent development and identify the most effective options, including digital learning and in-person workshops.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/how-boards-have-risen-to-the-covid-19-challenge-and-whats-next\"\u003eBoards and management responded to the pandemic\u003c/a\u003e by working harder and collaborating more on crisis management. Having found more effective ways to work together, directors and managers should build on the momentum by continuing to hold some meetings remotely, even when it is no longer required for health reasons, engaging in more formal and informal contact, and focusing on corporate resilience.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-coronavirus-effect-on-global-economic-sentiment\"\u003eBusiness leaders are feeling good about the global economy\u003c/a\u003e. In the April McKinsey Global Survey on economic sentiment, 73 percent of respondents said they believe that conditions will improve in the next six months. The share of executives expecting conditions to worsen has shrunk by more than half in the past three months. Sentiment is most buoyant in North America and Greater China and most negative in India and Latin America, where the pandemic has recently taken a devastating toll.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMeanwhile, workers may be too groggy to feel optimistic about anything. This edition of the \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/quarterly/the-five-fifty\"\u003eMcKinsey Quarterly Five Fifty\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e, a quick look accompanied by \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/what-employees-are-saying-about-the-future-of-remote-work\"\u003ean optional deep dive\u003c/a\u003e, examines \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/five-fifty-the-great-exhaustion\"\u003ethe great exhaustion\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; in which nearly half of all workers surveyed report symptoms of burnout brought on by hybrid work.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe world could gain a new seventh largest economy by 2030 if \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/asia-pacific/ten-ideas-to-unlock-indonesias-growth-after-covid-19\"\u003eIndonesia can return to its prepandemic growth rate\u003c/a\u003e. McKinsey proposes ten ways to reignite Indonesia\u0026rsquo;s economy, including by investing in its healthcare system, adopting modern agricultural technologies, and promoting domestic tourism.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are some other key findings from our sector research this week:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/on-target-how-to-succeed-with-carbon-reduction-initiatives\"\u003eHow can companies succeed in their green initiatives?\u003c/a\u003e McKinsey examined thousands of companies\u0026rsquo; greenhouse-gas-emissions disclosures and identified factors that contributed to success.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/whats-ahead-for-biotech-another-wave-or-low-tide\"\u003eBiotech had a banner year\u003c/a\u003e, but to keep building, companies need to find more talent and get better at going to market.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/how-the-medtech-industry-can-capture-value-from-digital-health\"\u003eMedtech must change\u003c/a\u003e to take advantage of the digital transformation of healthcare. Patients, not products, need to be the new focus.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/winning-the-chinese-bev-market-how-leading-international-oems-compete\"\u003eTo win market share for battery-electric vehicles in China\u003c/a\u003e, Western automakers must understand what the Chinese consumer wants.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOur most recent edition of \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-for-kids/a-tigers-tale-about-what-nature-is-really-worth\"\u003eMcKinsey for Kids\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e introduces younger audiences to mangrove forests and explains why building a \u0026ldquo;business case\u0026rdquo; for mangroves can help protect  Bengal tigers and King cobras. Our \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books\"\u003eAuthor Talks\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e series features Ohio State University professor Angus Fletcher on his new book, \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-angus-fletcher-on-the-power-of-literature\"\u003eWonderworks: The 25 Most Powerful Inventions in the History of Literature\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e, about a neuroscience-based method of reading and teaching literature that reveals its power to inspire. For more perspectives, please see the full\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of our coronavirus-related content, visual insights from our \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; a curated collection of our\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 articles\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;related to the coronavirus, our\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7b1fc4c0cc-f07a-40fd-b12a-3081fb62de78%7d%40en\"\u003esuite of tools\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic, and how our editors choose\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/covid-19-visualizing-the-impact-of-an-invisible-threat\"\u003eimages\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that help readers visualize the impact of an invisible threat.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Katy McLaughlin, a senior editor in the Southern California office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #52, April 28, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eThe pandemic is a fierce teacher, but how do we apply the lessons?\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWe know\u003c/strong\u003e the COVID-19 pandemic has changed consumer behavior, attitudes toward office work, and even some views about society itself. But knowing something and knowing what to do about it are two different things. This week, McKinsey looked across industries and sectors at how knowledge\u0026mdash;increasingly, though not exclusively, generated by advanced-analytics technology\u0026mdash;can be used to improve the way we tackle challenges.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe pandemic reshaped what consumers buy and how they go about getting it. The challenge for consumer-packaged-goods companies is to \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/can-your-supply-chain-deliver-what-your-consumer-wants\"\u003eredesign their supply-chain operating models\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to be resilient enough to meet new consumer demands. Because each company is different, key first steps include identifying unique strengths and honing in on the most critical objectives.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAmong the most obvious pandemic takeaways: \u003ca href=\"/industries/real-estate/our-insights/the-workplace-will-never-be-the-same-imperatives-for-real-estate-owners-and-operators\"\u003eworkplaces will never be the same\u003c/a\u003e, and companies that want to lure workers back in will have to dangle more than a sterile \u0026ldquo;cube farm\u0026rdquo; and lukewarm office coffee. But for tenants, it\u0026rsquo;s not obvious how the future will play out in their office spaces, so owner/operators must take the lead, offering more flexible leasing models, redesigning layouts to accommodate hybrid work, and supplying a \u0026ldquo;wow factor.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe pandemic gave many business leaders practice in thinking about an external issue as a core concern. Stakeholder capitalism, similarly, asks business leaders to \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-case-for-stakeholder-capitalism\"\u003edefine their mission\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;as creating long-term value not only for shareholders but also for customers, suppliers, employees, communities, and others. \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/from-principle-to-practice-making-stakeholder-capitalism-work\"\u003eMaking stakeholder capitalism work\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;requires five steps, including identifying stakeholders, defining ways to serve them, and committing to a long-term outlook.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePrivate markets experienced a year of disruption, starting with a \u0026ldquo;COVID correction\u0026rdquo; in the second quarter and followed by a K-shaped recovery that favored private equity and left real estate lagging. These are some of the insights found in the \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/private-capital/our-insights/mckinseys-private-markets-annual-review-archive\"\u003eMcKinsey Global Private Markets Review 2021\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e, a thorough analysis of the bumpy ride of 2020.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are some other key findings from our sector research this week:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/fulfilling-the-promise-of-advanced-analytics-in-oncology\"\u003eAdvanced analytics could revolutionize cancer treatment\u003c/a\u003e, but use of this technology is underdeveloped. The field is held back by factors that include a lack of data scientists with oncology expertise. But companies that solve the biggest problem\u0026mdash;a cultural tendency toward skepticism of analytics techniques\u0026mdash;will move fastest in adopting these game-changing tools.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eDigital analytics have transformed nearly every part of how companies operate, except for the one that guides them all: strategy. \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-strategy-analytics-revolution\"\u003eIt\u0026rsquo;s time for leaders to bring advanced analytics into the strategy room\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to help reduce bias, identify trends, and spot growth opportunities.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eAs companies rebuild and restructure for the \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/the-next-normal\"\u003enext normal\u003c/a\u003e, they need to determine how and where to invest in new capabilities. \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-cfos-role-in-capability-building\"\u003eCFOs are ideally positioned to identify capability needs\u003c/a\u003e, articulate the value in investing in them to C-suite leaders, and steer resources where they are most required.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-podcast\"\u003eThe McKinsey Podcast\u003c/a\u003e \u003c/em\u003ethis week delves into that most complex of human relationships. No, not with Mom, the ex, nor the teenage offspring. Instead, Tera Allas, director of research and economics in McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s London office, \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/the-boss-factor\"\u003eexamines the power our bosses have over us\u003c/a\u003e, why working from home changed some dynamics, and how important it is to organizations for bosses to be better at the job. \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eBusiness leaders crave new perspectives. But getting vaccination right is multifaceted, with abundant opportunities for missteps, and complicated by variants that can throw even the best-oiled system into disarray.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-podcast\"\u003eThe McKinsey Podcast\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e this week features senior partners Lieven Van der Veken and Tania Zulu Holt outlining what we\u0026rsquo;ve learned so far about a \u003ca href=\"/industries/social-sector/our-insights/the-covid-19-vaccine-lessons-and-challenges\"\u003ewell-built vaccine rollout\u003c/a\u003e. Each country\u0026rsquo;s program is \u003ca href=\"/industries/social-sector/our-insights/the-covid-19-vaccines-are-here-what-comes-next\"\u003ea complex system of component parts\u003c/a\u003e, and the challenge is making sure a weakness in one area doesn\u0026rsquo;t delay or derail everything else. A key question countries face is how to inspire popular acceptance of the vaccine. The answer? Perhaps another Elvis, who played a role in promoting the polio vaccine in the 1950s.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/getting-to-work-employers-role-in-covid-19-vaccination\"\u003eEmployers\u003c/a\u003e can also play a key role in the quest for herd immunity. Paid time off to get vaccinated was the most popular incentive, but information and appointment help also rated high.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSuch efforts are not just niceties. But with employees feeling anxious and burned out, getting the balance of the new hybrid model right is critical. We surveyed 5,000 employees to find out \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/what-employees-are-saying-about-the-future-of-remote-work\"\u003ewhat they\u0026rsquo;re saying about remote work\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and summarized the findings in a dozen charts. Here\u0026rsquo;s an important one: any communication helps a little, but detailed information on policies and plans helps much more.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlong with employee burnout and anxiety has come a lot of soul-searching. After a year of the COVID-19 pandemic, people are reexamining and remaking every part of their lives, especially their jobs. Companies that ignore this do so at their peril because employees also say that if their job doesn\u0026rsquo;t give them purpose, they\u0026rsquo;ll leave for one that will.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis week, we looked into the next normal for several sectors, starting with \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/back-to-the-future-airline-sector-poised-for-change-post-covid-19\"\u003eairlines\u003c/a\u003e. Leisure trips will fuel the recovery, but it won\u0026rsquo;t be easy or quick. What comes next?\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eOne year ago this month,\u003c/strong\u003e WHO declared a global pandemic. Through a long and dismal year, McKinsey has \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003etracked\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;the development of COVID-19 and its devastation and disruption. Today, we mark the milestone with a set of new reports and articles that look ahead with considerable optimism to the second year of the pandemic.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePublic health is still the chief concern. In the latest installment of our perspectives on \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/when-will-the-covid-19-pandemic-end\"\u003ewhen the pandemic will end\u003c/a\u003e, we see progress toward normalcy during the second quarter of 2021 in the United Kingdom and the United States and herd immunity in the third quarter. The new wave of cases in the European Union means that these transitions are likely to come later. But new variants of the coronavirus and other risks threaten that timeline.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNew US COVID-19 cases rose sharply in late 2020 and, until recently, declined nearly as steeply during the first few months of 2021. This pattern is similar to that of other respiratory viruses in the winter months, but in this case, many are not sure precisely why it has happened. One unexplored factor may be at work: the different patterns of human interactions. Some \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/all-in-the-mix-why-us-covid-19-cases-rose-and-fell-and-what-comes-next\"\u003epeople get out and about\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;much more than others, but most epidemiological models don\u0026rsquo;t account for that.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe global economy has rebounded from the lows of 2020 (stock markets have too, though in \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/four-regions-four-stories-of-recovery-and-resilience\"\u003edifferent ways\u003c/a\u003e), but its future direction is hazy, even by the standards of economic forecasting. Throughout the crisis, we have offered two essential tools for business leaders to plot a course; this month, we updated both of them. In April 2020, we \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/safeguarding-our-lives-and-our-livelihoods-the-imperative-of-our-time\"\u003epublished\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;a set of nine scenarios as part of our economic model and \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-coronavirus-effect-on-global-economic-sentiment\"\u003esurveyed\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;thousands of global business executives about their economic outlook. Our latest \u003ca href=\"/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7bead334e6-5610-409d-a683-1b51709a1aa7%7d%40en\"\u003esurvey\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;finds greater optimism about the economy and corporate prospects than at any time since the crisis began\u0026mdash;and on a few fronts, more than in the past several years. Still, weak demand continues to threaten corporate growth, and the pandemic remains the biggest risk to growth in respondents\u0026rsquo; countries. See our interactives about the scenarios and the surveys \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/nine-scenarios-for-the-covid-19-economy\"\u003ehere\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eProductivity has long been a weak spot in global growth, but the crisis might have kick-started a rise in productivity. As companies shifted rapidly to online channels, automated production tasks, increased operational efficiency, and sped up decision making and innovation of operating models, productivity also rose\u0026mdash;and more growth may be in store. New McKinsey Global Institute \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/will-productivity-and-growth-return-after-the-covid-19-crisis\"\u003eresearch\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;finds that there is potential to accelerate annual productivity growth by about one percentage point in the period to 2024. The stakes are high. One percentage point of additional productivity growth per year in every country to 2024 would imply an increase in per capita GDP ranging from about $1,500 in Spain to about $3,500 in the United States.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHow do companies find the extra gear needed for a sustained burst in productivity? As our researchers suggest, \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/speed-and-resilience-five-priorities-for-the-next-five-months\"\u003espeed thrills\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;but also chills: companies need to work through five critical questions in the next few months to lock in the speed of the pandemic response in a way that does not wreck mental health or cause employees to burnout. According to a McKinsey survey, productivity is up for about half of all workers, with the other half reporting no change or lower productivity. Tilting that balance will be vital.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlso this week: \u003cem\u003eThe McKinsey Podcast\u003c/em\u003e listened in on the \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/the-postpandemic-state-of-fashion\"\u003epostpandemic state of fashion\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;(it\u0026rsquo;s sweatpants today, but tomorrow will be different). And our industry researchers took a look at \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/middle-east-and-africa/african-banking-in-the-new-reality\"\u003eAfrican banking\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in the new reality and the path forward for \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/the-path-forward-for-european-grocery-retailers\"\u003eEuropean grocers\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eBusiness leaders crave new perspectives. In \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7b944e912e-f0aa-42c6-b18a-15568673f0c8%7d%40en\"\u003eOur Asian Voices\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e, a new feature, 72 Asian colleagues at McKinsey raise their voices and share their stories\u0026mdash;on what Asian identity means, what allies can do to support them, and how they are processing this moment. Our \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books\"\u003eAuthor Talks\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e series features the writers of the best new business books; in this week\u0026rsquo;s edition, \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-saadia-madsbjerg-on-making-money-moral\"\u003eSaadia Madsbjerg\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;speaks on making money moral. For more perspectives, please see the full\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of our coronavirus-related content, visual insights from our \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; a curated collection of our\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 articles\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;related to the coronavirus, our\u0026nbsp;suite of tools\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic, and how our editors choose\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/covid-19-visualizing-the-impact-of-an-invisible-threat\"\u003eimages\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that help readers visualize the impact of an invisible threat.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Mark Staples, an executive editor in the New York office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #47, March 24, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eAfter a year when consumers did everything differently, what changes will stick?\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eConsumer behavior\u003c/strong\u003e has changed: it\u0026rsquo;s a truism of COVID-19 analysis. What\u0026rsquo;s missing is a sense of what behaviors have changed for good and what are likely to revert to prepandemic norms. A new \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/the-consumer-demand-recovery-and-lasting-effects-of-covid-19\"\u003ereport\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;from the McKinsey Global Institute offers a view: e-grocery shopping is here to stay, while remote learning for primary grades could be headed for the dustbin of history. We devised a \u0026ldquo;stickiness\u0026rdquo; index (or, if we\u0026rsquo;re being academic, a gauge of behavior plasticity) to assess all the big shifts of 2020.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis week, we spoke with two prominent executives about what\u0026rsquo;s stuck with them from their pandemic experience. Chris Kempczinski, CEO of McDonald\u0026rsquo;s, \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/keeping-mcdonalds-relevant-an-interview-with-ceo-chris-kempczinski\"\u003espoke\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;with senior partner Greg Kelly about how the company has worked hard to stay relevant. For a restaurant chain in the crisis, that means excelling at delivery; McDonald\u0026rsquo;s expanded the number of its locations offering delivery to more than 30,000. Leena Nair, chief human-resources officer of Unilever, shared her \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/fit-for-the-postpandemic-future-unilevers-leena-nair-on-reinventing-how-we-work\"\u003estrategies for caring\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;about 150,000 employees with senior partner Mary Meaney and executive editor Astrid Sandoval. For those in the workforce wondering when 2020\u0026rsquo;s pace of work might relent, here\u0026rsquo;s one encouraging sign: Nair says, \u0026ldquo;This speed is unsustainable.\u0026rdquo; \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlso this week, our industry researchers examined the potential for \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/asia-pacific/reimagining-tourism-how-vietnam-can-accelerate-travel-recovery\"\u003eVietnam to rebuild tourism\u003c/a\u003e, the ecosystem opportunity for \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/defining-and-seizing-the-mobility-ecosystem-opportunity\"\u003emobility companies\u003c/a\u003e, and the pleasant surprises \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/omnichannel-in-b2b-sales-the-new-normal-in-a-year-that-has-been-anything-but\"\u003eB2B companies\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;have discovered as they adapted to online sales. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally, in the pandemic, many of us have spent more time with our children than we used to, and we\u0026rsquo;ve learned from them. In our new edition of \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-for-kids/food-waste-not-want-not\"\u003eMcKinsey for Kids\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e, we attempt to return the favor by taking a look at the food distribution system and food waste. Please share it with your young people, and let us know what they think. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eBusiness leaders crave new perspectives. Check out our series of \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books\"\u003eAuthor Talks\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e, which features the writers of the best new business books. This week\u0026rsquo;s additions to the series include \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-gregory-b-fairchild-on-the-next-frontier-in-racial-equality\"\u003eGregory B. Fairchild\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;on the next frontier in racial equality and \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-nicolai-tillisch-on-how-to-frame-ambition-and-not-let-it-frame-you\"\u003eNicolai Tillisch\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;on how to frame ambition (and not let it frame you). For more perspectives, please see the full\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of our coronavirus-related content, visual insights from our \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; a curated collection of our\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 articles\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;related to the coronavirus, our\u0026nbsp;suite of tools\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic, and how our editors choose\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/covid-19-visualizing-the-impact-of-an-invisible-threat\"\u003eimages\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that help readers visualize the impact of an invisible threat.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Mark Staples, an executive editor in the New York office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #46, March 17, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eIn 2020, consumer goods and retail were shaken. What will it take to return to stirring performance?\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe future usually arrives\u003c/strong\u003e in an orderly fashion. But for consumer goods and retail, a year like no other meant that the future showed up early, and in an ugly mood. In March 2020, COVID-19 shut down retail locations across the world, forcing consumers to change their buying behaviors, and as a consequence, these two sectors may never be the same again.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTwo new reports look at the changes wrought by COVID-19 in the United States and assess their long-term effects. In \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/covid-19s-impact-on-demand-and-costs-in-the-cpg-industry\"\u003econsumer goods\u003c/a\u003e, we examine four effects on demand and costs. Demand has proved highly variable and may remain so for some time; company performance has been all over the map, even within the same category; growth soared in 2020, and large companies captured a big chunk of it; and most costs will likely remain higher in 2021.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/retail-speaks-seven-imperatives-for-the-industry\"\u003eretail\u003c/a\u003e, our research with the Retail Industry Leaders Association finds that success in a post-COVID-19 world will require hastened progress on four long-standing imperatives and three new strategies that will be increasingly critical in coming years. Consider one of the older yet still fundamental challenges: the shift to omnichannel, led by digital shopping. Our survey reveals that 65 percent of retailers base decisions about their store network on brick-and-mortar performance, without considering how changes might affect omnichannel. In a world where consumers pick their retailers based on digital offerings, that\u0026rsquo;s a recipe for irrelevance.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis week, the \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-global-surveys\"\u003eMcKinsey Global Survey\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;returned for its \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/seven-lessons-on-how-technology-transformations-can-deliver-value\"\u003eannual look at IT strategy\u003c/a\u003e. The pandemic made clear that the technology imperative is stronger than ever. One key finding: more than half of respondents said that technology transformations have lifted revenues, reduced costs, and improved employee experiences in the past two years.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally this week, new research in operations finds that \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/the-manufacturers-lighting-a-path-to-sustainable-growth\"\u003elighthouses\u003c/a\u003e\u0026rdquo;\u0026mdash;leading-edge manufacturing sites\u0026mdash;are demonstrating that the benefits of an infusion of digital can go beyond mere productivity to create a higher base for future growth. A new report from our organizational researchers examines how \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/the-new-possible-how-hr-can-help-build-the-organization-of-the-future\"\u003eHR\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;can build the organization of the future; our corporate-finance experts look at the state of \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/transformation/our-insights/road-to-recovery-the-state-of-corporate-restructuring-in-europe\"\u003ecorporate restructuring in Europe\u003c/a\u003e; and \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-podcast\"\u003eThe McKinsey Podcast\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e talks through what it will take to build \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/creating-a-more-resilient-and-responsive-government\"\u003ea more resilient and responsive government\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eWith vaccinations underway, executives everywhere are thinking about the critical next months of the pandemic. Start with the\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7ba0bc1c78-5546-4070-afc4-d4e908eca4ae%7d%40en\"\u003eMcKinsey Download Hub\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;to find McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s latest research, perspectives, and insights on the management issues that matter most, from leading through the COVID-19 crisis to managing risk and digitizing operations. Also consider our special collection of reports on the next normal, which are a product of \u003c/em\u003eOur New Future\u003cem\u003e, a multimedia series we created with CNBC. Our report collection includes a 172-page\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/how-six-companies-are-using-technology-and-data-to-transform-themselves\"\u003ereport\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;on technology and data transformation, a 130-page\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/transformation/our-insights/the-path-to-true-transformation\"\u003ereport\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;on the path to true transformation, a 206-page\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/reimagining-the-way-businesses-operate\"\u003ereport\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;on reimagining the postpandemic organization, a 157-page\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/the-challenge-of-climate-change\"\u003ereport\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;on the challenge of climate change, and a 202-page \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/the-need-for-resiliency\"\u003ereport\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;on reimagining operational resilience.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eYou can also see the full\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of our coronavirus-related content, visual insights from our \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; a curated collection of our\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 articles\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;related to the coronavirus, our\u0026nbsp;suite of tools\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic, and how our editors choose\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/covid-19-visualizing-the-impact-of-an-invisible-threat\"\u003eimages\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that help readers visualize the impact of an invisible threat.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Mark Staples, an executive editor in the New York office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #45, March 10, 2021\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eAfter a year of COVID-19, women in the workplace want out, and companies seek growth in all directions.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHere\u0026rsquo;s one of the more intriguing statistics\u003c/strong\u003e from last year\u0026rsquo;s Women in the Workplace \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/women-in-the-workplace-archive\"\u003eresearch\u003c/a\u003e: 77 percent of men think they share the load at home equally with their partners, while just 40 percent of women agree. Sounds like the guys have some \u0026ldquo;splainin\u0026rdquo; to do. Given that imbalance, and the enormous burden (three hours a day, or more) that COVID-19 has added to women\u0026rsquo;s workload, it may be less surprising that one-quarter of women in corporate America are thinking about leaving. Senior partners Alexis Krivkovich and Lareina Yee dig into the details, in the latest \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/creating-a-postpandemic-recovery-for-women-in-the-workplace\"\u003eedition\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-podcast\"\u003eThe McKinsey Podcast\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e. And our \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/seven-charts-that-show-covid-19s-impact-on-womens-employment\"\u003esalute\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to International Women\u0026rsquo;s Day charts the impact to date and hints at the way forward.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis week, McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/inside-the-strategy-room/id1422814215?mt=2\"\u003eInside the Strategy Room\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/inside-the-strategy-room/id1422814215?mt=2\"\u003e podcast\u003c/a\u003e looked at a different kind of exit: the shift that companies need to make as COVID-19 fades and the next normal takes hold. Senior partner Martin Hirt and partner Anna Koivuniemi \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/in-conversation-the-covid-exit\"\u003eexplain\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;how, with all signs pointing toward a significant, possibly historic economic rebound, companies need to pull out all the stops. Our research shows that outperformers seek growth in every dimension: core expansion, geographic, up and down the value chain, and in adjacent spaces.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRegarding that rebound: stock markets seem to have embraced the possibilities. Our latest \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-impact-of-covid-19-on-capital-markets-one-year-in\"\u003ecapital-markets research\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;reviews the four acts of the 2020 stock-market drama. What comes next is anybody\u0026rsquo;s guess. But the \u0026ldquo;Mega 25,\u0026rdquo; which reeled in 40 percent of total public market gains in 2020, will have much to say about future developments.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlso this week, our industry researchers investigated the potential for \u003ca href=\"/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/our-insights/a-battle-plan-for-telcos-digital-attacker-brands\"\u003eincumbent telcos\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to unleash digital attackers and surveyed consumers on \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/mobility-investments-in-the-next-normal\"\u003eall things mobility\u003c/a\u003e: autos, both gas and electric powered; trucks; and autonomous vehicles.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eWith vaccinations underway, executives everywhere are thinking about the critical next months of the pandemic. Vaccine development, however, is on pace for a surprising milestone.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAlthough teachers around the world\u003c/strong\u003e have different styles and standards for learning, there is one thing on which they seem to agree: a computer is no match for a classroom as a place for kids to learn. We asked teachers in eight countries to rate \u003ca href=\"/industries/education/our-insights/teacher-survey-learning-loss-is-global-and-significant\"\u003ethe effectiveness of remote learning\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;between March and July of 2020. They gave it an average score of five out of ten. The grades were especially harsh from teachers in Japan and the United States, where nearly 60 percent rated the effectiveness of remote learning at between one and three out of ten. That barely beats skipping school altogether. While the quality and support systems around remote learning have likely improved since then, this is still a striking indictment.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eReopening schools depends in part on COVID-19-vaccine development, manufacturing, and distribution. In our \u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/on-pins-and-needles-will-covid-19-vaccines-save-the-world\"\u003eestimate\u003c/a\u003e, if all clinical trials succeed, and if manufacturing commitments to scale up production hold true, more than 14 billion doses could be produced by the end of the year. Since most vaccines require two shots, that\u0026rsquo;s enough to vaccinate nearly 80 percent of the global population.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThat said, there\u0026rsquo;s a lot of green between the ball and the pocket: new variants of concern have emerged; not all populations have equitable access to supplies; and technology transfer at the required scale is complex and far from assured.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese challenges also worry business leaders seeking the next normal. We recently surveyed 300 European senior executives to understand their \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/strategic-resilience-during-the-covid-19-crisis\"\u003estrategy during COVID-19\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and find out what was working best. One critical finding was that business-model innovation was by far the most important strategic lever. Almost 90 percent of the successful companies said that new digital experiences, new partnerships, faster product development, and other changes to the business model had made them more effective.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis week, our diversity and inclusion researchers produced two new reports. In the first, we consider \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/race-in-the-workplace-the-black-experience-in-the-us-private-sector\"\u003ethe Black experience in the US private sector\u003c/a\u003e, which we hope serves to highlight the scale of the issues facing Black workers and leads to better understanding of the challenges they face, thereby galvanizing action for system-level change and better and scaled solutions. In the second, we look closely at \u003ca href=\"/industries/private-capital/our-insights/how-private-equity-can-catalyze-diversity-equity-and-inclusion-in-the-workplace\"\u003eprivate equity\u003c/a\u003e, in which gender and racial diversity are stronger in entry-level positions than in more senior roles. One idea for asset managers to consider: diversity assessments of investment targets, to assess risk and to understand the value-creation opportunity from improving diversity, equity, and inclusion.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally, the new \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/five-fifty-breaking-through-in-health\"\u003eedition\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of the \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/quarterly/the-five-fifty\"\u003eFive Fifty\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e looks at healthcare, where ten promising innovations might speed effective responses to future pandemics and health crises.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eWith vaccinations underway, executives everywhere are thinking about the critical next months of the pandemic. Our new #America2021 series looks at how the country can recover.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe US presidential transition\u003c/strong\u003e is always a time for the country to reflect and reset. The 2021 transition is much more than that; given the once-in-a-century pandemic, it is a watershed moment. This week, we published a \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/america-2021\"\u003eseries of five memos\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;offering our latest perspectives on four issues confronting the country and how public- and private-sector leaders could organize to drive change on them.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[BespokeInteractive 1]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eDefeat COVID-19.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e Will 2021 be the year in which the United States gains a decisive upper hand in its fight against the pandemic? We argue that it is reasonable to hope that the first half of the year could be a bridge to \u0026ldquo;normalcy,\u0026rdquo; when many aspects of social and economic life can resume without fear of excess mortality. This \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/america-2021-building-a-bridge-to-normalcy\"\u003ememo\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;condenses the recent history of the COVID-19 crisis into must-see charts and sets out six considerations for those building bridges to normalcy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eRebuild the economy.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e For America\u0026rsquo;s leaders, innovators, and changemakers, the post\u0026ndash;World War II recovery offers valuable lessons for encouraging productivity, innovation, and social-capital creation in a post-COVID-19 future. Global managing partner Kevin Sneader and senior partner Shubham Singhal \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/america-2021-rebuilding-lives-and-livelihoods-after-covid-19\"\u003eexplore\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;the good policies, political commitment, and hard work that will be needed to replicate those successes.\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eAdvance racial equity.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e Repairing the frayed social fabric in the United States is not a new problem. But as the civil unrest of 2020 showed, it has become increasingly urgent. Our experts contribute \u003ca href=\"/bem/our-insights/america-2021-the-opportunity-to-advance-racial-equity\"\u003eideas for inclusive growth\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;for all races and the impact, in particular, of higher Black participation in different roles in the economy\u0026mdash;a goal that the pandemic has set back.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eCommit to climate action.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e The global transition to a low-carbon economy is well underway. In the United States, 23 states have established emission-reduction goals, and 12 have instituted carbon-pricing policies. Making good on those intentions will require new information, products, operations, and market innovations from public officials and business leaders. Our experts \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/america-2021-renewing-the-nations-commitment-to-climate-action\"\u003ebring the best\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s decades of research to the task.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eOrganize for change.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e To make all this happen, public-sector leaders will need to move swiftly and decisively, bringing the whole of government to bear across all four priorities, even as they revitalize a federal workforce with plummeting morale and lack of trust in government leadership. In the final memo of the series, we \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/america-2021-making-change-happen-against-the-odds\"\u003edistill the lessons\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;from successful government-change programs in a set of tactical ideas for leaders to consider.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlso this week, the McKinsey Global Institute published the first of three reports that examine the postpandemic economy. In \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/future-of-work/the-future-of-work-after-covid-19\"\u003eThe future of work after COVID-19\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e, we assess the lasting impact of the pandemic on labor demand, the mix of occupations, and the workforce skills required in eight countries with diverse economic and labor-market models: China, France, Germany, India, Japan, Spain, the United Kingdom, and the United States. Our research concludes that because of the pandemic, up to 25 percent more workers than previously estimated may need to switch occupations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eWith vaccinations underway, executives everywhere are thinking about the critical next months of the pandemic. Start with the\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7ba0bc1c78-5546-4070-afc4-d4e908eca4ae%7d%40en\"\u003eMcKinsey Download Hub\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;to find McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s latest research, perspectives, and insights on the management issues that matter most, from leading through the COVID-19 crisis to managing risk and digitizing operations. Our latest logistics research takes a look.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMore than 12 billion vaccine doses\u003c/strong\u003e have been announced by manufacturers for release in 2021, subject to successful clinical trials. The earth\u0026rsquo;s population is 7.8 billion. Coverage for a first dose seems adequate, until you consider the logistics. Manufacturing is concentrated in a handful of countries; regions without manufacturing must import the vaccine.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur new \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/is-the-world-up-to-the-challenge-of-mass-covid-19-vaccination\"\u003eresearch\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;looks into the considerable obstacles blocking these flows, including the need for ultracold supply chains, lack of air-cargo capacity, and counterfeiting. What\u0026rsquo;s needed is collective action on an unprecedented scale among manufacturers, governments, customs authorities, and others.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSome countries, such as the United Kingdom, are equipped with adequate vaccine manufacturing to meet domestic needs. But the United Kingdom faces other problems, such as the plight of small and medium-size businesses, which we \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/how-the-covid-19-crisis-is-affecting-uk-small-and-medium-size-enterprises\"\u003edescribed\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in June 2020. Our \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/uk-small-and-medium-size-enterprises-impact-of-the-covid-19-crisis\"\u003eupdate\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;shows that on many measures, life is getting better for these companies. But many are still dependent on government support, and anxious about what comes next.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCompanies everywhere are reckoning with the first-order effects of the pandemic and trying to anticipate those of the second order. In this week\u0026rsquo;s \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/the-vanishing-middle-manager\"\u003eepisode\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of the \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/mckinsey-talks-talent-podcast\"\u003eMcKinsey Talks Talent\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e podcast, our experts help you get out in front of the changes in middle management. Faster, flatter, leaner: companies have been trying for decades to thin their ranks. But amid the challenges of the pandemic, middle managers can still make valuable contributions, in new ways.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eStock markets seem to have established their own form of herd immunity. This week, marking the 50th anniversary of Nasdaq, senior partner Vijay D\u0026rsquo;Silva and executive editor Roberta Fusaro \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/taking-stock-catching-up-with-nasdaq-ceo-adena-friedman\"\u003espoke\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;with Nasdaq CEO Adena Friedman about how markets are staying relevant, and partner Tim Koller \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/how-capital-markets-keep-us-connected\"\u003eweighed in\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;on how markets should be more inclusive, share more information, inspire innovation, and bring the world together.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlso new this week, we explored the \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/the-nine-traits-of-future-ready-companies\"\u003enine traits\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of future-ready companies, tracked down a winning formula for \u003ca href=\"/industries/chemicals/our-insights/a-winning-formula-for-specialty-chemical-conglomerates\"\u003especialty chemical\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;companies, and \u003ca href=\"/industries/semiconductors/our-insights/navigating-through-change-an-interview-with-nxp-semiconductors-kurt-sievers\"\u003espoke\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;with the new CEO of NXP Semiconductors.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally, we conclude \u003cem\u003eOur New Future\u003c/em\u003e, a series of management discussions in partnership with CNBC; our final topic is \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/the-need-for-resiliency\"\u003ethe need for resiliency\u003c/a\u003e. Senior partner Katy George leads the discussion, joined by Arvind Krishna, CEO of IBM. One essential insight: resiliency isn\u0026rsquo;t a lever to be pulled; rather, it\u0026rsquo;s a combination of actions, technologies, and strategies that companies work on every day.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eWith vaccinations underway, executives everywhere are thinking about the critical next months of the pandemic. In our newest \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-coronavirus-effect-on-global-economic-sentiment\"\u003eMcKinsey Global Survey\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of more than a thousand executives from all industries, the outlook is still positive, though not quite as strong as in early December 2020. Majorities of executives continue to believe that conditions in their home economies and in the global economy will improve over the next six months.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe also ask leaders about their home countries. The story there is mixed. Sentiment in India is up and is nearly as positive as it is in China. But in Asia\u0026ndash;Pacific and Europe, the share of executives that is optimistic fell by double digits. And in Latin America, just 30 percent are optimistic, the lowest figure globally.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAdvanced industrials companies are among the world\u0026rsquo;s largest\u0026mdash;and those most affected by the pandemic. Worldwide, these firms (including advanced electronics, aerospace and defense, and automotive and assembly companies) employ almost 25 million people and generate about $9.3 trillion in annual revenue. The crisis has hurt sales, margins, and growth. In our new comprehensive \u003ca href=\"/industries/industrials-and-electronics/our-insights/the-ceo-agenda-for-companies-in-advanced-industries\"\u003ereport\u003c/a\u003e, we outline ten actions that industrials can take to undo the damage and pivot to a postcrisis future. Among the ideas: take advantage of the stunning developments in e-commerce. Companies that embed digital sales into their marketing models see five-times-faster revenue growth compared with previous levels, as well as 30 percent higher acquisition efficiency and cost reductions of 40 to 60 percent within sales.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur researchers continue to track the long-running crisis of our time: climate change. In a new report, we address the potential for \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/a-blueprint-for-scaling-voluntary-carbon-markets-to-meet-the-climate-challenge\"\u003evoluntary carbon markets\u003c/a\u003e. Some companies need carbon credits to offset emissions they can\u0026rsquo;t get rid of by other means. Others might have credits to sell. But carbon markets have a mixed track record. To build a better one, buyers, sellers, and a few other stakeholders need to come together. Our research for the \u003ca href=\"https://www.iif.com/tsvcm\"\u003eTaskforce on Scaling Voluntary Carbon Markets\u003c/a\u003e, led by Mark Carney and Bill Winters, explains what\u0026rsquo;s needed. And in this week\u0026rsquo;s \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/climate-math-what-it-takes-to-limit-warming-to-1-point-5-degrees-c\"\u003eedition\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of the \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-podcast\"\u003eMcKinsey Podcast\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e, McKinsey experts discuss what can be done to truly decarbonize global business at scale.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlso new this week, we outline a new portfolio model for \u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/a-new-portfolio-model-for-biotech\"\u003ebiotech\u003c/a\u003e; consider the potential for \u0026ldquo;smart quality\u0026rdquo; assurance in \u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/making-quality-assurance-smart\"\u003epharmaceuticals\u003c/a\u003e; and share tips for \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/tips-for-new-government-leaders-unlocking-diversity-and-inclusion\"\u003egovernment leaders\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to unlock diversity and inclusion. Our new research explores where and why.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMcKinsey research\u003c/strong\u003e intently continues to examine the progress of SARS-CoV-2 vaccine development and distribution. Both represent serious threats to the timetable. This week, we looked more closely at the problems in vaccine distribution. We start by mapping the operating path, from raw materials to post-vaccination care. At every step, \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/the-risks-and-challenges-of-the-global-covid-19-vaccine-rollout\"\u003erisks and challenges\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;are emerging. But so too are collaborative approaches that can help countries achieve herd immunity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe pandemic has been a tough, real-life stress test for government disbursement schemes, highlighting not only opportunities but also gaps and vulnerabilities. Our new \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/covid-19-making-the-case-for-robust-digital-financial-infrastructure\"\u003eresearch\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;across 12 countries shows both. One key finding: getting aid to those who need it is greatly bolstered by digital payment channels, a basic digital identification system used by most people, and simple data on individuals and businesses that are tethered to that digital ID.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGone but not forgotten: in the crisis, global CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e emissions briefly plunged, then resumed. Today, as economies rebuild, the climate challenge is again top of mind. For a new report published this week, we teamed up with the World Economic Forum (WEF) to examine \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/why-investing-in-nature-is-key-to-climate-mitigation\"\u003enatural climate solutions\u003c/a\u003e. Simply put, these are techniques to increase carbon storage and avoid emissions\u0026mdash;through better conservation, restoration, and management of our priceless natural resources. There is no clear path to mitigate the damaging effects of climate change that doesn\u0026rsquo;t include natural climate solutions. The case is complete when you consider the urgent need to slow the destruction of the natural world. (We\u0026rsquo;re also collaborating with WEF on the \u003ca href=\"/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7bbba2d50b-e3b6-4994-b0d7-e0c57fc5dd58%7d%40en\"\u003eDavos Agenda\u003c/a\u003e, the first of two events being held in place of its usual annual meeting.)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlso this week, we looked at \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/five-themes-can-help-procurement-shape-recovery-in-the-next-normal\"\u003eprocurement in the next normal\u003c/a\u003e, the greatly exaggerated rumor of the \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/asia-pacific/did-online-delivery-kill-the-vending-machine\"\u003edeath of the vending machine\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in Japan, the dramatic shifts in \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/sporting-goods-2021-the-next-normal-for-an-industry-in-flux\"\u003esporting goods\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;over the past year, and the rising value of \u003ca href=\"/industries/industrials-and-electronics/our-insights/the-rising-value-of-industrial-brands\"\u003eindustrial brands\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eWith vaccinations underway, executives everywhere are thinking about the critical next months of the pandemic. New research looks at developments in industrial technology, renewables, travel, ASEAN\u0026rsquo;s vast human capital, and China\u0026rsquo;s education system.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIn 2020,\u003c/strong\u003e the largest health and economic crisis in recent history forced companies across sectors into extraordinary measures to protect their people and maintain operations. Did the technologies of the ongoing Fourth Industrial Revolution (or Industry 4.0) help? Our new \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/covid-19-an-inflection-point-for-industry-40\"\u003esurvey\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of industrial companies (two-thirds in Asia) suggests three outcomes, starting with a huge win for companies that had already scaled digital technologies. Those that were still scaling faced a reality check, and 2020 was a wake-up call for those that hadn\u0026rsquo;t yet started on their Industry 4.0 journeys.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOther technologies are also changing life in Asia. While coal is expected to remain a significant component of India\u0026rsquo;s energy mix, the country is placing big bets on renewable power, which could make up nearly half of the global total electricity capacity by 2035. Among the biggest believers is Sumant Sinha of ReNew Power. Our interview \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/india/asia-at-the-speed-of-light-an-interview-with-the-head-of-renew-power\"\u003eexplores\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;why renewables are different in Asia.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur 2020 \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/covid-19-tourism-spend-recovery-in-numbers\"\u003eresearch\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;offered a perspective on the coming rebound in travel: how far, how fast, and where. Now, in an \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/indonesias-traveloka-finds-strength-in-local-markets-amid-the-pandemic\"\u003einterview\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;with McKinsey, the president of online travel unicorn Traveloka explains the nuts and bolts of the rebound. The critical moves for this company? Giving a thousand employee-volunteers the tools they needed to help customers with more than 150,000 refund requests; extending credit to strapped customers who were having trouble saving for their big trip; and thinking about the local market beyond the big beach destinations popular with international tourists.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor many people, those beaches are a major part of the allure of ASEAN countries, along with sunshine, great food, and history. But as our recent \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/asia-pacific/reimagining-emerging-asean-in-the-wake-of-covid-19\"\u003eresearch\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;shows, there is more to ASEAN than just that, and now is a good time to rethink ASEAN and its 650 million people, $3 trillion economy, ten countries, and history of robust growth: 5 percent over the past 20-plus years. In the latest \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/future-of-asia/future-of-asia-podcasts/can-asean-maintain-its-growth-trajectory-in-a-post-covid-19-world\"\u003eFuture of Asia Podcast\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e, our experts delve into the question of whether ASEAN can maintain that track record after the difficult challenges of COVID-19. Short answer: yes, if the region can harness its extraordinary resources.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAcross Asia, and the world, work is changing as digitization and automation spread. Hundreds of millions of people may need to raise and refresh their skills; some may need to change occupations. Up to one-third of these transitions may be needed in China. What happens next?\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFor a time in 2020,\u003c/strong\u003e we stopped driving, flying, commuting. And we stopped buying the fuel needed to do these things. Today, even as economies have restarted, fuel demand remains subdued. McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s \u003cem\u003eGlobal Energy Perspective 2021\u003c/em\u003e, an annual report, \u003ca href=\"/industries/oil-and-gas/our-insights/global-energy-perspective-2021\"\u003eanalyzes\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;the ways in which the COVID-19 pandemic has permanently shifted energy-demand curves. Demand is likely to return to 2019 levels within one to four years, with electricity and gas rebounding fastest. But we do not foresee a return to the previous trajectory of growth in demand.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the longer term, the energy transition\u0026mdash;already underway before 2020\u0026mdash;will accelerate. Power consumption doubles by 2050 as energy demand electrifies, wealth increases, and green hydrogen picks up momentum. Oil demand peaks in 2029; gas, in 2037. But fossil fuels continue to play a major role in the energy system in 2050. Our \u003ca href=\"/industries/oil-and-gas/our-insights/global-energy-perspective-2021\"\u003ereference-case\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;modeling helps you understand all the twists and turns.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith workforces now located in kitchens, basements, and attics, what will happen to all those sleek urban office towers and their glossy suburban counterparts? The answer has to start with their current tenants. Our latest survey of CXOs, which focused on \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/the-corporate-center-driving-the-next-normal\"\u003ethe corporate center\u003c/a\u003e, finds that most companies are intensely debating the issues raised by COVID-19\u0026rsquo;s work-from-home experiment, and many companies are planning substantial shifts in the next three to nine months. In the short term, 70 percent of corporate-center executives plan to reconfigure office space, as do 54 percent of business-unit leaders. Over the midterm, 30 percent of corporate centers want to terminate existing leases early, compared with 14 percent of business units. Finally, as they look to the longer term, 55 percent of corporate centers plan to shift toward fewer and lower-cost locations. Business heads showed more willingness to stay put.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn a crisis, it\u0026rsquo;s all hands on deck. Bank tellers are becoming financial advisors; fresh-faced managers are leading enormous projects; and companies are intently searching for people with the aptitude to become data analysts and mobile web designers. In this month\u0026rsquo;s edition of the \u003cem\u003eMcKinsey Quarterly Five Fifty\u003c/em\u003e, we document the trend underpinning it all: \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/five-fifty-the-skillful-corporation\"\u003ereskilling\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlso this week, we researched the long-term effects of the pandemic on \u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/biopharma-2020-a-landmark-year-and-a-reset-for-the-future\"\u003ebiopharma\u003c/a\u003e, explained the \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/organizing-for-the-future-nine-keys-to-becoming-a-future-ready-company\"\u003enine keys\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to becoming a future-ready company, and considered the long-run implications of 2020 on \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/the-latin-american-energy-sector-how-to-address-cybersecurity\"\u003ecybersecurity in Latin America\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eExecutives everywhere are thinking about the critical next months of the pandemic. Start with the\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7ba0bc1c78-5546-4070-afc4-d4e908eca4ae%7d%40en\"\u003eMcKinsey Download Hub\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;to find McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s latest research, perspectives, and insights on the management issues that matter most, from leading through the COVID-19 crisis to managing risk and digitizing operations.
